Capitalised Kumar
revision.text:
[[Image:-174 -20 globe.jpg|thumb|right|Location of Fiji in the Pacific Ocean]] The '''Fiji Meteorological Service (FMS)''' is a Department of the government of [[Fiji]] responsible for providing weather forecasts and is based in [[Nadi]]. The current director of Fiji Meteorological Service is Ravind Kumar. Since 1985, FMS has been responsible for naming and tracking [[tropical cyclone]]s in the Southwest Pacific region. Current Meteorologists working at FMS have a Graduate Diploma in Meteorology from the Australian [[Bureau of Meteorology]].
==History== In the 1910s, weather services for Fiji were considered part of the responsibility of the Harbour Board in Suva.<ref>http://www.mca.gov.to/Met/index_files/history_tms.pdf{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Role of Fiji Meteorological Services== [[Image:Nadi town.jpg|190px|right]] Since June 1995, the central weather office of Fiji, Nadi, has been one of six [[Regional Specialized Meteorological Center]]s within the World Weather Watch program of the [[World Meteorological Organization]]. Its specialty is forecasting tropical cyclones south of the [[equator]] to the [[25th parallel south]], and between the [[160th meridian east]] and [[120th meridian west]] [[longitude]]. FMS issues public and marine weather bulletins for [[Kiribati]], Northern Cooks, Southern Cooks, [[Tuvalu]], [[Tokelau]], [[Niue]], [[Nauru]] and [[Fiji]]. The Fiji Meteorological Services, as per agreement with the International Civil Aviation Organization, functions as the Meteorological Watch Office for the Nadi Flight Information Region (FIR), which extends from Western [[Kiribati]] to [[Tuvalu]], [[Fiji]], [[Vanuatu]], [[Wallis and Futuna]] and [[New Caledonia]]. However, it still provides certain aviation forecast services to Cook Islands, Christmas Island (Line Islands), [[Samoa]], [[Niue]] and [[Tonga]] which are situated outside the Nadi FIR boundary. Aviation products issued by FMS include [[Terminal Aerodrome Forecast]]s (TAF), [[Trend Type Forecast]]s (TTF), Area Forecasts, Route Forecasts, Inclement Weather Warnings for Nadi and Nausori Airports, Sigmets and Tropical Cyclone Advisories (TCA). Routine 24 hour TAF's are issued for Nadi (NFFN), Nausori (NFNA), Rarotonga (NCRG), Fuamotu (NFTF), Vavau (NFTV), Faleolo (NFSA), Niue, Tarawa (NGTA), and Christmas Island (PLCH) airports. 24 hour TAF's are also issued for Funafuti (NGFU) airport on certain days. TAF's (validity periods of less than 24 hours) are also issued for Aitutaki (NCAI), Manihiki (NCMH), Penrhyn (NCPY), Haapai (NFTL), Labasa (NFNL) and Rotuma (NFNR) airports.
==Tropical Cyclone Products Issued by FMS== Special Weather Bulletins (SWB's), Tropical Disturbance Advisories (TDA's), Special Advisory for [[Samoa]], Tropical Cyclone Advisories (TCA's), Tropical Cyclone Sigmets, CREX bulletins, International Marine Warnings associated with tropical cyclones (WTPS and WHPS) and Tropical cyclone forecast and uncertainty tracks are the tropical cyclone products issued by FMS.
==See also== {{Portal|Fiji}} *[[{{#ifexpr:{{#time:n}}>6|{{#time:Y}}–{{#time:y|+1 year}}|{{#time:Y|-1 year}}–{{#time:y}}}} South Pacific cyclone season]] *[[Meteorological Service of New Zealand Limited]] *Australian [[Bureau of Meteorology]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.met.gov.fj/ Fiji Meteorological Service]
{{National Meteorological Organisations}}
[[Category:Governmental meteorological agencies in Oceania]] [[Category:Geography of Fiji]] [[Category:Government agencies of Fiji]] [[Category:Regional Specialized Meteorological Centres]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox islands | name = Dominica | image_name = Dominica.png | image_caption = Map of Dominica | image_size = | map_image = LocationDominica.png | map_caption = | native_name = | native_name_link = | nickname = ''Nature Isle of the Caribbean'' | location = [[Caribbean Sea]] | coordinates = {{coord|15|25|N|61|20|W|display=inline,title}} | archipelago = [[Windward Islands]] | total_islands = | major_islands = | area_km2 = 751 | length_km = 47 | width_km = 29 | coastline_km = 148 | highest_mount = [[Morne Diablotins]] | elevation_m = 1447 | country = Dominica | country_admin_divisions_title = | country_admin_divisions = | country_admin_divisions_title_1 = | country_admin_divisions_1 = | country_admin_divisions_title_2 = | country_admin_divisions_2 = | country_largest_city = [[Roseau]] | country_largest_city_population = 14,847 | population = 71,727 | population_as_of = 2003 | density_km2 = 95.51 | ethnic_groups = [[African diaspora|Black]] 90%, [[Mulatto]], 8 % Carib-[[Amerindian]] 2% | additional_info = }} [[Dominica]] is an [[island]] in the [[Caribbean Sea]], located about halfway between the French islands of [[Guadeloupe]] (to the north) and [[Martinique]] (to the south). Its coordinates are 15 25 N, 61 20 W. It is known as "The Nature Island of the Caribbean" due to its spectacular, lush, and varied flora and fauna, which is protected by an extensive natural park system. It is the fourth largest island in the Eastern Caribbean with a population of people mainly from African descent. The lowest point in the country is at [[sea level]] along the coast, and the highest is [[Morne Diablotins]] ({{convert|1447|m|ft|0|abbr=on|disp=or}}). The extreme southwestern coast of the island includes a large collapsed submarine caldera. Portions of the exposed rim of this caldera form the southwestern tip of the island at Scott's Head. Natural resources include [[farming]], [[hydropower]] and [[timber]]. Geographically, Dominica is distinctive in many ways. The country has one of the most rugged landscapes in the Caribbean, covered by a largely unexploited, multi-layered rain forest. It is also among the Earth's most rain-drenched lands, and the water runoff forms cascading rivers and natural pools. The island, home to rare species of wildlife, is considered by many as a beautiful, unspoiled tropical preserve. According to a popular West Indian belief, Dominica is the only New World territory that Columbus would still recognize. Dominica is the largest and most northerly of the [[Windward Islands]]. The island faces the Atlantic Ocean to the east and the Caribbean Sea to the west. Its nearest neighbors are the French islands of Guadeloupe, some {{convert|48|km|mi|0}} north, and Martinique, about {{convert|40|km|mi|0}} south. Oblong-shaped and slightly smaller than New York City, Dominica is {{convert|750|km2|sqmi|0}} in area, {{convert|47|km|mi|0}} in length, and {{convert|29|km|mi|0}} in width. Roseau, the nation's capital and major port, is favorably situated on the sheltered, southwestern coast. ==Climate== The island's [[climate]] is tropical, moderated by northeast [[trade winds]] and heavy [[rain]]fall. Dominica has a [[tropical rainforest climate]] and some areas bordering on a [[tropical monsoon climate]] with characteristically warm temperatures and heavy rainfall. Excessive heat and humidity are tempered somewhat by a steady flow of the northeast trade winds, which periodically develop into hurricanes during the Northern Hemisphere's summer. The steep interior slopes also alter temperatures and winds. Because of the moderating effects of the surrounding ocean temperature ranges are slight. Average daytime temperatures generally vary from {{convert|26|°C|1}} in January to {{convert|32|°C|1}} in June. Diurnal ranges are usually no greater than {{convert|3|C-change|1}} in most places, but temperatures dipping to {{convert|13|°C|1}} on the highest peaks are not uncommon. Most of the island's ample supply of water is brought by the trade winds. Although amounts vary with the location, rain is possible throughout the year, with the greatest monthly totals recorded from June through October. Average yearly rainfall along the windward east coast frequently exceeds {{convert|5000|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}, and exposed mountainsides receive up to {{convert|9000|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}, among the highest accumulations in the [[Caribbean]] and the world. Totals on the leeward west coast, however, are only about {{convert|1800|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} per year. Humidities are closely tied to rainfall patterns, with the highest values occurring on windward slopes and the lowest in sheltered areas. Relative humidity readings between 70 percent and 90 percent have been recorded in Roseau. Hurricanes and severe winds, most likely to occur during the wettest months, occasionally are devastating. The most recent hurricanes of note were [[Hurricane David|David and maria]] and [[Hurricane Frederic|Frederic]] in August 1979 and [[Hurricane Allen|Allen]] in August 1980. The 1979 hurricanes caused over 40 deaths, 2,500 injuries, and extensive destruction of housing and crops. Many agricultural commodities were destroyed during the 1980 storm, and about 25 percent of the banana crop was destroyed by strong winds in 1984. Dominica is especially vulnerable to hurricanes as the island is located in what is referred to as the [[hurricane]] region. In 1979, Dominica was hit directly by [[Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 5]] [[Hurricane David]], causing widespread and extreme damage. On August 17, 2007, [[Hurricane Dean]], a [[Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 1]] at the time, hit the island. A mother and her seven-year-old son died when a [[landslide]] caused by the heavy rains fell onto their house.{{cite news | title = Hurricane Dean Gains Caribbean Strength | author = Jonathan Katz | publisher = [[Associated Press]] | url = https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2007/08/18/ap4033014.html | date = 2007-08-18 | accessdate = 2007-08-18}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In another incident two people were injured when a tree fell on their house.{{cite web|date=2007-08-17 |title=Hurricane claims one life in St. Lucia and possibly two in Dominica |publisher=CBC |accessdate=2007-08-17 |url=http://www.cbc.bb/content/view/12195/45/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070828065016/http://www.cbc.bb/content/view/12195/45/ |archivedate=2007-08-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Prime Minister of Dominica|Prime Minister]] [[Roosevelt Skerrit]] estimated that 100 to 125 homes were damaged, and that the agriculture sector was extensively damaged, in particular the banana crop.{{cite web|date=2007-08-17 |title=Dominica Badly Affected |publisher=CBC |accessdate=2007-08-17 |url=http://www.cbc.bb/content/view/12195/45/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070828065016/http://www.cbc.bb/content/view/12195/45/ |archivedate=2007-08-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Below is the climate data for Roseau, the capital city located on the western side of Dominica partially shielded from the trade winds by the mountains. {{Weather box |location = Roseau |metric first = yes |single line = yes |Jan record high C = 33 |Feb record high C = 34 |Mar record high C = 36 |Apr record high C = 36 |May record high C = 36 |Jun record high C = 36 |Jul record high C = 35 |Aug record high C = 35 |Sep record high C = 35 |Oct record high C = 37 |Nov record high C = 35 |Dec record high C = 34 |year record high C = 37 |Jan high C = 28.0 |Feb high C = 28.0 |Mar high C = 28.4 |Apr high C = 29.1 |May high C = 29.6 |Jun high C = 30.1 |Jul high C = 30.2 |Aug high C = 30.5 |Sep high C = 30.4 |Oct high C = 29.0 |Nov high C = 29.6 |Dec high C = 28.6 |year high C = 29.3 |Jan mean C = 24.9 |Feb mean C = 24.8 |Mar mean C = 25.1 |Apr mean [[NOAA]]{{cite web | url = ftp://ftp.atdd.noaa.gov/pub/GCOS/WMO-Normals/TABLES/REG_IV/DO/78905.TXT | title = Climate Normals for Melville Hall Airport 1961-1990 | publisher = National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration | accessdate = February 28, 2013}} |source 2 = BBC Weather {{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/3575635 | title = Average Conditions Roseau, Dominica | accessdate = February 28, 2013 | publisher = BBC Weather}} |date=August 2010 }} ==Bays== {{main article|List of bays of Dominica}} Bays are as follows from the northern tip of the island in a clockwise direction: [[Agoucha Bay]] [[Sandwich Bay (Dominica)|Sandwich Bay]] [[Grand Baptiste Bay]] [[Petit Bapitiste Bay]] [[La Taille Bay]] [[Rough Bay]] [[Marigot Bay (Dominica)|Marigot Bay]] [[Walker's Rest Bay]] [[Sophia Bay]] [[Londonderry Bay]] [[Mango Hole Bay]] [[Middle Bay (Dominica)|Middle Bay]] [[Panto Hole Bay]] [[Petite Soufriere Bay]] [[Soufriere Bay]] [[Woodbridge Bay]] [[Prince Rupert Bay]] [[Douglas Bay (Dominica)|Douglas Bay]] ==Geology== Dominica was the last island to be formed in the Caribbean. The island was created by volcanic action about 26 mya. It lies upon two opposing tectonic plates. This explains why an island a bit bigger than [[Martha's Vineyard]] has mountains approaching {{convert|5000|ft|0}}.{{cite book | author = Holahan, David |title = Rugged Dominica worth the ruined sneakers | publisher = Boston Globe | date = January 18, 2009}} Geologically, Dominica is part of the rugged Lesser Antilles volcanic arc. The country's central spine, a northwest-southeast axis of steep volcanic slopes and deep gorges, generally varies in elevation from {{convert|300|to|1400|m|0}} above sea level. Several east-west trending mountain spurs extend to the narrow coastal plain, which is studded with sea cliffs and has level stretches no wider than {{convert|2000|m|0}}. The highest peak is Morne Diablotins, at {{convert|1447|m|0}}; Morne Trois Pitons, with an elevation of {{convert|1423|m|0}}, lies farther south and is the site of the national park. The interior features rugged [[mountain]]s of [[volcano|volcanic]] origin. Volcanism is still quite evident on the island, the most popular examples being Dominica's [[Boiling Lake]] and "valley of desolation." The boiling lake (the world's second largest) is within a crater and is fed by a waterfall - the boiling is believed to be caused by the heat of a magma chamber beneath the lake. The valley of desolation is a sulfurous valley of volcanic vents and hot springs that inhibits significant plant growth - in stark contrast to the surrounding rain forest. Technically dormant today, this caldera last erupted in 1880. The area that exploded on 4 January 1880 was reported to be "fully nine square miles".''The Twillingate Sun'', February 10, 1881. [[File:Volcanic rock (Dominica).jpg|thumb|left|300px|Volcanic rock at Pagua Bay, Dominica]] Dominica's rugged surface is marked by its volcanic past. Rock formations are mainly volcanic andesite and rhyolite, with fallen boulders and sharp-edged protrusions peppering slope bases. The light- to dark-hued clayey and sandy soils, derived from the rocks and decomposed vegetation, are generally fertile and porous. Only a few interior valleys and coastal strips are flat enough for soil accumulations of consequence, however. Although scores of mostly mild seismic shocks were recorded in 1986, volcanic eruptions ceased thousands of years ago. Sulfuric springs and steam vents, largely concentrated in the central and southern parts of the island, remain active, however. One of the largest springs, Boiling Lake, is located in the national park. Dominica is water-rich with swift-flowing highland streams, which cascade into deep gorges and form natural pools and crater lakes. The streams are not navigable, but many are sources of hydroelectric power. Trafalgar Falls, located near the national park, is one of the most spectacular sites on the island. The falls has two twin waterfalls known as the mother and father. The falls form a natural pool where the natives and tourist come to enjoy a nice cool bath. The principal rivers flowing westward into the Caribbean are the Layou and the Roseau, and the major one emptying eastward into the Atlantic is the Toulaman. The largest crater lake, called Boeri, is located in the national park. There are 83 "significant" waterways on the island out of a total of 365 rills and brooks. ===Natural history=== There are 172 species of birds, including four species of [[hummingbird]], [[broad-winged hawk]]s, [[yellow-crowned night heron]]s, and the [[brown trembler]]. Some plants and animals thought to be extinct on surrounding islands can still be found in Dominica's forests.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} The [[imperial parrot|sisserou parrot]] is Dominica's national bird and is indigenous to its mountain forests. The [[Caribbean Sea]] offshore of the island of Dominica is home to many [[cetaceans]]. Most notably a small group of [[sperm whale]]s live in this area year round. These are shy animals, but there is a good chance of seeing them if you go out on a calm day. Other cetaceans commonly seen in the area include [[pilot whale]], [[Fraser's dolphin]], [[pantropical spotted dolphin]] and [[bottlenose dolphin]]. Less commonly seen animals include [[Cuvier's beaked whale]], [[false killer whale]], [[pygmy sperm whale]], [[dwarf sperm whale]], [[Risso's dolphin]], [[common dolphin]], [[humpback whale]] and [[Bryde's whale]]. This makes Dominica a destination for tourists interested in [[whale-watching]]. == Statistics == '''Map references:''' Central America and the Caribbean '''Area:'''
''total:'' [[1 E8 m2|751 km2]]
''land:'' 751 km2 '''Coastline:''' 148 km '''Maritime claims:'''
''territorial sea:'' {{convert|12|nmi|km mi|abbr=on|1}}
''contiguous zone:'' {{convert|24|nmi|km mi|abbr=on|1|lk=in}}
''exclusive economic zone:'' {{convert|200|nmi|km mi|abbr=on|1}} '''Land use:'''
''arable land:'' 8%
''permanent crops:'' 24%
''other:'' 68% (2012 est.) '''Irrigated land:''' NA km2 '''Total renewable water resources:''' NA '''Freshwater withdrawal (domestic/industrial/agricultural):'''
''total:'' 0.02 km3/yr
''per capita:'' 244.1 m3/yr (2004) '''Natural hazards:''' Flash floods are a constant threat; destructive hurricanes can be expected during the late summer months '''Environment - current issues:''' NA '''Environment - international agreements:'''
''Party to:'' [[Biodiversity]], Climate Change, [[Desertification]], Endangered Species, Environmental Modification, Hazardous Wastes, [[Law of the Sea]], Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, Whaling ==== Extreme points ==== * Northernmost point – [[Carib Point]] * Southernmost point – Coast southeast of [[Scotts Head, Dominica|Scotts Head]] * Westernmost point – Cape in the southwest of [[Saint John Parish, Dominica|Saint John Parish]] * Easternmost point – Cape in the southeast of [[Saint David Parish, Dominica|Saint David Parish]] * Highest point – [[Morne Diablotins]]: 1447 m * Lowest point – [[Caribbean Sea]]: 0 m ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} ==References== {{commons category|Geography of Dominica}} *{{loc}} *{{CIA World Factbook}} * http://www.dominica-weekly.com/trafalgar-falls/ * http://www.in-west-indies.com/dominica/discover/geography.htm{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcdominica.htm * http://www.thedominican.net/about/dominica.htm {{Geography of North America}} {{North America topic|Climate of}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Geography of Dominica}} [[Category:Geography of Dominica| ]]

revision.comment: Added reference
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2014}}
The '''geography of the [[Manila|City of Manila]]''' is characterized by its coastal position at the [[estuary]] of the [[Pasig River]] that flows to [[Manila Bay]]. The city is located on a naturally protected harbor, regarded as one of the finest harbors in Asia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.city-data.com/world-cities/Manila-Environment.html |title=Environment — Manila |publisher=City-Data |accessdate=February 26, 2017}}</ref> The scarce availability of land is a contributing factor that makes Manila the densest populated city in the world.
Almost all of the city sits atop of centuries of prehistoric [[alluvium|alluvial]] deposits built up by the Pasig River and on some land reclaimed from Manila Bay. The city's land has been altered substantially by human intervention, with considerable land reclamation along the waterfronts since the American colonial times. Some of the natural variations in topography have been evened out due to the urbanization of the city. Manila lies 800 miles (1,300 km) from mainland [[Asia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://geography.howstuffworks.com/asia/geography-of-manila.htm |title=Geography of Manila |publisher=[[HowStuffWorks]] |accessdate=2010-04-13}}</ref>
Before and during the [[Spanish colonization of the Philippines]], [[Manila]] was the provincial capital over a province whose territory at one time covered nearly all of Luzon, and included the modern territorial subdivisions of [[Pampanga]], [[Bulacan]], [[Rizal]], [[Laguna (province)|Laguna]], [[Batangas]], [[Quezon]], [[Mindoro]], [[Masbate]] and [[Marinduque]]. Later, these subdivisions were themselves made provinces, leaving Manila province with a territory roughly equal to the present City of Manila proper (except Intramuros, the capital site), and the northwestern two-thirds of Rizal province. The boundary of Manila province went from northeast to southwest, including [[Antipolo]], [[Cainta]], [[Taytay, Rizal|Taytay]] and [[Taguig]], and all of the towns north and west of them, in Manila province; and [[Angono]], [[Teresa, Rizal|Teresa]], [[Morong, Rizal|Morong]], and the towns south and east of them, in Laguna province. Early in the province's history, the provincial name was changed from Manila to [[Tondo Province]], by which it was known for most of the Spanish era.
In about 1853, four [[pueblo]]s or towns of Tondo Province were joined with the northeastern towns of Laguna province to form the politico-military ''Distrito de los Montes de San Mateo'', or District of the San Mateo Mountains. The Tondo Province annexed to this new district the towns of [[Cainta]], [[Taytay, Rizal|Taytay]], [[Antipolo]] and [[Boso-boso]], while Laguna contributed the towns of [[Angono]], [[Binangonan]], [[Cardona, Spain|Cardona]], [[Morong, Rizal|Morong]], [[Baras, Rizal|Baras]], [[Tanay, Rizal|Tanay]], [[Pililla]] and [[Jalajala]]. But the name of the new district proved unwieldy, too long, and misled many into thinking the town of [[San Mateo, Rizal|San Mateo]] (in Tondo province) was the capital of the San Mateo Mountain District, when in reality the district capital was in Morong. So, in 1859, following common practice of the day, the district was renamed after its capital; namely, Morong District. At about the same time, Tondo Province was renamed [[Manila Province]].
When the Spaniards turned over the Philippines to the hands of the Americans, a civil government was formed. In about the same period, the Manila Province was dissolved by the [[Philippine Commission]], and its pueblos were incorporated with those of the District of Morong, forming the new [[Rizal|Province of Rizal]]. A few weeks, a new charter for the City of Manila, defining its boundaries and annexing some of towns of the Province of Rizal to its districts. These boundaries were slightly revised and redefined on January 29, 1902 when the suburb of [[Gagalangin, Tondo|Gagalangin]] was annexed to the city district of Tondo, and the former pueblo of [[Santa Ana, Manila|Santa Ana]] was turned into a city district of Manila. On July 30 of the same year, the city board officially divided the city into 13 political subdivisions named as districts, and the boundaries of each were defined. On August 15 of the same year, the pueblo of [[Pandacan, Manila|Pandacan]] was annexed as a city district. Since then the boundaries and city districts of Manila have remained essentially the same.
During World War II, the city of Manila was declared an open city and its administrative boundaries expanded to outlying cities and municipalities. It was called the '''Greater Manila''' and included districts such as ''Bagumbayan'' means New Town (South of Manila), ''Bagumpanahon'' means "New Era" (Sampaloc, Quiapo, San Miguel and Santa Cruz), ''Bagumbuhay'' means "New Life" (Tondo), ''Bagong Diwa'' means "New Order" (Binondo & San Nicholas), the then newly established [[Quezon City]] was collapsed and divided into two districts, while the municipalities of [[Caloocan City|Caloocan]], [[Las Piñas City|Las Piñas]], [[Malabon City|Malabon]], [[Makati City|Makati]], [[Mandaluyong City|Mandaluyong]], [[Navotas City|Navotas]], [[Parañaque City|Parañaque]], [[Pasay City|Pasay]], and [[San Juan, Metro Manila|San Juan]] became districts of Manila.
==City Plan==
<gallery mode=packed style="font-size:88%; line-height:130%"> File:Plano de Manila 1851.jpg|The ''Plano de Manila'' in 1851 that shows the layout of the historic walled area of ''[[Intramuros]]'' File:BurnhamPlanOf-Manila.jpg|The Plan of Manila by [[Daniel Burnham]] in 1905 includes the towns and suburbs beyond the Walled City as part of the City of Manila File:Unofficial Manila Map.jpg|Unofficial Map of the City of Manila produced by the City Planning and Development Office File:Comprehensive Land Use Plan of the City of Manila.JPG|The 2006-2020 Comprehensive Land Use Plan of the City of Manila File:Existing Land Use Map of Manila 2017.jpg|Existing Land Use Map of the City of Manila File:Ph map manila large.png|Map of the City of Manila showing points of interests </gallery>
==See also== {{Portal|Manila}} * [[Luzon]] * [[Geography of the Philippines]] * [[Kingdom of Tondo]] * [[Greater Manila Area]] * [[Mega Manila]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Manila}} {{Metro Manila}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Geography Of Manila}} [[Category:Geography of Manila|*]]

revision.comment: /* top */John Hopkins to Johns Hopkins, replaced: John Hopkins → Johns Hopkins
revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} [[File:Pluto-01 Stern 03 Pluto Color TXT.jpg|thumb|High-resolution [[New Horizons#Ralph telescope|MVIC]] view of Pluto in enhanced color, illustrating variations in surface composition]] The '''geology of Pluto''' consists of the characteristics of the surface, crust, and interior of [[Pluto]]. Because of Pluto's distance from Earth, in-depth study from Earth is difficult. Many details about Pluto remained unknown until 14 July 2015, when ''[[New Horizons]]'' flew through the Pluto system and began transmitting data back to Earth. When it did, Pluto was found to have remarkable geologic diversity, with ''New Horizons'' team member Jeff Moore saying that it "is every bit as complex as that of Mars".{{cite web | url=http://astronomy.com/news/year-of-pluto/2015/09/new-pluto-images-from-nasas-new-horizons-show-complex-terrain | title=New Pluto images from NASA’s New Horizons show complex terrain | date=10 September 2015 | publisher=Astronomy | accessdate=29 June 2018 }} The final ''New Horizons'' Pluto data transmission was received on 25 October 2016.{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=No More Data From Pluto |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/29/science/pluto-nasa-new-horizons.html |date=28 October 2016 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=3 December 2016 }}{{cite web | url=http://pluto.jhuapl.edu/News-Center/News-Article.php?page=20161027 | title=Pluto Exploration Complete: New Horizons Returns Last Bits of 2015 Flyby Data to Earth | date=27 October 2016 | publisher=Johns Hopkins Applied Research Laboratory | accessdate=3 December 2016 }} == Surface == {{see also|Geography of Pluto}} [[File:Pluto by LORRI, 11 July 2015.jpg|thumb|150px|left|
Polygonal feature north of the dark equatorial regions on Pluto
(11 July 2015)
]] [[File:Pluto-Map-Annotated.jpg|thumb|The portions of Pluto's surface mapped by ''New Horizons''. Center is 180 degrees longitude (diametrically opposite the moon Charon).]] Pluto's surface is composed of more than 98 percent [[solid nitrogen]], with traces of [[methane]] and [[carbon monoxide]]. The face of Pluto oriented toward Charon contains more solid methane,{{cite web |last=Lewin |first=Sarah |title=Pluto's 'Skyscrapers': What's Responsible for Dwarf Planet's Giant Ice Blades |url=https://www.space.com/38281-pluto-giant-ice-blades-explained.html |date=27 September 2017 |work=[[Space.com]] |accessdate=27 September 2017 }} whereas the opposite face contains more nitrogen and solid carbon monoxide. Distribution of volatile ices is thought to be season-dependent and influenced more by solar insolation and topography than subsurface processes.{{Cite journal|last=Bertrand|first=T|last2=Forge|first2=F|date=2016|title=Observed glacier and volatile distribution on Pluto from atmosphere-topography processes|journal=Nature|volume=2016; 000}} Maps produced from images taken by the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] (HST), together with Pluto's light curve and the periodic variations in its infrared spectra, indicate that Pluto's surface is very varied, with large differences in both brightness and color, with albedos between 0.49 and 0.66. Pluto is one of the most contrastive bodies in the Solar System, with as much contrast as [[Saturn]]'s moon [[Iapetus (moon)|Iapetus]]. The color varies between charcoal black, dark orange and white. Pluto's color is more similar to that of [[Io (moon)|Io]] with slightly more orange, significantly less red than [[Mars]]. ''New Horizons'' found that Pluto's surface age is equally variable, with ancient, dark, mountainous terrain (such as Cthulhu) being found alongside the bright, flat, effectively craterless Sputnik Planitia and various terrains of intermediate age and color. Pluto's surface color has changed between 1994 and 2003: the northern polar region has brightened and the southern hemisphere has darkened. Pluto's overall redness has also increased substantially between 2000 and 2002. These rapid changes are probably related to seasonal condensation and [[sublimation (phase transition)|sublimation]] of portions of Pluto's [[Atmosphere of Pluto|atmosphere]], amplified by Pluto's extreme [[obliquity|axial tilt]] and high [[orbital eccentricity]]. {{multiple image |caption_align=center |align=center |width= |direction=horizontal |header= |image1=PIA20154-Pluto-MapOfOver1000Craters-20151110.jpg |caption1=Distribution of over 1000 craters of all ages on Pluto. The variation in density indicates a long history of varying geological activity. |width1=350 |image2=Pluto's Sputnik Planum geologic map (cropped).jpg |caption2=Geologic map of Sputnik Planitia and surroundings ([[c:File:Pluto's Sputnik Planum geologic map - context.jpg|context]]), with convection cell margins outlined in black |width2=298 }} ===Soft-ice plains and glaciers=== [[Sputnik Planitia]] appears to be composed of ices more volatile, softer and more dense than the water-ice bedrock of Pluto, including [[solid nitrogen|nitrogen]], carbon monoxide and solid methane.{{cite web | url = http://www.planetary.org/blogs/emily-lakdawalla/2015/12211538-pluto-updates-from-agu.html | title = Pluto updates from AGU and DPS: Pretty pictures from a confusing world | last = Lakdawalla | first = Emily | author-link=Emily Lakdawalla | date =2015-12-21 | publisher = [[The Planetary Society]] | access-date = 2016-01-24}} A polygonal [[convection cell]] structure is visible over much of the planitia. No craters have been found, indicating that its surface must be less than 10 million years old.{{cite journal|last1=Marchis|first1=F.|last2=Trilling|first2=D. E.|title=The Surface Age of Sputnik Planum, Pluto, Must Be Less than 10 Million Years|journal=PLOS ONE|volume= 11|issue=1|date= 2016-01-20|pages= e0147386|doi= 10.1371/journal.pone.0147386|arxiv = 1601.02833 |bibcode = 2016PLoSO..1147386T|pmid=26790001|pmc=4720356}} A number of mechanisms are proposed to explain the absence of craters including [[Cryovolcano|cryovolcanism]] (volcanoes erupting [[volatiles]] instead of magma), convective overturn, and [[Viscosity|viscous]] relaxation - processes that would erase negative topography. Glaciers of what is probably solid nitrogen can be seen flowing from the planitia into adjacent depressions and craters. Nitrogen from the plain appears to have been carried via the atmosphere and deposited in a thin layer of ice on uplands to the east and south of the plain, forming the large bright eastern lobe of [[Tombaugh Regio]]. Glaciers appear to be flowing back into the planitia through valleys from these eastern highlands. {{multiple image |caption_align=center |align=center |width= |direction=horizontal |header= |image1=NH-Pluto-FrozenCarbonMonoxide-20150714.jpg |caption1=Localization of frozen [[carbon monoxide]] in Sputnik Planitia (shorter contours represent higher concentrations). |width1=300 |image2=Troughs in Sputnik Planum by LORRI - crop of PIA19936.jpg |caption2=Polygonal ice patterns in southern Sputnik Planitia ([[c:File:PIA19936 crop - context for Troughs in Sputnik Planum by LORRI.jpg|context]]) due to convection. Dark spots in the troughs at lower left are pits.{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=Pluto terrain yields big surprises in New Horizons images |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/18/science/space/pluto-terrain-yields-big-surprises-in-new-horizons-images.html |date=17 July 2015 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=17 July 2015 }} |width2=170 |image3=Pluto-puzzling-pits-2.png |caption3=Closeup view of sublimation pits ([[c:File:PIA19936 crop Pluto-puzzling-pits context.jpg|context]]) in Sputnik Planitia |width3=114 |image4=PIA20151-Pluto-PitsInSputnikPlanum-20151110.jpg |caption4=Additional views of Sputnik Planitia sublimation pits ([[c:File:PIA19936 crop - context for Sputnik Planum pits images - PIA20151.jpg|context]]); some (left image) have dark material within |width4=250 }} {{Gallery| align=center |width=210 |File:Flowing nitrogen ice on Pluto.jpg|The northern edge of Sputnik Planitia ([[c:File:PIA19936 crop - Flowing nitrogen ice on Pluto context.jpg|context]]), with indications of [[nitrogen]] ice flowing into and filling adjacent depressions. |File:Nh-3flow-detail-annotated-9-17-15.jpg|Nitrogen ice [[glacier]]s flow from uplands through valleys into east Sputnik Planitia ([[c:File:PIA19936 crop - context for Valley Glaciers on Pluto, PIA19944.jpg|context]]). Arrows indicate valley sides (which are 3 to 8 km apart) and the flow front in the planitia. |File:PIA19943 - Intricate Valley Glaciers in Sputnik Planum, annotated.jpg|Nitrogen ice glaciers flowing into the eastern margin of the planitia (similar reprojected backlit view highlighting flow lines). }} ===Water-ice mountains=== Mountains several kilometres high have been found along the southwestern and southern edges of Sputnik Planitia. Water ice is the only ice detected on Pluto that is strong enough at Plutonian temperatures to support such heights. {{Gallery|align=center |width=210 |File:PIA20374-Pluto-NewHorizons-WaterIce-20150714.jpg|Pluto - water ice distribution (false color; rel 29 January 2016 |File:NH-Pluto-WaterIceDetected-BlueRegions-Released-20151008.jpg|Regions where water ice has been detected (blue regions) |File:NH-Pluto-SputnikPlanum-HillaryMontes-NorgayMontes-20150714.jpg|[[Hillary Montes]] and [[Tenzing Montes]] lie between Sputnik Planitia (top) and Cthulhu Regio (bottom).{{cite web |last=Gipson |first=Lillian |title=New Horizons Discovers Flowing Ices on Pluto |url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/new-horizons-discovers-flowing-ices-on-pluto |date=24 July 2015 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=24 July 2015 }} }} ===Ancient cratered terrain=== [[Cthulhu Regio]] and [[Brass Knuckles (Pluto)|other dark areas]] have many craters and signatures of solid methane. The dark red color is thought to be due to [[tholin]]s falling out of Pluto's atmosphere. ===Northern latitudes=== The mid-northern latitudes display a variety of terrain reminiscent of the surface of [[Triton (moon)|Triton]]. A polar cap consisting of solid methane "diluted in a thick, transparent slab of solid nitrogen" is somewhat darker and redder.{{cite web | title = Solar System Exploration: Multimedia: Gallery: Planetary Images: Pluto: The Ice Plot Thickens |publisher=NASA | url = http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/multimedia/display.cfm?Category=Planets&IM_ID=20257 | accessdate = 2015-08-11 }} {{Gallery|align=center |width=210 |File:NH-Pluto-MethaneIce-20150715.png|Distribution of methane ice on Pluto. Bright green is the polar cap; bright red is [[Balrog Regio]]. |File:NH-Pluto-MethaneIce-20150924.jpg|Map of methane ice abundance, which shows striking regional differences. Stronger methane absorption indicated by the brighter purple colors here, and lower abundances shown in black. |File:NH-07-10-15-Pluto-FirstGeology-20150709.jpg|Indications of complex geological features north of the dark equatorial regions }} ===Tartarus Dorsa=== [[File:Snakeskin terrain covering Tartarus Dorsa.png|thumb|right|Snakeskin terrain formed by penitentes covering Tartarus Dorsa.]] The western part of Pluto's northern hemisphere consists of an extensive, highly distinctive set of 500-meter-high mountains informally named Tartarus Dorsa; the spacing and shape of the mountains looks similar to scales or tree bark. These icy ridges were identified as [[penitente (snow formation)|penitentes]] in a January 2017 [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] paper by Dr. John Moores and his colleagues.{{cite journal|last1=Moores|first1=John E.|last2=Smith|first2=Christina L.|last3=Toigo|first3=Anthony D.|last4=Guzewich|first4=Scott D.|title=Penitentes as the origin of the bladed terrain of Tartarus Dorsa on Pluto|journal=Nature|date=4 January 2017|volume=541|issue=7636|pages=188–190|doi=10.1038/nature20779|pmid=28052055|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v541/n7636/pdf/nature20779.pdf|arxiv = 1707.06670 |bibcode = 2017Natur.541..188M }} Penitentes are icy depressions formed by erosion and surrounded by tall spires. Pluto is the only planetary body other than Earth on which penitentes have been identified. Although penitentes have been hypothesized on Jupiter's satellite [[Europa (moon)|Europa]], current theories suggest they may require an atmosphere to form. Moores and his colleagues hypothesize that Pluto's penitentes grow only during periods of high atmospheric pressure, at a rate of approximately 1 centimeter per orbital cycle. These penitentes appear to have formed in the last few tens of millions of years, an idea supported by the sparsity of craters in the region, making Tartarus Dorsa one of the youngest regions on Pluto. Cutting through both Tartarus Dorsa and Pluto's heavily cratered northern terrain (and thus formed more recently than both) is a set of six canyons radiating from a single point; the longest, informally named Sleipnir Fossa, is over 580 kilometers long. These chasms are thought to have originated from pressures caused by material upwelling at the center of the formation.{{cite web|editor-last=Talbert|editor-first=Tricia|url=http://www.nasa.gov/feature/icy-spider-on-pluto|title=Icy ‘Spider’ on Pluto|publisher=NASA|date=8 April 2016|accessdate=23 February 2017}} ===Possible cryovolcanism=== When ''New Horizons'' first sent back data from Pluto, Pluto was thought to be losing hundreds of tons of its atmosphere an hour to ultraviolet light from the Sun; such an escape rate would be too great to be resupplied by comet impacts. Instead, nitrogen was thought to be resupplied by either [[cryovolcano|cryovolcanism]] or geysers bringing it to the surface. Images of structures that imply upwelling of material from within Pluto, and streaks possibly left by geysers, support this view.{{cite web| title= Scientists study nitrogen provision for Pluto's atmosphere| publisher=phys.org| date=2015-08-11|url=http://phys.org/news/2015-08-scientists-nitrogen-provision-pluto-atmosphere.html |accessdate=11 August 2015}} Subsequent discoveries suggest that Pluto's atmospheric escape was overestimated by several thousand times and thus Pluto could theoretically keep its atmosphere without geological assistance, though evidence of ongoing geology is still strong.http://pluto.jhuapl.edu/News-Center/News-Article.php?page=20151109 Two possible cryovolcanoes, provisionally named [[Wright Mons]] and [[Piccard Mons]], have been identified in topographic maps of the region south of [[Sputnik Planitia]], near the south pole. Both are over 150 km across and at least 4 km high, the tallest peaks known on Pluto at present. They are lightly cratered and thus geologically young, although not as young as Sputnik Planitia. They are characterized by a large summit depression and hummocky flanks. This represents the first time large potentially cryovolcanic constructs have been clearly imaged anywhere in the Solar System.{{cite web | url = http://pluto.jhuapl.edu/News-Center/News-Article.php?page=20151109 | title = At Pluto, New Horizons Finds Geology of All Ages, Possible Ice Volcanoes, Insight into Planetary Origins | date = 2015-11-09 | website = New Horizons News Center | publisher = The Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory LLC | access-date = 2015-11-09}}{{cite web | url = http://www.nature.com/news/icy-volcanoes-may-dot-pluto-s-surface-1.18756 | title = Icy volcanoes may dot Pluto's surface | last = Witze | first = A. | date = 2015-11-09 | website = Nature News and Comment | publisher = [[Nature Publishing Group]] | access-date = 2015-11-09}}{{cite web | url = http://www.space.com/31073-pluto-ice-volcano-mountains-photos.html | title = Icy Volcanoes May Erupt on Pluto | last = Redd | first = N. T. | date = 2015-11-09 | publisher = Space.Com | access-date = 2015-11-10}} {{multiple image |caption_align=center |align=center |width= |direction=horizontal |header=Pluto - possible [[cryovolcanoes]] |image1=PIA20361-Pluto-WrightMons-20150714.jpg |caption1=[[Wright Mons]] (overall context) |width1=340 |image2=Pluto possible cryovolcano - Wright Mons.jpg |caption2=Wright Mons, displaying its central depression ([[c:File:Pluto possible cryovolcano - Wright Mons.jpg|source image (context)]]) |width2=185 |image3=PIA20050-Pluto-IceVolcanoes-20151110.jpg |caption3=3D map showing Wright Mons (above) and Piccard Mons |width3=100 }} == Internal structure == [[File:Internal Structure of Pluto.jpg|thumb|182px|Pluto's theoretical structure{{unbulleted list|'''1.''' Frozen nitrogen|'''2.''' Water ice|'''3.''' Rock}}]] Pluto's density is {{val|1.87|u=g/cm3}}.[http://www.universetoday.com/13861/pluto/ Pluto – Universe Today] Because the decay of radioactive elements would eventually heat the ices enough for the rock to separate from them, scientists think that Pluto's internal structure is differentiated, with the rocky material having settled into a dense [[Core (geology)|core]] surrounded by a [[mantle (geology)|mantle]] of water ice. The diameter of the core is hypothesized to be approximately {{val|1700|u=km}}, 70% of Pluto's diameter. It is possible that such heating continues today, creating a subsurface [[ocean layer]] of liquid water and ammonia some {{nowrap|100 to 180 km}} thick at the core–mantle boundary. Studies based on ''New Horizon'''s images of Pluto reveal no signs of contraction (as would be expected if Pluto's internal water had all frozen and turned into [[ice II]]) and imply that Pluto's interior is still expanding, probably due to this internal ocean; this is the first concrete evidence that Pluto's interior is still liquid.{{cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2094848-pluto-must-have-liquid-ocean-or-itd-look-like-an-overripe-peach/|title=Pluto must have liquid ocean or it’d look like an overripe peach|last=Gearin|first=Conor|work=[[New Scientist]]|date=22 June 2016|accessdate=23 February 2017}}{{cite journal|last1=Hammond|first1=Noah P.|last2=Barr|first2=Amy C.|last3=Parmentier|first3=Edgar M.|title=Recent tectonic activity on Pluto driven by phase changes in the ice shell|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|date=2 July 2016|volume=43|issue=13|pages=6775–6782|doi=10.1002/2016GL069220|arxiv = 1606.04840 |bibcode = 2016GeoRL..43.6775H }} Pluto is proposed to have a thick water-ice lithosphere, based on the length of individual faults and lack of localized uplift. Differing trends in the faults suggest previously active tectonics, though its mechanisms remain unknown.{{cite journal|last1=Moore|first1=J. M.|last2=McKinnon|first2=W. B.|last3=Spencer|first3=J. R.|last4=Howard|first4=A. D.|last5=Schenk|first5=P. M.|last6=Beyer|first6=R. A.|last7=Nimmo|first7=F.|last8=Singer|first8=K. N.|last9=Umurhan|first9=O. M.|last10=White|first10=O. L.|last11=Stern|first11=S. A.|last12=Ennico|first12=K.|last13=Olkin|first13=C. B.|last14=Weaver|first14=H. A.|last15=Young|first15=L. A.|last16=Binzel|first16=R. P.|last17=Buie|first17=M. W.|last18=Buratti|first18=B. J.|last19=Cheng|first19=A. F.|last20=Cruikshank|first20=D. P.|last21=Grundy|first21=W. M.|last22=Linscott|first22=I. R.|last23=Reitsema|first23=H. J.|last24=Reuter|first24=D. C.|last25=Showalter|first25=M. R.|last26=Bray|first26=V. J.|last27=Chavez|first27=C. L.|last28=Howett|first28=C. J. A.|last29=Lauer|first29=T. R.|last30=Lisse|first30=C. M.|last31=Parker|first31=A. H.|last32=Porter|first32=S. B.|last33=Robbins|first33=S. J.|last34=Runyon|first34=K.|last35=Stryk|first35=T.|last36=Throop|first36=H. B.|last37=Tsang|first37=C. C. C.|last38=Verbiscer|first38=A. J.|last39=Zangari|first39=A. M.|last40=Chaikin|first40=A. L.|last41=Wilhelms|first41=D. E.|display-authors=10|title=The geology of Pluto and Charon through the eyes of New Horizons|journal=Science|date=18 March 2016|volume=351|issue=6279|pages=1284–1293|doi=10.1126/science.aad7055|arxiv = 1604.05702 |bibcode = 2016Sci...351.1284M }} The [[German Aerospace Center|DLR]] ''Institute of Planetary Research'' calculated that Pluto's density-to-radius ratio lies in a transition zone, along with Neptune's moon [[Triton (moon)|Triton]], between icy satellites like the mid-sized [[moons of Uranus]] and [[moons of Saturn|Saturn]], and rocky satellites such as Jupiter's [[Io (moon)|Io]]. Pluto has no magnetic field.{{cite web |title=X-ray Detection Sheds New Light on Pluto |url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/chandra/x-ray-detection-sheds-new-light-on-pluto.html |accessdate=3 December 2016 |date=14 September 2016 |author=NASA |work=nasa.gov}} {{clear}} ==See also== * [[List of geological features on Pluto]] == References == {{reflist | colwidth = 30em | refs = {{cite web |last1=Brown|first1=Dwayne |last2=Buckley|first2=Michael |last3=Stothoff |first3=Maria |title=January 15, 2015 Release 15-011 - NASA's New Horizons Spacecraft Begins First Stages of Pluto Encounter |url=http://www.nasa.gov/press/2015/january/nasa-s-new-horizons-spacecraft-begins-first-stages-of-pluto-encounter |date=15 January 2015 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=15 January 2015 }} {{cite journal | title = Surface Ices and the Atmospheric Composition of Pluto | first=Tobias C. |last=Owen | first2=Ted L. |last2=Roush | first3=Dale P. |last3=Cruikshank | display-authors=3 | first4=James L. |last4=Elliot | first5=Leslie A. |last5=Young | first6=Catherine |last6=de Bergh | first7=Bernard |last7=Schmitt | first8=Thomas R. |last8=Geballe | first9=Robert H. |last9=Brown | first10=Mary Jane |last10=Bartholomew | journal = Science | date = 1993 | volume = 261 | issue = 5122 | pages = 745–748 | doi = 10.1126/science.261.5122.745 | pmid = 17757212 | bibcode = 1993Sci...261..745O | jstor=2882241 }} {{cite news | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3077880/ | publisher = MSNBC | title = Pluto regains its place on the fringe | first=Alan |last=Boyle | date = 11 February 1999 | accessdate = 20 March 2007 }} {{cite journal | doi = 10.1088/0004-6256/139/3/1117 | first1=Marc W. |last1=Buie | first2=William M. |last2=Grundy | first3=Eliot F. |last3=Young | display-authors=3 | first4=Leslie A. |last4=Young | first5=S. revision.comment: added some links, removed that flag, double-stubbed it...
Remove unsourced material that contradicts the ISO 3166-2 standard (the topic of this article). Additional changes to match https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:MA
revision.text:
{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:MA''' is the entry for [[Morocco]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for Morocco, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for two levels of subdivisions: * [[regions of Morocco|12 regions]] * [[prefectures and provinces of Morocco|62 provinces and 13 prefectures]] Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|MA}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Morocco. The second part is either of the following: * two digits (01–12): regions * three letters: provinces and prefectures The codes for the regions are assigned roughly from north to south. ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' ===Regions=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! replaced working paper with published result
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2009}}
'''Integrated assessment modelling''' ('''IAM''') or '''integrated modelling''' ('''IM'''){{efn|This second shortened version is used in the 2014 [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report]].<ref name="clarke-etal-2014"> {{cite book | first1 = Leon | last1 = Clarke | first2 = Kejun | last2 = Jiang | display-authors = etal | editor = IPCC | year = 2014 | title = Climate change 2014: mitigation of climate change. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change | chapter = Chapter 6: Assessing transformation pathways | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | place = Cambridge, UK and New York, NY, USA | isbn = 978-1-107-65481-5 | url = http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg3/ipcc_wg3_ar5_full.pdf | access-date = 2016-05-09 }}</ref> Note too the American spellings of '''integrated assessment modeling''' and '''integrated modeling'''.}} is a type of [[scientific modelling]] often used by the [[environmental sciences]] and [[environmental policy]] analysis. The modelling is '''integrated''' because environmental problems do not respect the borders between academic disciplines. Integrated assessment models therefore integrate knowledge from two or more domains into a single framework. Integrated modelling is referred to as '''assessment''' because the activity aims to generate useful information for policy making, rather than to advance knowledge for knowledge's sake. Integrated assessment modelling is that part of integrated assessment that relies on the use of numerical '''models'''.
Integrated assessment modelling has a long history, and scholars disagree on the first precedent. However, it became recognizable as a sub- or inter-discipline in the late 1980s with a focus on understanding and regulating [[acid rain|acidification]]. Integrated assessment modelling was further developed in the area of [[climate change]], inter alias in the context of the [[Energy Modeling Forum]].
Notable centres of integrated assessment modelling are [[IIASA]], [[MIT]], [[Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency]], and [[International Futures]]. Notable scholars are [[Barry B. Hughes]], [[William Nordhaus|Bill Nordhaus]], [[Robert O. Mendelsohn|Robert Mendelsohn]], [[Richard G. Richels|Rich Richels]], [[Michael Schlesinger]], [[Stephen Schneider]], [[Richard Tol]], [[John Weyant]], and [[Gary Yohe]].
== Interpretation ==
While the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) relies heavily on integrated modeling, [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report]] lead author Thomas Bruckner cautions against overinterpreting the results from such modeling.<ref name="bruckner-2016"> {{cite journal | first = Thomas | last = Bruckner | title = Decarbonizing the global energy system: An updated summary of the IPCC report on mitigating climate change | date = January 2016 | journal = Energy Technology | volume = 4 | issue = 1 | pages = 19–30 | doi = 10.1002/ente.201500387 | issn = 2194-4296 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ente.201500387/pdf | access-date = 2016-10-26 }} </ref> With regard to future technology choice, Bruckner observes that "The ''quantitative deployment'' of [[nuclear power]] or [[Carbon capture and storage|CCS]] technologies that has been found by the IPCC authors in the different mitigation scenarios, for instance, occasionally has been (mis)interpreted as an IPCC ''recommendation for their factual usage''."<ref name="bruckner-2016"/>{{rp|20}}{{nnbsp}}{{rp|at=emphasis per original}} Bruckner continues "The scale of deployment of low-carbon technologies shown in [IPCC] diagrams{{nbsp}}... reveals neither the ''possible contribution'' of the respective energy technology to GHG mitigation nor the ''required contribution''.{{nbsp}}... The possible contribution (without considering costs) might be higher whereas the strictly required one could be lower.<ref name="bruckner-2016"/>{{rp|20}}
== Criticism ==
Economist [[Robert Pindyck]] argues that IAMs are problematic and "close to useless as tools for policy analysis". He argues that "IAM-based analyses of [[Climate change policy of the United States|climate policy]] create a perception of knowledge and precision that is illusory, and can fool policy-makers into thinking that the forecasts the models generate have some kind of scientific legitimacy".<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Robert S. |last1=Pindyck |title=The Use and Misuse of Models for Climate Policy |journal=Review of Environmental Economics and Policy |volume=11 |issue=1 |year=2017 |pages=100–114 |doi=10.1093/reep/rew012 }}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Hartmut Bossel]]
== Notes == {{notelist}}
==References==
{{reflist|30em}}
== External links ==
* [https://web.archive.org/web/20080110233636/http://www.tias.uni-osnabrueck.de/ Integrated Assessment Society] * [http://journals.sfu.ca/int_assess/index.php/iaj Integrated Assessment Journal]
{{Energy modeling}}
[[Category:Climate change policy]] [[Category:Environmental science]] [[Category:Environmental social science]] [[Category:Scientific modeling]]

page.title: Line of succession to the former Austro-Hungarian throne

revision.comment: Undid revision 868405233 by [[Special:Contributions/Gyorgyvonhabsburg|Gyorgyvonhabsburg]] ([[User talk:Gyorgyvonhabsburg|talk]]) reverting self-advertising vandalism
revision.text:
{{Former monarchic orders of succession}} The dual monarchy of [[Austria-Hungary]] was abolished in 1918. The current Head of the [[House of Habsburg]] is [[Archduke]] [[Karl Habsburg-Lothringen|Karl]]. The succession law used is [[Order of succession#Agnatic succession|Semi-Salic]].<ref>{{cite book |title=[[Almanach de Gotha]] |year=1905 |publisher=[[Justus Perthes]] |edition=142 |page=658 }}</ref>
==History==
===Pragmatic Sanction=== {{Main article|Pragmatic Sanction of 1713}}
===Equal marriages=== During the monarchy and for a number of decades afterwards members of the House of Habsburg-Lorraine had to be born of an Imperially approved, [[Royal intermarriage|equal marriage]] to be deemed [[Dynasty#Dynasts|dynastic]], according to the Imperial Family's [[house law]] of 1839. On the authorization of the Emperor, that law was amended with addenda on 12 June 1900 (two weeks prior to a declaration to the Austrian and Hungarian legislatures of the morganatic nature of [[Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria|Archduke Franz Ferdinand]]'s impending marriage to [[Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg|Countess Sophie Chotek]]), requiring a spouse to belong to one of the following: the Imperial Family of Austria-Hungary, a currently or previously sovereign Christian dynasty, or a [[German Mediatisation|mediatised]] family. It further clarified the pool of eligible marital partners to include 1. a list of 32 mediatised, princely families, and 2. only members of the specified mediatized families who were born in compliance with their own family's equality of birth house law or who could prove 16 noble, knightly [[Quarters of nobility|quarterings]] (i.e., all great-great-grandparents) and beyond that at least 300 years of [[tournament]], [[fief]]-holding nobility in the paternal and maternal lines.<ref name=houselaw>Wien, Haus-, Hof- und Staatsarchiv. Familienstatut. Familienurkunden 1839, Daran geheftet und durch Hängesiegel damit verbunden: ''Authentische Interpretation des Tit. I § 1 des Familienstatuts von 1839'' ddo. 12. Juni 1900. Vienna. (German).</ref><ref name="petit">de Badts de Cugnac, Chantal. Coutant de Saisseval, Guy. ''Le Petit Gotha''. Nouvelle Imprimerie Laballery, Paris 2002, pp. 169-275. French. {{ISBN|2-9507974-3-1}}.</ref>
By the time of the marriage of Archduke Karl in 1993 to Baroness [[Francesca von Habsburg|Francesca Thyssen-Bornemisza]], who did not meet the old equality requirements, the rules regarding equal marriages had been relaxed<ref name="petit"/> (In 1953 [[Archduke Rudolf of Austria (1919–2010)|Archduke Rudolf]]'s marriage to Countess Xenia Tchernichev-Besobrasov and in 1976 that of another [[Archduke Carl Ludwig of Austria (1918–2007)#Family|Archduke Rudolf]] to Baroness Marie-Hélène de Villenfagne de Vogelsangck had been approved as dynastic).<ref name="enache">Enache, Nicolas. ''La Descendance de Marie-Therese de Habsburg''. ICC, Paris, 1996. pp. 46-47. (French). {{ISBN|2-908003-04-X}}</ref> Currently for a marriage to be dynastic all that is needed is the consent of the head of the house and a religious marriage.<ref name="petit"/> On 30 November 1990 the head of the house Crown Prince [[Otto von Habsburg|Otto]] recognized the title Count or Countess von Habsburg to the issue of [[morganatic marriage]]s contracted after the dynasty ceased to reign.<ref name="petit"/><ref name="ghda">''Genealogisches Handbuch des Adels, Fürstliche Häuser'' XVI. "Haus Österreich". C.A. Starke Verlag, 2001, pp. 87-90, 119-120, 563, 568-569, 577. {{ISBN|978-3-7980-0824-3}}.</ref> The descendants of archdukes whose wives had been of comital rank were retroactively integrated into the dynasty with traditional titles of Counts of Habsburg (e.g., the children and male-line descendants of Archduke Leo Karl {1893-1939} and his wife since 1922, Countess Maria-Klothilde von Thuillières von Montjoye-Vaufrey et de la Roche {1893-1978}),<ref name="ghda"/> except those of Archduke Clemens Salvatore of Austria-Tuscany (1904-1974) who, on 2 April 1930, had renounced his Tuscan succession rights and dynastic titles, receiving authorization from Crown Prince Otto for himself, his wife and male-line descendants to bear the title and name of Prince or Princess von Altenburg on 15 December 1949.<ref name="ghda"/>
===Archduchesses=== Although under the semi-salic succession law archduchess possess the right of succession when there are no males of any Habsburg-Lorraine branch left to succeed, during the monarchy (from 1719) upon marriage they renounced their succession rights to the Austro-Hungarian thrones in favor of the heiress of the last male ("Erbtochter" in German).<ref>{{cite news |title=Prince Weds Archduchess |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/02/11/100350177.pdf |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=11 February 1912 |accessdate=22 November 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.heraldica.org/topics/royalty/ps1713.htm#Renunciations The House Laws of the German Habsburgs, renunciations of archduchesses (Heraldica.org)]</ref>

{{about||a list of all F.C. Copenhagen players, major or minor|List of F.C. Copenhagen players|the current F.C. Copenhagen first-team squad|F.C. Copenhagen#Current squad}} The '''F.C. Copenhagen Player of the Year''' award is voted for annually by the members of the official [[fan club]] for [[F.C. Copenhagen]], FCKFC, in recognition of the best overall performance by an individual player throughout the [[Association football|football]] season. Towards the end of each season, members are invited to cast their votes for this award. The winner is the player who polls the most votes. The recipient is awarded a diploma, presented on the pitch before one of the last home games of the season. The inaugural award has existed as long as the club, and was given to [[Palle Petersen]] at the end of the club's first season. ==Winners== Player name in bold text represents players still on the playing staff of the club. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: left;" !style="width:6em"|Season!!Name{{cite web |url=http://fckfc2.net.dynamicweb.dk/Default.aspx?ID=113&M=ImageGallery&PID=324&Picture=yp2006_diplom.jpg |title=Årets spiller... |accessdate=2008-01-02 |year=2006 |publisher=F.C. Copenhagen Fan Club |language=Danish }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}!!Age!!Position{{efn|For a full description of positions see [[Football (soccer) positions|Football Positions]].}}!!Nationality!![[International Caps|International
Caps]]{{efn|If blank, uncapped at full international level.}}{{efn|As of 2017-05-29}}!!Current club |- | align=center|[[2016–17 F.C. revision.text:
[[File:Vegetables Malta.JPG|thumb|Some Maltese vegetable dishes]] The following is a '''list of dishes in [[Maltese cuisine]]'''.
==Appetizers== * Żebbuġ Mimli (pitted green olives stuffed with tuna mixture) * Fażola bajda bit-tewm u t-tursin (White beans with parsley, garlic and olive oil) * [[Ful medamesMalta|Ful bit-tewm]] * [[Bigilla]] (mashed "Tic beans "known in Malta as "Ful Ta' Ġirba" (Djerba beans)) * [[Galletti]] (Maltese [[Biscuit#food|biscuit]]) * [[Bebbux]] ([[Escargot#Preparation|escargot]])
==Soups== * [[Brodu]] (beef or chicken broth) * [[Minestra]] * [[Kusksu]] (vegetable soup with small pasta beads called ''kusksu'' and fresh [[broad bean]]s in season) * [[Soppa tal-armla]] (vegetable soup with fresh cheeselets and beaten eggs) * [[Aljotta]] (fish soup with plenty of garlic, herbs, and tomatoes) * [[Kawlata]] (cabbage and pork soup)
==Pasta and rice== [[Image:Maltese Timpana.JPG|thumb|right|A slice of timpana]] * [[Imqarrun]] (a [[Macaroni casserole#Malta|Macaroni casserole]] baked with bolognese style meat sauce and egg.) * [[Timpana]] * [[Ross il-forn]] (baked rice) * [[Għaġin Grieg]] (small pasta beads with minced pork and cheese) * [[Froġa tat-tarja]] (fried [[omelette]] with [[vermicelli]] pasta)
==Meat== * [[Stuffat tal-fenek]] ([[rabbit]] [[stew]]) * [[Fenek moqli]] (fried rabbit) * [[Braciola|Braġjoli]] * [[Laħam fuq il-fwar]] (steamed slices of [[beef]]) * [[Falda Mimlija]] (stuffed flank of [[pork]]) * [[Laħam taż-żiemel]] ([[Horse meat#Malta|stallion meat]], usually fried or baked in a white wine sauce) * [[Zalzett tal-Malti]] (a short, thick sausage made of pork, sea salt, black peppercorns, coriander seeds and parsley) * [[Mazzit]] (Maltese [[blood sausage]])
==Fish== [[Image:Malta grilled klamari 2.JPG|thumb|Grilled Calamari]] * [[Mahi-mahi|Lampuka]] * [[Stuffat tal-qarnit]] ([[Octopus#As food|octopus stew]]) * [[Qarnit bit-tewm]] (octopus with garlic) * [[Klamari mimlija]] (stuffed [[Squid (food)#Squid preparation|Calamari]]) * [[Pixxispad]] (fried [[Swordfish#Harvest|swordfish]])
==Eggs and cheeses== * [[Ġbejna]] (a small round cheese) * Froġa ([[omelette]] with [[ġbejna]], [[Vicia faba|broad beans]] or meat) * Balbuljata ([[Scrambled eggs|scrambled eggs cooked with tomatoes and onions]])
==Vegetables and sauces== [[File:Qargħa Bagħli Mimli (Stuffed marrows - Maltese Style).jpg|thumb|right|Qargħa Bagħli Mimli (Stuffed [[Marrow (vegetable)|marrows]])]] * [[Qarabagħli mimli]] (stuffed [[Courgette#Cooking|courgette]]) * [[Brunġiel mimli]] (stuffed [[Aubergine#Cooking|aubergine]]) * [[Bżar mimli]] ([[stuffed peppers]]) * Patata l-Forn (baked sliced [[potatoes]]) * [[Caponata|Kapunata]] * [[Aljoli (arjoli)]] (Maltese [[Aioli]] which contains no egg) * [[Qaqocc Mimli]] (stuffed [[artichokes]])
==Savoury pastries== [[Image:Malta Pastizzi.JPG|thumb|Pastizzi]] [[Image:Malta pie qassata.JPG|thumb|Spinach and Pea Qassata with salted tuna, anchovies and herbs]] * [[Torta tal-irkotta]] ([[ricotta]] pie) * [[Sfineġ]] (vegetable, fish or cheese [[fritters]]); * [[Pastizzi]] * [[Qassatat]] * [[Torti tar-ross u l-qargħa ħamra]] (rice and pumpkin pie)
==Bread== {{main|Maltese bread}} * [[Ħobża tal-Malti]] * [[Ftira]] (a Maltese [[flatbread]]) * [[Ħobż biż-żejt u t-tadam]] (bread with olive oil and tomato) * [[Ftira Għawdxija]]
==Sweets== [[Image:Qaghaq tal-hmira.jpg|thumb|right|Qagħaq tal-ħmira]] * [[Qagħaq tal-ħmira]] (soft sweet [[bagel]] shape cake with a hint of aniseed, topped with sesame seeds) * [[Imqaret]] (deep fried diamond-shaped pastry)<ref>Sweet Delights from a Thousand and One Nights: The Story of Traditional Arab Sweets, Habeeb Salloum, Muna Salloum, I.B.Tauris, Λονδίνο 2013, σελ. 132, {{ISBN|9781780764641}}</ref><ref>Proceedings of the First Congress on Mediterranean Studies of Arbo-Berber Influence, Micheline Galley, David R. Marshall, Société nationale d'édition et de diffusion, 1973</ref> * [[Cannoli|Kannoli tal-irkotta]] (ricotta filled fried crisp pastry tubes) * [[Ravjul moqli]] (sweet [[toasted ravioli]]) * [[Torti tat-tamal]] (date and cocoa tart) * [[Torti tal-marmorat]] (almond and chocolate pie) * [[Ħelwa tat-Tork]] (nut studded sesame seed and sugar [[halva]]) * [[Pudina tal-ħobż]] (baked [[bread pudding]] with raisins and cocoa powder) * [[Prinjolata]] (Carnival sweet, made of biscuit and sponge cake covered with frosting and decorated with glacè cherries and melted chocolate) * [[Kwareżimal]] (Lenten almond biscuit scented with the zest of orange, lemon and Maltese mixed spice, cinnamon and orange blossom) * [[Ftira tar-Randan]] (Lenten honey drizzled squares of crisp deep fried pastry) * [[Karamelli tal-ħarrub]] (Lenten hard candy flavoured with carob) * [[Figolla]] (Easter icing-coated biscuit stuffed with a mixture of sweet ground almonds called ''intrita'') * [[Ħobża ta' San Martin]] (sweet [[bread roll]], sweetened with [[Mastic (plant resin)#Use in food|mastic]] associated with [[Saint Martin's Day#Malta|Saint Martin's Day]]) * [[Qagħaq tal-għasel]] or tal-Qastanija (Christmas sweet rings made from a light pastry with a filling made of treacle, honey, semolina, citrus zest, cinnamon and cloves) * [[Għadam tal-mejtin]] (Pastry shaped in the form of a bone filled with almond paste) * [[Zeppole|Zeppoli]]
==Beverages== * [[Ceratonia siliqua#Traditional uses|Ġulepp tal-ħarrub]] (Carob Syrup) * [[Imbuljuta]] (Chestnut, Tangerine zest and Cocoa Drink) * [[Coffee|Kafè]] (coffee boiled with [[aniseed]], [[cinnamon sticks]] and/or [[rosewater]]) * [[Orgeat syrup|Ruġġata]] (a drink made from cinnamon, vanilla, bitter almonds, sugar, water and milk similar to Italian 'orzata') * [[Builder's tea|Te fit-Tazza]] (A local variety of Builder's Tea, traditionally served with condensed milk and sweetened in a glass) * [[Kinnie]] (A bittersweet soft drink) * [[Bajtra]] (a [[Opuntia ficus-indica|prickly pear]]-based liqueur)
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== {{portal|Malta|Food}} * {{commonscat-inline|Cuisine of Malta}}
{{Lists of prepared foods}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Maltese Dishes}} [[Category:Lists of foods by nationality]] [[Category:Malta-related lists|Dishes]] [[Category:Maltese cuisine|*]]

revision.text:
This is the list of the '''[[Border Guard]]''' agencies in different countries. Such agencies may also be known as ''Border Patrol'', ''Border Police'', ''Border Troops'', ''Frontier Guard'' or ''Frontier Police''. {{TOC right}}
==Asia==
==={{flagicon|Bangladesh}} Bangladesh=== * [[Border Guards Bangladesh]] - 67,000 personnel
==={{flagicon|China}} China=== * General Administration of Customs - Primary customs and excise agency. * [[Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Public Security]] - China Immigration Inspection * [[People's Armed Police]] - Border patrol and control functions in remote regions.
===={{flagicon|Hong Kong}} Hong Kong==== * [[Hong Kong Immigration Department]] * [[Customs and Excise Department (Hong Kong)|Hong Kong Customs & Excise]]
==={{flagicon|India}} India=== * [[Border Security Force]] – 245,000 personnel on the Pakistan and Bangladesh Border * [[Indo-Tibetan Border Police]] – 77,000 personnel * [[Rashtriya Rifles]] – 40,000 personnel in [[Kashmir]] * [[Special Frontier Force]] – 10,000 personnel primarily used for conducting clandestine intelligence gathering and commando operations along the India Chinese border. Officially constrained from operating within 10 km of the international border * [[Assam Rifles]] – 50,000 personnel organised into 46 battalions, an internal security force with secondary duties along the eastern borders. * [[Sashastra Seema Bal]] (SSB) 82,000 personnel on the Bhutan and Nepal borders
==={{flagicon|Iran}} Iran=== * [[Islamic Republic of Iran Border Guard Command|Border Guard Command]]
==={{flagicon|Israel}} Israel=== * [[Israel Border Police]]
==={{flagicon|Malaysia}} Malaysia=== * [[ Malaysian Immigration Department]] * [[Border Security Agency]] * [[Malaysia Maritime Enforcement Agency]]
==={{flagicon|Pakistan}} Pakistan=== * [[Pakistan Rangers]] * [[Frontier Corps]] * [[Gilgit Baltistan Scouts]] * [[Pakistan Coast Guard]] * [[Maritime Security Agency]] * [[Pakistan Customs]]
==={{flagicon|Singapore}} Singapore=== * [[Immigration and Checkpoints Authority]]
==={{flagicon|Turkey}} Turkey=== * [[General Directorate of Security|Department of Foreigners, Borders and Asylum]] * [[Gendarmerie (Turkey)|Border Gendarmerie]] * [[Turkish Coast Guard Command|Coast Guard Command]] * [[General Directorate of Customs Protection]]
==={{flagicon|Taiwan}} Taiwan=== * [[National Immigration Agency]] of the Ministry of the Interior of Taiwan Political Authority - Immigration and border security * [[Customs Administration]] of Ministry of Finance - handles customs
=== United Arab Emirates ===
* Critical Infrastructure & Coastal Protection Authority
==={{flagicon|Vietnam}} Vietnam=== * [[Vietnam Border Defence Force]]
==Europe==
==={{flagicon|European Union}} European Union=== * [[Frontex]]
==={{flagicon|Andorra}} Andorra=== * [[Police Corps of Andorra]]
==={{flagicon|Belarus}} Belarus=== * State Border Committee http://www.gpk.gov.by/
==={{flagicon|Bulgaria}} Bulgaria=== * [[Border Police (Bulgaria)|Bulgaria Border Police]]
==={{flagicon|Estonia}} Estonia=== * [[Politsei- ja Piirivalveamet|Police and Border Guard Board]] ({{lang-et|Politsei- ja Piirivalveamet}})
==={{flagicon|Finland}} Finland=== * [[Finnish Border Guard]]
==={{flagicon|France}} France=== * [[Directorate-general of customs and indirect taxes|Directorate-General of Customs and Indirect Taxes]] * [[Direction centrale de la police aux frontières]] * [[Gendarmerie Nationale (France)|Gendarmerie Nationale]]
==={{flagicon|Georgia}} Georgia=== * [[Ministry of Internal Affairs of Georgia|Patrol Police Department]] (border control)<ref>[http://police.ge/en/ministry/structure-and-offices/patrol-police-department?sub=375]</ref> * [[Border Police of Georgia]] (border supervision)
==={{flagicon|Germany}} Germany=== * [[German Federal Police]] (formerly known as the Bundesgrenzschutz from 1951-2005) * [[Bundeszollverwaltung]] (Federal Customs Service)
==={{flagicon|Ireland}} Ireland=== * [[Garda Síochána]]
==={{flagicon|Italy}} Italy=== * [[Polizia di Stato]] * [[Guardia di Finanza]]
==={{flagicon|Kyrgyzstan}} Kyrgyzstan=== * [[State Border Guard Service (Kyrgyz Republic)]]
==={{flagicon|Latvia}} Latvia=== * [[State Border Guard]]
==={{flagicon|Liechtenstein}} Liechtenstein=== * [[Landespolizei (Liechtenstein)#Structure|Border and Customs Unit]]
==={{flagicon|Lithuania}} Lithuania=== * [[State Border Guard Service (Lithuania)|State Border Guard Service]]
==={{flagicon|Moldova}} Moldova=== * [[Moldovan Border Police]]
==={{flagicon|Netherlands}} Netherlands=== * [[Royal Marechaussee]]
==={{flagicon|Norway}} Norway=== * [[Garnisonen i Sør-Varanger]]
==={{flagicon|Poland}} Poland=== * [[Border Guard (Poland)]] (Polish: Straż Graniczna)
==={{flagicon|Portugal}} Portugal=== * [[Serviço de Estrangeiros e Fronteiras]] Immigration and Border Service * [[National Republican Guard (Portugal)|Guarda Nacional Republicana]] (Unidade de Controlo Costeiro<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gnr.pt/legislacaoGNR/leiOrganica.pdf|title=Lei n.º 63/2007 - GNR|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>) Border Surveillance
==={{flagicon|Romania}} Romania=== * [[Romanian Border Police]] ({{lang-ro|Poliţia de Frontieră}})
==={{flagicon|Russia}} Russia=== * [[Border Guard Service of Russia]] (Russian: Пограничная служба России)
==={{flagicon|Spain}} Spain=== * [[Guardia Civil]]
==={{flagicon|Sweden}} Sweden=== * [[Swedish Police Authority]]
==={{flagicon|Switzerland}} Switzerland=== * [[Border Guard Corps]] (land borders and the airports of Basel (together with French Border police), Geneva and Lugano * [[Kantonspolizei Bern|Cantonal police of Berne]] (at Bern-Belp airport) * [[Kantonspolizei Zürich|Cantonal police of Zurich]] (at Zurich airport)
==={{flagicon|Tajikistan}} Tajikistan=== * [[Tajik Border Troops]]
==={{flagicon|Ukraine}} Ukraine=== * [[State Border Guard Service of Ukraine]] (Ukrainian: Державна Прикордонна Служба України)
==={{flagicon|United Kingdom}} United Kingdom=== * [[Border Force]]
===={{flagicon|Guernsey}} Guernsey==== * [[Guernsey Border Agency]]
===={{flagicon|Jersey}} Jersey==== * [[Customs & Immigration Service]]
==North America==
==={{flagicon|Canada}} Canada=== * [[Canada Border Services Agency]]
==={{flagicon|United States}} United States=== * [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]]
==Oceania==
==={{flagicon|Australia}} Australia=== * [[Australian Border Force]]
==={{flagicon|New Zealand}} New Zealand=== * [[Immigration New Zealand]] * [[New Zealand Customs Service]]
==South America==
==={{flagicon|Colombia}} Colombia=== * Migración Colombia
==Defunct agencies==
==={{flagicon|East Germany}} East Germany=== * [[Grenztruppen der DDR]]
==={{flagicon|Soviet Union}} Soviet Union=== * [[USSR Border Troops]]
==={{flagicon|Hungary}} Hungary=== * [[Border Guard (Hungary)|Border Guard]]
