revision.comment: /* External links */minor fixes
revision.text:
[[File:Potsdam Stadtblick 1871.jpg|thumb|300px|Historical view of the city with the [[Garrison Church, Potsdam|Garrison Church]], [[Stadtschloss (Potsdam)|Stadtschloss]] and St. Nicholas' Church in 1871]] [[File:Potsdam - Schloss Sanssouci mit Weinberg 2005 2.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Sanssouci]] Palace and the vineyard.]]
The following is a list of '''sights of [[Potsdam]]''', the capital of the German state of [[Brandenburg]] in [[Germany]].
== Sanssouci Park == The historic [[Sanssouci Park|park of Sanssouci]] covers an area of about 290 hectares and is thus the largest and best known in the March of Brandenburg. In the 18th and 19th centuries, [[Frederick II of Prussia|Frederick the Great]] and [[Frederick William IV of Prussia|Frederick William IV]] influenced the park in the contemporary architectural styles of [[Rococo]] and [[Classicism]] and had an artistic synthesis of architecture and gardens constructed, whose centrepiece is the vineyard terraces and the palace of Sanssouci that crowns them.
* [[Sanssouci Palace]] (built 1745 to 1747, symbol of the town) * [[New Palace (Potsdam)|New Palace]] (''Neues Palais'') (1763 to 1769) * [[Charlottenhof Palace]] (''Schloss Charlottenhof'') (1826 to 1829) * [[Orangery Palace]] (''Orangerieschloss''), also called the Orangery (''Orangerie'') or New Orangery (''Neue Orangerie'') (1851 to 1864) * [[New Chambers (Sanssouci)|New Chambers]] (''Neue Kammern'') (1771 to 1775) * [[Sanssouci Picture Gallery]] (''Bildergalerie'') (1755 to 1764) * [[Chinese House (Potsdam)|Chinese House]] (''Chinesisches Haus'') (1755 to 1764) * [[Church of Peace (Sanssouci)|Church of Peace]] (''Friedenskirche'') (1845 to 1848) * [[Antique Temple]] (''Antikentempel'') (1768/1769) * [[Temple of Friendship]] (''Freundschaftstempel'') (1768 to 1770) * [[Roman Baths (Potsdam)|Roman Baths]] (''Römische Bäder'') (1829 to 1840) * [[Belvedere on the Klausberg]] (''Belvedere auf dem Klausberg'') (1770 to 1772) * [[Dragon House (Sanssouci)|Dragon House]] (''Drachenhaus'') on the Klausberg (1770 to 1772) * [[Historic Mill of Sanssouci]] (1736 to 1739, first rebuilding begun 1790, destroyed during fighting in 1945, rebuilt in 1983 and from 1990 to 1993)'' * [[Neptune Grotto]] (''Neptungrotte'') (from 1751) * [[Green Gate, Potsdam|Green Gate]] (''Grünes Gitter'') at the park entrance * [[Botanical Garden, Potsdam]] * No longer accessible: The "Fort in the Park" of Sanssouci (1893). A model fort near the New Palace. Filled in since 2004. * Pheasantry (''Fasanerie'') * [[Bornstedt Crown Estate]], a former royal estate and nowadays a living history centre.
<Gallery> File:Potsdam Luftbild Neues Palais Schlösser westlich im Park Sanssouci Foto Wolfgang Pehlemann Wiesbaden IMG 0059.jpg|[[New Palace (Potsdam)|New Palace]] File:Potsdam Teehouse.jpg|[[Chinese House (Potsdam)|Chinese House]] File:Potsdam Drachenhaus.jpg|[[Dragon House (Potsdam)|Dragon House]] File:Römische Bäder Potsdam.jpg|[[Roman Baths (Potsdam)|Roman Baths]] </Gallery>
== New Garden == The New Garden (''Neuer Garten'') is a park, roughly 100 ha in area, that lies in the north of Potsdam and borders on the lakes of [[Heiliger See (Potsdam)|Heiliger See]] and the [[Jungfernsee]]. In 1787 [[Frederick William II of Prussia|Frederick William II]] had a new garden laid out on this site, hence the name. The park was intended to reflect the prevailing fashion for the [[English garden]], in contrast to the outmoded style of the [[Baroque]] ornamental and vegetable garden at Sanssouci.
* [[New Garden, Potsdam|New Garten]] (''Neuer Garten'') (laid out from 1787) * [[Marble Palace, Potsdam|Marble Palace]] (''Marmorpalais'') (1787 to 1792) * Palace kitchen, in the shape of a temple ruin (1788 to 1790) * Orangery (1791 to 1793) * Gothic Library (1792 to 1794) * Pyramids (1791 to 1792) * [[Dairy in the New Garden|Dairy]] (1790 to 1792) * [[Shell Grotto in the New Garden|Crystal and Shell Grotto]] (''Crystall- and Muschelgrotte'') (1791/92) * Dutch Quarter (''Holländisches Etablissement'') - houses in Dutch style * Garden houses: the White, Brown, Red and Green House * [[Cecilienhof Palace]] (''Schloss Cecilienhof'') (1914 to 1917)
<Gallery> File:Schloss Cecilienhof Panorama.jpg|[[Cecilienhof Palace]] File:Marmorpalais.jpg|[[Marble Palace]] File:Heiliger See.jpg|[[Heiliger See (Potsdam)|Heiliger See]] File:Gotische_Bibliothek.JPG|Gothic Library </Gallery>
== Babelsberg Park == [[File:Schloss Babelsberg.jpg|thumb|[[Babelsberg Palace]] on the Havel.]] Bordering the ''Tiefer See'' on the [[River Havel]] lies Babelsberg Park, covering an area of 114 hectares. In 1833, on the order of Prince William, later Emperor [[William I (German Empire)|William I]] and his wife, [[Augusta of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach|Augusta]] the landscape gardener, [[Peter Joseph Lenné]], and [[Hermann, Fürst von Pückler-Muskau|Prince Hermann of Pückler-Muskau]] began turning the rolling terrain that sloped down towards the lake into a park.
* [[Babelsberg Park]] ''(started 1833)'' * Royal Stables (''Marstall'') (1834 to 1839 and 1861) * [[Babelsberg Palace]] (1835 to 1849) * Little Palace (''Kleines Palace'') (1841/42) * Sailors' House (''Matrosenhaus'') (1842) * Steam-powered Pumping Station (''Dampfmaschinenhaus'') (1843 to 1845) * Flatow Tower (''Flatowturm'') (1853 to 1856) * Court Arcade (''Gerichtslaube'') (1871)
== Other parks and gardens == [[File:Freundschaftsinsel Potsdam Statue.jpg|thumb|Island of Friendship]]
* Island of Friendship (''Freundschaftsinsel'') in the centre of the city with the Karl Foerster perennial garden. * Karl Foerster Garden in Potsdam-Bornim with its private residence. * Pleasure Garden (''Lustgarten''), the oldest garden in Potsdam, originally part of the City Palace (''Stadtschloss'') site * Potsdam Municipal Park (''Volkspark Potsdam'') on the old 2001 ''[[Bundesgartenschau|Federal Garden Show]]'' site with the [[Potsdam Biosphere]], a commercially run park. * Potsdam Wildlife Park (''Wildpark'', 1834 to 1838), one of the oldest examples of the linkage of courtly tradition and landscape gardening. The wildlife park has an area of over 875 hectares and is located west of Sanssouci Park. * [[Bornstedt (Potsdam)|Bornstedt]] Cemetery, more-than-400-year-old park with Italian-like church. Amongst those buried here are [[Ferdinand von Arnim]], [[Peter Joseph Lenné]] and [[Ludwig Persius]].
== Palaces == :''For an overview of all palaces see [[List of castles in Berlin and Brandenburg#Potsdam|List of castles in Berlin and Brandenburg]]''
== Churches == The Prussian tolerance, which is highly visible in the city, is also expressed by Potsdam's churches: In the centre of Protestant Potsdam, stands a large Roman Catholic church, and the oldest Russian Orthodox Church in Germany is found here. Churches were built for settlers from various corners of Europe: the Swiss, French, Bohemians ...
* [[St. Nicholas' Church, Potsdam|St. Nicholas' Church]], (1830 to 1837). A giant domed building based on cathedrals in Rome, London and Paris, on the [[Old Market Square, Potsdam|Old Market Square]], consecrated in 1837, architects: [[Karl Friedrich Schinkel|Schinkel]], [[Ludwig Persius|Persius]] and [[Friedrich August Stüler|Stüler]]. * [[French Church, Potsdam|French Church]], (1752/1753). Based on the Roman Pantheon and built for French settlers, consecrated in 1753, builders: restored by [[Georg Wenzeslaus von Knobelsdorff|Knobelsdorff]], [[Johann Boumann|Boumann]], in the past years. * [[St. Peter and St. Paul's Church, Potsdam|Roman Catholic Priory Church of St. Peter and Paul]], (1867 to 1870). Like a campanile writ large, the church stands at the end of the Potsdam ''Bummelboulevard'', consecrated in 1870, builders: [[Friedrich August Stüler|Stüler]], [[Wilhelm Salzenberg|Salzenberg]]. * [[Church of Peace (Sanssouci)|Church of Peace in Sanssouci Park]], ''(1845 to 1854)''. This church was established at the entrance to Sanssouci Park like a medieval Italian monastery, consecrated in 1848, builders: [[Ludwig Persius|Persius]], [[Ferdinand von Arnim|von Arnim]], [[Ludwig Ferdinand Hesse|Hesse]], [[Friedrich August Stüler|Stüler]]. * [[Church of the Redeemer, Sacrow|Church of the Redeemer]], well outside the town centre, on the banks of the Havel, in the style of an Italian basilica, stood for years in the shadow of the wall in no-man's land, consecrated in 1844, architect: [[Ludwig Persius|Persius]]. * [[Alexander Nevsky Memorial Church]] built for the Russian residents of the settlement of [[Russian Colony of Alexandrowka|Alexandrowka]] below the ''Kapellenberg'', used without interruption, consecrated 1829, oldest Russian Orthodox church in Germany, architects: [[Vasily Stasov]] (design), [[Karl Friedrich Schinkel]]. * [[Church of Our Saviour, Potsdam|Church of Our Saviour]] (''Erlöserkirche''). Evangelical church in Potsdam-West, consecrated in 1898, builder: [[Gotthilf Ludwig Möckel|Möckel]] * Church of Christ, wedged between residential buildings continues to be the one-time [[Old Lutheran]] church, consecrated in 1903. Today the church is used independent Evangelical-Lutheran Church of Christ parish ([[SELK]]). Builder: Grabowsky. * Pentecostal Church, (1894). This church stands between [g] and the New Garden in an idyllic garden setting, consecrated in 1894, architect: [[Ludwig von Tiedemann|Tiedemann]]. * [[Hermannswerder]] Island Church, a Neogothic building that belongs to the [[Hoffbauer Foundation]], consecrated in 1911, builder: Gebrüder Bolle. * Frederick Church on the ''[[Weberviertel|Weberplatz]]'', (1752/1753). Centrepiece of a settlement for Bohemian weavers in Babelsberg (formerly Nowawes), consecrated in 1753, builder: [[Johann Boumann|Boumann]]. * Oberlin Church, Babelsberg, (1904/1905). focal point of the Oberlinhaus, ''inter alia'' a lyceum for deaf-blind people, consecrated in 1905, builder: [[Ludwig von Tiedemann|Tiedemann]]. * Old Neuendorf Church in Babelsberg, built 1850-52, rebuilding started in 1998<ref>{{cite web|title=Official site|url=http://www.neuendorfer-kirche-potsdam.de/|publisher=Alten Neuendorfer Kirche|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> * Parish Church of St. Anthony, Roman Catholic church for Babelsberg, consecrated in 1934, architect: Fahlbusch. * Chapel of Klein-Glienicke, near the city's boundary with Berlin, which meant that the church fell into ruin as a result of its proximity to the Berlin Wall, consecrated in 1881, architect: [[Reinhold Persius]]. * Bornstedt Church, Italianate church that watches over the graves of famous Potsdam townsfolk, consecrated in 1856, builder: Stüler. * other village churches in the incorporated villages: ** Bornim (1902/1903, consecrated 1903). Architect: [[Ludwig von Tiedemann|Tiedemann]] ** Eiche (1771) ** Grube (1746) ** Nattwerder (1690 – the oldest surviving church in Potsdam) ** Drewitz (1732) * and the churches in the new districts: ** Stern Church (1990) ** Church of Atonement, Kirchsteigfeld (1997)
<Gallery> Image:Potsdam St. Nikolaikirche 2005.jpg|St. Nicholas' Church File:French Church Potsdam.jpg|French Church File:Friedenskirche.jpg|[[Church of Peace (Potsdam)|Church of Peace]] File:Potsdam Alexandrowka 02-14 img5.jpg|Russian Orthodox church File:Neuendorfer Kirche.jpg|Neuendorf Church File:Christuskirche Potsdam.jpg|Evangelical-Lutheran Church of Christ File:Church of St Peter and Paul, Potsdam.jpg|Church of St. Peter and Paul </Gallery>
== City gates == As a garrison city Potsdam had a city wall with several gates. With their flamboyant architectural styles they were more built for show that for defence. Of the city gates only three have survived.
* [[Brandenburg Gate (Potsdam)|Brandenburg Gate]] (1770) * [[Nauen Gate (Potsdam)|Nauen Gate]]: construction plans by [[Johann Gottfried Büring]] based on 1754 sketches by King [[Frederick II of Prussia]]. First example of [[Neogothic]] in continental Europe. * [[Jägertor]] ("Hunters' Gate", 1733)
<gallery> File:Potsdam Brandenburger.jpg|Brandenburg Gate Image:Potsdam Nauener Tor 07-2017.jpg|Nauen Gate File:Potsdam Jaegertor 07-2017.jpg|Jägertor ("Hunters' Gate") </gallery>
== City quarters and ensembles ==
=== City quarters === * [[Dutch Quarter]] (1733 to 1740) * Russian Colony of Alexandrowka (1826/1827) with its [[Alexander Nevsky Memorial Church]] (foundation stone laid 1826, consecration 1829) * [[Potsdam-Babelsberg]] (around 1900) and the villa colony of Neubabelsberg as well as the Bohemian Weavers' Quarter (''Weberviertel'') * ''Brandenburger Straße'' is the shopping street of Potsdam in the city centre, and is a pedestrian zone, bordered by St. Peter and St. Paul's Church and the Brandenburger Tor.) * [[Berliner Vorstadt]] (from the second half of the 19th century) * [[Westliche Vorstadt (Potsdam)|Potsdam West]]
<Gallery> File:HollViertel.jpg|[[Dutch Quarter]] File:Potsdam Alexandrowka 02-14 img2.jpg|Russian Colony of Alexandrowka Image:Berliner Sternwarte Babelsberg.jpg|[[Berliner Sternwarte#Sternwarte Berlin-Babelsberg|Sternwarte Babelsberg]] File:Potsdam Brandenburger Str.jpg|Brandenburger Straße </Gallery>
=== Open spaces and squares === * [[Alter Markt (Potsdam)|Alter Markt]], historic centre of the city. ** [[Potsdam City Palace]] (''Stadtschloss''), (1662 to 1669, 1744 to 1752; was damaged in 1945, its rebuilding as the state parliament (''[[Landtag]]'') should be finished in 2012) ** [[Fortuna Portal]], (1701 to 1740) rebuilt 2001/02. ** [[Old City Hall (Potsdam)|Old City Hall]] (''Altes Rathaus''), built in the baroque style in 1753 to a design by [[Andrea Palladio]] for the Palazzo Angarano in [[Vicenza]] that was never executed. * ''[[Neuer Markt (Potsdam)|Neuer Markt]]'', almost entirely preserved baroque square. * ''[[Luisenplatz (Potsdam)|Luisenplatz]]'', (ab 1733), baroque square between ''Brandenburger Straße'' and the entrance to Sanssouci Park. * ''[[Bassinplatz]]'' with St. Peter and St. Paul's and the French Church. * ''[[Platz der Einheit (Potsdam)|Platz der Einheit]]'', central square with modern and historic architecture. * [[Glienicke Bridge]], (end of the 17th century), well known for the exchange of agents during the [[Cold War]]. * [[Potsdam Airship Station]] (''Luftschiffhafen Potsdam'') * [[Babelsberg Film Studio]] and [[Babelsberg Film Park]] * The new cultural quarter of ''Schiffbauergasse'' with the [[Hans Otto Theatre (Potsdam)|Hans Otto Theatre]] and the Schinkelhalle.
<gallery> Image:Potsdam_Altes_Rathaus.jpg|Old City Hall on the ''Alter Markt'' (old market square) Image:GlienickerBruecke ty 20060908r0012665.jpg|[[Glienicke Bridge]] File:Hans-Otto-Theater4.jpg|Hans Otto Theatre </gallery>
=== Buildings === * [[Jan Bouman]] House (1735) in the Dutch Quarter * The Hiller & Brandt Houses (1769) located at Breite Strasse 8–12 * The former Great Military Orphanage (''Großes Militärwaisenhaus'') (1771) * [[Pomona Temple]] (around 1800), the first work by [[Karl Friedrich Schinkel]] * The steam-powered Pump House (1841–43) for the fountains of [[Sanssouci Park]], designed by [[Friedrich Ludwig Persius|Ludwig Persius]] in the shape of a mosque on the bank of the Havel River * [[Belvedere on the Pfingstberg]] (1847 to 1852, 1860 to 1863) * The former War College (''Kriegsschule'') (1902) on the Brauhausberg hill * The [[Kaiserbahnhof Potsdam|Emperor's Station]] (1905–09) (''Kaiserbahnhof''), originally the Court Station (''Hofstation'') in Wildpark, has been used since its recent restoration as a Management Academy (''Akademie für Führungskräfte'') for the [[Deutsche Bahn|German rail system]]. * Karstadt department store with [[art nouveau]] facade and atrium (1905, 1928–29) * Werner Alfred Bathhouse * [[Bayrisches Haus]] * [[Einstein Tower]] (1920 to 1921) * Glass Sweets Factory owned by the firm [[Katjes]]. From the gallery, visitors can view the entire sweets-manufacturing process. <gallery> File:Potsdam-Jan-Boumann-Haus-17-06-2008.jpg|Jan Bouman House File:Breite Straße Potsdam November 2013.jpg|Hiller & Brandt Houses File:Potsdam Militärwaisenhaus.jpg|The former Great Military Orphanage File:Pomonatempel Potsdam.jpg|Pomona Temple File:Potsdam Pumpenhaus 07-2017.jpg|Steam-powered Pump House File:Belvedere auf dem Pfingstberg in Potsdam Juli 2014.jpg|Belvedere on the Pfingstberg File:Kreml Potsdam.jpg|Former War College on the Brauhausberg hill File:Potsdam Sanssouci 07-2017 img1.jpg|[[Kaiserbahnhof Potsdam|The Emperor's Station]] File:Stadtpalais.JPG|Karstadt department store Image:Einsteinturm 7443.jpg|[[Einstein Tower]] </gallery>
== Museums and exhibitions == [[File:Altes Rathaus und Knobelsdorffhaus - Potsdam (2014).png|thumb|Old Town Hall - home of the Potsdam Museum - Forum for Art and History]] [[File:Museum Barberini (von der Freundschaftsinsel aus).jpg|thumb|Museum Barberini in November 2016]] * [[Babelsberg Palace]] * [[Belvedere auf dem Klausberg]] * [[Belvedere on the Pfingstberg]] * [[Berlin S-Bahn Museum]] at [[Griebnitzsee station]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Official site|url=http://www.s-bahn-museum.de/|publisher=Berliner S-Bahn Museum|accessdate=16 October 2015|language=de}}</ref> * [[Cecilienhof]] * [[Charlottenhof Palace]] * [[Einstein Tower]] * [[Extavium Potsdam]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Official site|url=http://extavium.de/|publisher=Extavium|accessdate=16 October 2015|language=de}}</ref> * [[Historic Mill of Sanssouci]] * House of Brandenburg-Prussian History at the ''Neuer Markt''<ref>{{cite web|title=Official site|url=http://www.hbpg.de/|publisher=House of the Brandenburg-Prussian History|accessdate=16 October 2015|language=de}}</ref> * [[Jan Bouman]] House - typical gabled house from 1735 in the [[Dutch Quarter]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Official site|url=http://www.jan-bouman-haus.de/|publisher=Jan Bouman House|accessdate=16 October 2015|language=de}}</ref> * Kommandantenhaus - Memorial Lindenstraße for the victims of political violence in the 20th century<ref>{{cite web|title=Memorial Lindenstraße for the victims of political violence in the 20th century|url=http://vv.potsdam.de/vv/oe/173010100000008448.php|publisher=City of Potsdam|accessdate=17 October 2015|language=de}}</ref> * [[Marmorpalais]] * [[KGB Prison, Potsdam|Memorial Leistikowstraße Potsdam]] - former KGB prison * [[Museum Alexandrowka]] - Restored 1820s period wooden house in Russian style<ref>{{cite web|title=Official site|url=http://alexandrowka.de/english/|publisher=Museum Alexandrowka|accessdate=16 October 2015}}</ref> * [[Museum Barberini]] - Built on the site of [[Barberini Palace, Potsdam|Barberini Palace]]<ref>[http://museum-barberini.com/en/museum-barberini/ Museum Barberini, Potsdam]</ref> * [[Museum FLUXUS+]] * Museum ‘Im Güldenen Arm’<ref>{{cite web|title=Official site|url=http://www.imgueldenenarm.de/|publisher=Museumshaus „Im Güldenen Arm“|accessdate=16 October 2015|language=de}}</ref> * [[New Chambers (Sanssouci)|New Chambers]] * Nowaweser Weaver's Cottage in the Bohemian Weber Quarter<ref>{{cite web|title=Nowaweser Weberstube|url=http://www.potsdam.de/content/nowaweser-weberstube|publisher=City of Potsdam|accessdate=16 October 2015|language=de}}</ref> * [[Orangery Palace]] * [[Potsdam Film Museum]] in the historic royal stables, the oldest surviving building in the city<ref>{{cite web|title=Official site|url=http://www.filmmuseum-potsdam.de/|publisher=Filmmuseum Potsdam|accessdate=16 October 2015}}</ref> * Potsdam Museum in the [[Dutch Quarter]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Potsdam Museum|url=http://www.potsdam.de/kategorie/potsdam-museum-forum-fuer-kunst-und-geschichte|publisher=City of Potsdam|accessdate=16 October 2015}}</ref> * Potsdam Natural History Museum<ref>{{cite web|title=Naturkundemuseum Potsdam|url=http://www.potsdam.de/kategorie/naturkundemuseum-potsdam-0|publisher=City of Potsdam|accessdate=16 October 2015}}</ref> * [[Roman Baths (Potsdam)|Roman Baths]] * [[Sanssouci|Sanssouci Palace]] * [[Sanssouci Picture Gallery]] * Steam Engine Building in Sanssouci Park - historic pumphouse designed like a mosque<ref>{{cite web|title=Steam engine building (Mosque)|url=http://www.potsdam-tourism.com/detail/id/10227/theme/a-z.html|publisher=Visit Potsdam|accessdate=17 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dampfmaschinenhaus (Moschee)|url=http://www.spsg.de/schloesser-gaerten/objekt/dampfmaschinenhaus-moschee/|publisher=Castles and Parks in Potsdam and Berlin|accessdate=17 October 2015|language=de}}</ref> * [[Villa Schöningen]]
== Villas == [[File:Löwenvilla Potsdam.jpg|thumb|Löwenvilla]] [[File:Potsdam Villa Gericke.jpg|thumb|Villa Gericke]] [[File:Villa Stülpnagel Potsdam.jpg|thumb|Villa Stülpnagel]] [[File:Rühmann-Villa.JPG|thumb|Villa Lademann]] Since the 1990s many architecturally interesting villas have been restored:
* [[Neubabelsberg]] villa colony * [[Villa Ingenheim]] * [[Villa Liegnitz]] * [[Villa von Diringshofen]] * [[Villa Kampffmeyer]] by the [[Glienicke Bridge]] * [[Villa Schöningen]] by the Glienicke Bridge * [[Villa Heydert]] * Villa Rohn also called the Löwenwilla, named after the lions (''Löwen'') in front of the facade. Owned since 1941 by the Fritz von der Lancken family, a resistance fighter against the Third Reich. * Herbertshof, named after Herbert Gutmann, with its Arabic Room (''Zimmer Arabicum'') * [[Lichtenau Palace|Palace of Countess Lichtenau]], on the [[Heiliger See (Potsdam)|Heiliger See]] * Villa Bach, ''Spitzweggasse'' * Villa Ernst von Bergmann, ''Berliner Straße'' * Villa Gericke, ''Puschkinallee'' * Villa Gutmann (only a small part has been renovated) * Villa Kellermann * Villa Kutscherhaus, ''Persiusstr''. * Villa General Ladental * Villa Mendelson, named after the Jewish merchant * Villa Mosler * Villa Fritz Rumpf * Villa Sarna with its lion frieze * Villa Spillner, Böcklinstraße/Tizianstraße * Villa Starke (Potsdam-Babelsberg) * Villa [[Stülpnagel]], ''Hegelallee 5'', with impressive frame and panel door (''Kassettentür''); large historic map of Berlin in Russian script in the fireplace room. * Villa Wiener, Konrad Adenauer lived here in 1934 * Villa Lademann, Heinz Rühmann lived here during filming, the house was built by the brother of Otto Lilienthal, Gustav Lilienthal * Villa Alfred Zeisler, by Marika Röckk <!--
== Bildende Kunst == Die Stadt Potsdam verfügt über eine Vielfalt an Bildender Kunst in Form von Skulpturen and Gemälden. Die Gemälde verteilen sich hauptsächlich auf die Gebäude im Sanssouci Park, das Potsdam-Museum and die Kirchen der Stadt. Die Skulpturen sind hauptsächlich in den Parks verteilt, vor allem im Sanssouci Park. Ein [[Lapidarium]] stellt einige die Originale der Statuen aus.
* '''Gemälde (Auswahl)''' **[[Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio|Caravaggio]] - Der ungläubige Thomas ([[Bildergalerie (Sanssouci)|Bildergalerie]]) **[[Guido Reni]] - Tod der Kleopatra (Bildergalerie) **[[Peter Paul Rubens]] - Der Heilige Hieronymus (Bildergalerie) **[[Antoine Watteau]] - Der Tanz ([[Neues Palais]]) **[[Anthonis van Dyck]] - Die Ausgießung des Heiligen Geistes **[[Antoine Pesne]] - Todesangst Christi ([[St. Peter and Paul (Potsdam)|St. Peter and Paul Kirche]]) * '''Skulpturen (Auswahl)''' **[[Deserteurdenkmal_(Bonn/Potsdam)|Denkmal für den unbekannten Deserteur]] auf dem [[Platz_der_Einheit_(Potsdam)|Platz der Einheit]] **Lapidarium in der Kleinen Orangerie ([[Neue Kammern]]) im Sanssouci Park **[[Sanssouci Park]], insbesondere das Neue Palais mit 400 Statuen oder das Mohrenrondell **[[Freundschaftsinsel]] **Die Familie Grün
<gallery> Image:Statue Frau Potsdam.jpg|''Venus'' von [[Jean-Baptiste Pigalle]] im Sanssouci Park Image:Peter Paul Rubens-Der Heilige Hieronymus.jpg|Peter Paul Rubens - ''Der Heilige Hieronymus'' Image:Deserteurdenkmal_bonn.jpg|[[Deserteurdenkmal_(Bonn/Potsdam)|Denkmal für den unbekannten Deserteur]] auf dem [[Platz_der_Einheit_(Potsdam)|Platz der Einheit]] </gallery> -->
== Lakes ==
* [[Griebnitzsee]] * [[Großer and Kleiner Zernsee]] * [[Heiliger See (Potsdam)|Heiliger See]] * [[Jungfernsee]] * [[Lehnitzsee (Potsdam)|Lehnitzsee]] * [[Potsdamer Teufelssee|Teufelssee]] * [[Templiner See]] * Tiefer See * [[Weißer See (Potsdam)|Weißer See]] * [[Potsdam City Canal]], rebuilt in 1999
<gallery> File:Grünes Haus (Potsdam).jpg|The Green House (''Grünes Haus'') in the [[New Garden, Potsdam|New Garden]] on the [[Heiliger See (Potsdam)|Heiliger See]] File:Griebnitzsee 2009.JPG|[[Griebnitzsee]] File:Potsdam Stadtkanal.jpg|[[Potsdam City Canal]] </gallery> <!-- == Verlorene Bauwerke ==
* [[Potsdamer Stadtschloss]], im Zweiten Weltkrieg beschädigt, später gesprengt. Der Brandenburger Landtag soll in der Kubatur des Stadtschlosses neu entstehen. Das [[Fortunaportal]] was bereits wiederaufgebaut. * [[Garnison Church (Potsdam)|Garnison Church]], im Zweiten Weltkrieg beschädigt, später gesprengt. Der Wiederaufbau ist geplant. * Das [[Königliches Schauspielhaus (Potsdam)|Königliche Schauspielhaus]], Am Kanal 8 (im Volksmund „Kanaloper“). Das Gebäude was am 25. April 1945 durch Artilleriebeschuss zerstört. Die noch erhaltene Fassade ist 1966 abgebrochen worden. * [[Acht Ecken (Potsdam)|Acht Ecken]], erhalten blieb nur eines von vier barocken Eckhäusern. * Die ''Gloriette'' am [[Bassinplatz]], nach dem Zweiten Weltkrieg abgetragen and durch einen sowjetischen Friedhof ersetzt. * Weite Teile des ''Französischen Viertels'', erhalten blieb die [[Französische Kirche (Potsdam)|Französische Kirche]]. * Berliner Tor, erhalten ist nur ein Seitenflügel. * Neustädter Tor, erhalten ist nur ein einzelner Obelisk. * Der [[Langer Stall|Lange Stall]], 1945 abgebrannt, nur die aufwendige Frontfassade blieb erhalten. * [[Potsdamer Stadtkanal]] mit seinen zahlreichen Bridgen, was to 1965 zugeschüttet, er soll vollständig rekonstruiert werden. * [[Heilig-Geist-Kirche (Potsdam)|Heilig-Geist-Kirche]], 1945 stark beschädigt, 1960 Abbruch der Kirchenschiffruine, 1974 Sprengung des Turmstumpfes. 1997 erfolgte ein Neubau in den Umrissen der Kirche als Seniorenresidenz. * Bethlehem Church auf dem Neuendorfer Anger, 1945 schwer zerstört, 1952 gesprengt. * Synagoge, 1938 geplündert, 1945 zerstört. * Zahlreiche weitere Einzelhäuser, unter anderem der [[Palast Barberini]] and das Palasthotel an der Havel sowie weite Teile der Breiten Straße. --> <gallery> File:Berliner Tor Potsdam 1895.jpg|The Berlin Gate File:Potsdam Langer Stall Fassade.jpg|Langer Stall front facade Image:Acht Ecken Potsdam.jpg|Acht Ecken </gallery>
== Literature == * {{citation/core|Surname1=Andreas Kitschke|Title=Die Potsdamer Kirchen |Publisher=Kunstverlag Peda|PublicationPlace=Passau|Year=2001|ISBN=3-89643-530-2|Date= 2001|language=German}} * {{citation/core|Title=Potsdamer Schlösser in Geschichte and Kunst |Edition=4.|Publisher=VEB F.A. Brockhaus Verlag|PublicationPlace=Leipzig|Year=1984|ISBN=3-325-00030-4|Date= 1984|language=German|Comment=Hrsg: Staatliche Archivverwaltung der DDR, Staatliche Schlösser and Gärten Potsdam-Sanssouci}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons|Potsdam}} {{Commons|Babelsberg}} * [http://www.potsdam-wiki.de www.potsdam-wiki.de] – Wiki about the town of Potsdam * [http://www.potsdam-portal.net Havelland Tourism Association (''Tourismusverband Havelland'')] * [http://www.galerie-potsdam.de/ galerie-potsdam.de] – comprehensive photograph gallery with images of Potsdam * [http://home.arcor.de/karstenknuth/html/potsdam.html Other images and information]

revision.text:
{{See also|Tobacco control movement}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[Image:No smoking symbol.svg|right|thumb|180px|A [[pictogram]] is often used to denote a smoking ban]]
This is a '''list of [[smoking ban]]s''' by country. Smoking bans are public policies, including [[criminal law]]s and [[occupational safety and health]] regulations, which prohibit [[tobacco smoking]] in workplaces and/or other [[public space]]s. Legislation may also, in some cases, restrict the carrying or possessing of any lit tobacco product.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.azleg.gov/ars/36/00601-01.htm |title = Smoke-free Arizona the buttville California |publisher = Arizona State Legislature |accessdate = 18 June 2009 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110522111711/http://www.azleg.gov/ars/36/00601-01.htm |archivedate = 22 May 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> {{clear}}
{{TOC right}}
==Smoking bans by country== {| |[[File:Smoking-ban-countries.svg|300px]] |{{legend|grey|No known "smoke-free" restrictions (or no data)}} {{legend|yellow|Partial "smoke-free" restrictions, or patchy or inconsistent law enforcement}} {{legend|pink|No national "smoke-free" legislation – some localities have local restrictions}} {{legend|orange|National "smoke-free" legislation for public areas except entertainment and restaurants}} {{legend|red|National "smoke-free" legislation for public areas except entertainment and restaurants – some localities have additional local restrictions}} {{legend|brown|National "smoke-free" legislation covering all public indoor areas (sometimes with specific exceptions)}} |}
===Albania=== {{Main|Smoking in Albania}} A law came into effect on 30 May 2007 restricting smoking in closed public areas and outlawing the advertisement of tobacco, although the measure was reportedly poorly enforced in the country until 2013. From 2013, law enforcement has been implemented, and smoking is strictly forbidden in closed public areas, including bars, pubs, restaurants etc. If any of these places are caught allowing a customer to smoke, they are fined €2,200 and the person smoking is fined €350.<ref>{{cite news|title=No smoking law is working this time in Albania|url=http://www.balkaneu.com/smoking-law-working-time-albania/|work=www.balkaneu.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170903210500/http://www.balkaneu.com/smoking-law-working-time-albania/|archivedate=3 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Andorra=== Since 2004, smoking is prohibited in government buildings, educational facilities, hospitals, enclosed sport facilities and buses. In 2010, an increase in restrictions at restaurants, bars, and workplaces was under discussion.<ref>[http://www.diariandorra.ad/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=1794 Una proposta ciutadana vol que no es pugui fumar a la feina] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706062305/http://www.diariandorra.ad/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=1794 |date=6 July 2011 }} – Diari d'Andorra</ref>
Andorra introduced a smoking ban in all public places on 13 December 2012. However, an exception was made for bars and restaurants, allowing special smoking rooms as long as they fulfill strict conditions: such as not serving food and drink.<ref>[http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/sociedad/andorra-prohibe-fumar-los-espacios-publicos-2271733 Andorra prohíbe fumar en los espacios públicos Bares y restaurantes podrán habilitar zonas para fumadores pero no podrán consumir bebida ni comida] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121216121042/http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/sociedad/andorra-prohibe-fumar-los-espacios-publicos-2271733 |date=16 December 2012 }} – ElPeriodico</ref> In 2014, Andorra joined France and Spain in banning smoking indoors, which resulted in the first smoke free ski season in Andorra.<ref>{{cite news|title=Andorra's first smoke-free ski season|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/ski/news/Andorras-first-smoke-free-ski-season/|work=The Telegraph|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171227123916/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/ski/news/Andorras-first-smoke-free-ski-season/|archivedate=27 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2017, Andorra was one of the countries with the lowest mortality rate from cardiovascular disease, whose main causes include smoking.<ref>{{cite news|title=The cause-thirds of deaths in the world - micetimes.asia|url=http://micetimes.asia/the-cause-thirds-of-deaths-in-the-world/|work=micetimes.asia|date=18 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171223043845/http://micetimes.asia/the-cause-thirds-of-deaths-in-the-world/|archivedate=23 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Argentina=== {{Main|Smoking in Argentina}} Since June 1, 2011 a smoking ban in all of Argentina prohibits smoking in workplaces, all public indoor areas, schools, hospitals, museums and libraries, theatres, and all public transport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://infoleg.gov.ar/infolegInternet/anexos/180000-184999/183207/norma.htm|title=National Law Nº26,687 – Article 23|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610162948/http://infoleg.gov.ar/infolegInternet/anexos/180000-184999/183207/norma.htm|archivedate=10 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, smoking is still allowed in balconies, terraces and patios. The law also included the prohibiting of advertising and sponsoring of tobacco. The fine for breaking the law is equivalent to 250 to 1,000,000 packets of the most expensive cigarettes in the market.<ref>{{cite news|title=Argentine law targets smoking in enclosed public spaces|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-13624384|work=BBC News|date=2 June 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171111003603/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-13624384|archivedate=11 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Armenia=== A law came into effect in March 2005 prohibiting smoking in hospitals, in cultural, educational and mental institutions, and on public transportation. On 1 March 2006, new rules came into effect requiring all public and private institutions, including bars and restaurants, to allow smoking only in special secluded areas. Absence of any legal sanctions against those who violate the smoking laws has made them completely ineffective.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.armenialiberty.org/armeniareport/report/en/2006/03/484fbde7-796a-4798-b4d1-b99aa705fa47.asp |title=Smoking Restrictions Widened In Armenia |publisher=Armenialiberty.org |date=1 March 2006 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115040823/http://www.armenialiberty.org/armeniareport/report/en/2006/03/484FBDE7-796A-4798-B4D1-B99AA705FA47.ASP |archivedate=15 November 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Tobacco advertising is prohibited in TV, radio and outdoor advertising. Other sources of advertising on newspapers, magazines of tobacco products is not fully restricted.{{clarifyme|date=December 2017}} Sponsorships are partially allowed in Armenia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Armenia Details – Tobacco Control Laws|url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/armenia/summary|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170505134642/http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/armenia/summary|archivedate=5 May 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2012, Armenia had the third-highest number of male cigarette smokers in the world.<ref>{{cite news|title=Armenia third in the world with highest smoking rates among men in 2012|url=http://www.armradio.am/en/2014/01/08/armenia-third-in-the-world-with-highest-smoking-rates-among-men-in-2012/|work=Public Radio of Armenia|date=8 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171223043539/http://www.armradio.am/en/2014/01/08/armenia-third-in-the-world-with-highest-smoking-rates-among-men-in-2012/|archivedate=23 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In January 11, 2017, the Eurasian Economic Commission said that starting mid-March 2017, graphic pictures would be implemented on the packaging of cigarettes in all Eurasian Economic Union member states (EEU).<ref>{{cite news|title=Armenia to introduce graphic pictures on cigarette packs|url=http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/news/229734/Armenia_to_introduce_graphic_pictures_on_cigarette_packs|work=PanARMENIAN.Net|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170112182245/http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/news/229734/Armenia_to_introduce_graphic_pictures_on_cigarette_packs|archivedate=12 January 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Australia=== {{Main|List of smoking bans in Australia}} In Australia, smoking bans are determined on a state-by-state basis. In chronological order by state: * South Australia: Smoking prohibited in all indoor dining areas since January 1999.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccolaws.sa.gov.au/ |title=Tobaccolaws.sa.gov.au |publisher=Tobaccolaws.sa.gov.au |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217051209/http://tobaccolaws.sa.gov.au/ |archivedate=17 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Banned in all enclosed public places since November 2007. * Western Australia: Incremental restrictions introduced from January 2005 with a comprehensive total restriction upon smoking in all enclosed public spaces taking effect from July 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Lists/Statements/DispForm.aspx?ID=115987 |title=WA Government media statement, 28 November 2004 |publisher=Mediastatements.wa.gov.au |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226091446/http://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Lists/Statements/DispForm.aspx?ID=115987 |archivedate=26 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Tasmania: Total indoor smoking ban in force since January 2006. From January 2008 the regulations were extended to include smoking in cars with passengers under the age of 18.<ref>{{Cite news |author=AAP |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22990981-2702,00.html |title=Smoking banned in cars in Tasmania |work=The Australian |date=31 December 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103110657/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22990981-2702,00.html |archivedate=3 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Queensland: Comprehensive smoking ban in effect since July 2006. Smoking is prohibited in all pubs, clubs, restaurants and workplaces, commercial outdoor eating and drinking areas, outdoor public places, and within 5 metres of non-residential building entrances.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.health.qld.gov.au/tobaccolaws/outdoor/default.asp |title=Outdoor public areas |publisher=Health.qld.gov.au |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314214906/http://www.health.qld.gov.au/tobaccolaws/outdoor/default.asp |archivedate=14 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Australian Capital Territory: A restriction upon smoking in enclosed public places has been in effect since December 2006. * Victoria: A restriction upon smoking in enclosed public places has been in effect since July 2007. It is also an offence to smoke in a vehicle where there is a person under the age of 18 present, since January 2010. Smoking is still Permitted in all drinking areas providing it is 25% Outdoors and meals are not being served. Private cigar bars and certain rooms of the Crown Casino still permitted smoking in fully enclosed areas providing it has a proper ventilation system. * New South Wales: A restriction upon smoking in all enclosed areas of restaurants, licensed clubs and pubs came into force in July 2007. From 1 July 2009, smoking in a car with a child under the age of 16 is against the law. The Public Health (Tobacco) Act 2008 creates a new offence of smoking in a car with a child under 16 years of age in the vehicle. A $250 on-the-spot fine applies to the driver and any passenger who breaks the law. This is enforced by NSW Police.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/publichealth/healthpromotion/tobacco/smoke_free_cars.asp |title=Smoke-free Cars – NSW Department of Health |publisher=Health.nsw.gov.au |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219052152/http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/publichealth/healthpromotion/tobacco/smoke_free_cars.asp |archivedate=19 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Northern Territory: Certain restrictions upon smoking in enclosed areas of restaurants, licensed clubs and pubs came into force on 2 January 2010. *Norfolk Island: Smoking is banned in all government buildings, tour buses, taxis and flights to and from the island. There is no law on smoking in restaurants but many are smokefree, however, they often have a dedicated smoking room for people that wish to smoke. Smoking is permitted in all bars and licensed premises. Resorts and motels have smoking rooms and areas for smokers.
===Austria=== Austrian law limits or bans smoking in certain areas: * Smoking is prohibited in all enclosed public spaces, with certain exceptions for eating and drinking establishments. Smoking in the workplace can be permitted if no employee working in the enclosed space objects. * A January 2009 law mandates that all restaurants, bars, discos, and pubs larger than 50 m² must either be non-smoking or introduce separate smoking rooms. Below 50 m² the owner may opt to make the establishment either a smoking or non-smoking place. The law provided for a long transition phase ending July 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/TRAVEL/getaways/03/05/austria.germany.travel/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=4 April 2010 |title=A wunderbar welcome in Austria and Germany - CNN.com |date=5 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090609081309/http://www.cnn.com/2009/TRAVEL/getaways/03/05/austria.germany.travel/index.html |archivedate=9 June 2009 }}</ref> The smoking ban has since been a subject of controversy, as the rules are widely ignored by bar owners and not actively enforced by the authorities. Anti-smoking campaigners claim to have filed 18,000 reports with the authorities on non-compliant businesses since the bans were introduced, to little effect. * Smoking was banned on trains and in railway stations when Germany introduced a similar smoking ban in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1350131.php |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120906044845/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1350131.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 September 2012 |title=Austria inches towards smoking ban |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=31 August 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 }}</ref>
In December 2017, after a change in government, an already passed bill<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parlament.gv.at/PAKT/AKT/SCHLTHEM/SCHLAG/198Rauchverbot.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710022413/http://www.parlament.gv.at/PAKT/AKT/SCHLTHEM/SCHLAG/198Rauchverbot.shtml |archivedate=10 July 2015 |df= }} Austrian parliament voted for strict smoking ban from May 2018</ref> banning smoking in all restaurants, bars, discos and pubs from May 2018 was repealed and the prior rules reinstated with some minor changes. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/austria-smoke-bar-mps-vote-to-scrap-ban/ |title=Austrian MPs vote to scrap smoking ban}}</ref>
===Bahrain=== In 2008, the Bahrain government introduced anti-smoking laws indoor public areas, including restaurants, cafes, hair salons, shopping malls and public transport. The law was highlighted by the ban of smoking in private cars when there are children.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bahrain introduces strict new anti-smoking laws|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/bahrain-introduces-strict-new-anti-smoking-laws-13636.html|work=Arabian Business|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101201020744/http://www.arabianbusiness.com/bahrain-introduces-strict-new-anti-smoking-laws-13636.html|archivedate=1 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The law could be implemented in the following points:
# Planting and manufacturing tobacco in Bahrain. # Cigarette vending machines. # Tobacco to be sold to anyone under the age of 18. # The importing of chewable-based tobacco products. # Smoking at closed public places, including airports, hotels, supermarkets and schools. # ‘No smoking’ signs must be displayed prominently where there is a ban.<ref>{{cite news|title=Smoking ban in Bahrain|url=http://www.timeoutbahrain.com/knowledge/features/8573-smoking-ban-in-bahrain|work=Time Out Bahrain|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223040821/http://www.timeoutbahrain.com/knowledge/features/8573-smoking-ban-in-bahrain|archivedate=23 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Belgium=== * 2005: Companies should have implemented smoking plans to discourage smoking. * January 2006: Smoking prohibited in the work area. * January 2007: Smoking prohibited in restaurants and bars, except in those that serve "light meals" (e.g. cold meals, pizzas and warm meals that are served with bread instead of French fries) ''and'' have less of 30% of their sales from food servings. Small bars are also not included in the regulations. Larger bars, such as concert venues, should enforce the regulations although the initial experience was variable. * September 2008: Smoking no longer allowed in schools. * January 2010: A general smoking ban that included all types of bars had been discussed but was watered-down to a set of regulations that apply only when food is served.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/cnt/g692344pg|title=Algemeen rookverbod op 1 juli 2010|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160623191651/http://www.nieuwsblad.be/cnt/g692344pg|archivedate=23 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * July 2011: On 15 March 2011, Belgium's Constitutional Court ruled that the discrimination between bars serving food and those not serving food (and casinos) distorted competition and that, as a consequence, the partial exemption had to end by July 2011, thus banning smoking in Belgium's bars, restaurants and casinos without exception.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20110315/lf_afp/belgiumtobaccohealth |title= Belgium tobacco health |publisher= |date= |accessdate=14 January 2013}}{{dead link|date=January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.const-court.be |title=Grondwettelijk Hof – Cour constitutionnelle |publisher=Const-court.be |date= |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028130727/http://www.const-court.be/ |archivedate=28 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Benin=== Benin has a smoking ban in place for certain public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/benin/summary|title=Benin Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093107/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/benin/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Bermuda=== As of 1 October 2006, smoking is banned in all enclosed workplaces in Bermuda, including restaurants, bars, private clubs and hotels.<ref>[http://bermudasun.bm/main.asp?SectionID=24&SubSectionID=270&ArticleID=31037&TM=10964.17 Smoking ban kicks in on Sunday] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824161403/http://bermudasun.bm/main.asp?SectionID=24&SubSectionID=270&ArticleID=31037&TM=10964.17 |date=24 August 2011 }} – Bermuda Sun</ref>
===Bhutan=== {{Main|Tobacco Control Act of Bhutan 2010}} Following a resolution of the 87th session of the National Assembly on 17 December 2004, a national prohibition upon the sale of tobacco and tobacco products went into effect, but importing limited tobacco was still permitted subject to very heavy taxes.<ref>''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate Magazine]]'': [http://www.slate.com/id/2112449/ The First Nonsmoking Nation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301005049/http://slate.com/id/2112449 |date=1 March 2009 }} by Eric Weiner</ref> Smoking in all public places in Bhutan became illegal on 22 February 2005. It thus became the first nation in the world to outlaw this practice outright.
The Tobacco Control Act of Bhutan was enacted by [[parliament of Bhutan|parliament]] on June 16, 2010.<ref name=TCA>{{cite web|url=http://www.nab.gov.bt/downloadsact/Dzo76.pdf |format=PDF |title=Tobacco Control Act of Bhutan, 2010 |publisher=[[Government of Bhutan]] |date=2010-06-16 |accessdate=2011-01-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706162944/http://www.nab.gov.bt/downloadsact/Dzo76.pdf |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> It regulates tobacco and tobacco products, banning the cultivation, harvesting, production, and sale of [[tobacco]] and [[tobacco products]] in Bhutan. The act also mandates that the [[government of Bhutan]] provide counseling and treatment to facilitate [[smoking cessation|tobacco cessation]]. Premised on the physical health and well-being of the Bhutanese people – important elements of [[Gross National Happiness]] – the Tobacco Control Act recognizes the harmful effects of tobacco consumption and exposure to tobacco smoke on both spiritual and social health.
The consumption of tobacco is not altogether prohibited in Bhutan, though it is largely banned in places of public accommodation. The Act largely targets [[smoking]] in particular, though all forms of tobacco are subject to the Act. The Tobacco Control Act establishes [[smoking ban|non-smoking]] areas: commercial centers including markets, hotel lobbies, restaurants, and bars; recreation centers such as discothèques, cinemas, and playing fields; institutions and offices, both public and private; public gatherings and public spaces such as festivals, taxi stands, and [[Paro Airport|the airport]]; all public transportation; and any other places declared by the Tobacco Control Board. The board also has the authority to designate smoking areas in public. Smoking areas are permitted in non-public areas of hotels (i.e. smoking floors or smoking rooms) at the discretion of the patron.
The Act prohibits the cultivation, harvest, manufacture, supply, and distribution of tobacco, as well as the manufacture, supply, distribution, sale, and purchase of tobacco products within Bhutan. The Act allows individuals to import tobacco and tobacco products for personal consumption subject to limits set by the Tobacco Control Board, as well as duties and taxes. Those who bring their own tobacco or tobacco products into Bhutan must bear{{clarifyme|date=December 2017}} proof of taxation, may only bring goods that display required health warnings, and must not bring goods that promote tobacco by means that are false, misleading, or likely to create an erroneous impression of its characteristics, health effects, or hazards. (e.g. descriptors such as "light" or "mild") The Act totally prohibits tobacco advertisement, promotion and sponsorship, restricting the appearance of tobacco in domestic videos and movies to educational clips produced for the purpose of health promotion.
===Bosnia and Herzegovina=== The [[Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] has prohibited smoking in public buildings nationwide since 1 September 2007. However, until 2016, indoor buildings were not completely smoke-free.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0012/312600/Tobacco-control-fact-sheet-BosniaHerzegovina.pdf|title=Tobacco Control Fact Sheet: Bosnia and Herzegovina. Health impact of tobacco control policies in line with the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC)|institution=World Health Organization|date=2016|accessdate=27 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511140143/http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0012/312600/Tobacco-control-fact-sheet-BosniaHerzegovina.pdf|archivedate=11 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Bosnia and Herzegovina was ranked the 4th highest in Europe by percentage of daily smokers in 2016, after Russia, Serbia and Greece (the highest).
===Brazil=== {{main|Smoking in Brazil}} Smoking in Brazil is forbidden in all enclosed public spaces except for specifically designated smoking areas.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil/LEIS/L9294.htm |title=Article 2 of Brazil Federal law no. 9294 |publisher=Planalto.gov.br |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110103074210/http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil/LEIS/L9294.htm |archivedate=3 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Since 15 December 2011, Federal Law 12546 (article 49) forbids smoking in enclosed spaces in the entire country, including restaurants and bars.<ref>[http://www2.inca.gov.br/wps/wcm/connect/observatorio_controle_tabaco/site/status_politica/ambientes_livres_tabaco INCA (National Cancer Institute)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212150458/http://www2.inca.gov.br/wps/wcm/connect/observatorio_controle_tabaco/site/status_politica/ambientes_livres_tabaco |date=12 February 2012 }}</ref> As of 3 December 2014, Brazil has banned smoking in all indoor private and public places, including restaurants, bars and nightclubs.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Alves|first1=Lise|title=Ample Anti-Smoking Law Implemented in Brazil {{!}} The Rio Times {{!}} Brazil News|url=http://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/rio-politics/ample-anti-smoking-law-implemented-in-brazil/|work=The Rio Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011181917/http://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/rio-politics/ample-anti-smoking-law-implemented-in-brazil/|archivedate=11 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2017, a research was published in Brazil that the smoke-free laws implemented resulted in a reduction in the number of heart attacks welcomed in the hospitals. After a year and half, the number of deaths caused by heart attacks decreased by 12% <ref>{{cite news|title=The evidence keeps piling up: Smoke-free law in São Paulo linked to fewer hospitalizations and deaths due to heart attacks {{!}} Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education|url=https://tobacco.ucsf.edu/evidence-keeps-piling-smoke-free-law-são-paulo-linked-fewer-hospitalizations-and-deaths-due-heart-attacks|work=tobacco.ucsf.edu|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511140141/https://tobacco.ucsf.edu/evidence-keeps-piling-smoke-free-law-s%C3%A3o-paulo-linked-fewer-hospitalizations-and-deaths-due-heart-attacks|archivedate=11 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In [[Brazil]], the legal age for sale and consumption of [[tobacco]] is 18. [[Tobacco advertising]] is restricted to posters in shops,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/CCIVIL/leis/L9294.htm |title=Law 9294, 15 July 1996 |publisher=Planalto.gov.br |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110103074210/http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil/LEIS/L9294.htm |archivedate=3 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and is banned on television and radio. All cigarette packs contain advertisements against smoking and government warnings about possible adverse [[health effects of smoking]].
===Bulgaria=== A comprehensive smoking ban has been introduced prohibiting smoking in all public places including bars, restaurants, clubs, workplaces, stadiums, etc. and came into effect on 1 June 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dnes.dir.bg/news/zabrana-luben-kornezov-merki-srestu-pusheneto-11164950?nt=4 |title=Забраниха пушенето на закрито, по стадиони и детски площадки – Днес.dir.bg |publisher=Dnes.dir.bg |date=23 April 2012 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605022500/http://dnes.dir.bg/news/zabrana-luben-kornezov-merki-srestu-pusheneto-11164950?nt=4 |archivedate=5 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Burkina Faso=== Burkina Faso has a smoking ban in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/burkina-faso/summary|title=Burkina Faso Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093106/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/burkina-faso/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Cameroon=== In Cameroon, smoking is only prohibited in schools, universities and ministry buildings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/cameroon/summary|title=Cameroon Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093116/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/cameroon/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Canada=== {{Main|Smoking in Canada}} In [[Smoking in Canada|Canada]], indoor smoking is restricted by all territories and provinces and by the [[Government of Canada|Canadian federal government]]. As of 2010, smoking bans within each of these jurisdictions are mostly consistent, despite the separate development of legislation by each. The federal government's workplace smoking ban applies only to the federal government and to federally regulated businesses, such as airports. In Ontario and Alberta, smoking is banned in all workplaces except designated areas. Smoking rooms are available in select hotels and motels in most jurisdictions. Individual communities have bylaws restricting where individuals may smoke. In several Canadian cities smoking has now been banned on municipally owned property including public parks. Manitoba, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Labrador, Alberta, and Ontario have also prohibited smoking within vehicles with children under 16.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/265625|title=Smoking Ban Starts Wednesday For Ontario Cars That Carry Children|date=21 January 2009|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820214418/http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/265625|archivedate=20 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.mb.ca/drivers/smoking_law.html |title=Province of Manitoba | Effective July 15, it's the law |publisher=Gov.mb.ca |date=15 July 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130104064009/http://www.gov.mb.ca/drivers/smoking_law.html |archivedate=4 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Chile=== Chile prohibits smoking in schools, hospitals, government offices, shopping centres, supermarkets, pharmacies, airports, buses, subway networks and other indoor public places. Smoking indoors in universities is restricted, although it is allowed outdoors. In 2013 Chile's legislative body approved a ban on all smoking in public enclosed spaces nationwide, including restaurants, pubs and clubs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ilovechile.cl/2013/01/03/smoking-ban/76919 |title=Chile's Congress Passes Monumental Public Smoking Ban | I Love Chile |publisher=Ilovechile.cl |date=3 January 2013 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130106070652/http://ilovechile.cl/2013/01/03/smoking-ban/76919 |archivedate=6 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===China=== {{Main|Smoking in the People's Republic of China}} [[Shanghai Municipality]] expanded a smoking ban from hospitals to kindergartens, schools, libraries and stadiums, as of 1 March 2010,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/11/content_12629545.htm |title=Shanghai to impose wider ban on smoking in public venues_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=11 December 2009 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125181315/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/11/content_12629545.htm |archivedate=25 January 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and had attempted to restrict smoking in restaurants for the [[2010 World Expo]], but compliance in restaurants was reportedly poor and enforcement lax. In 2015, Shanghai municipality improved the smoking ban by adding hotels, offices and restaurants. As of March 2017, Shanghai widened its smoking ban by implementing on all public places and adding some outdoor areas <ref>{{cite news|title=Shanghai expands public smoking ban|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20170301-shanghai-expands-public-smoking-ban|work=France 24|date=1 March 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170301093545/http://www.france24.com/en/20170301-shanghai-expands-public-smoking-ban|archivedate=1 March 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In [[Guangdong]] Province, the municipalities of [[Guangzhou]] and [[Jiangmen]] restricted smoking in public places in 2007, but the law was not effectively enforced.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsgd.com/news/guangdong1/200704100038.htm |title=Guangdong to launch stricter smoking ban at public places |publisher=Newsgd.com |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406114502/http://www.newsgd.com/news/guangdong1/200704100038.htm |archivedate=6 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A new national smoking ban, which extends to all enclosed public areas, came into effect on 1 May 2011. However enforcement of this is patchy at the best of times, especially outside developed cities like Beijing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.cri.cn/7146/2011/05/06/2702s635887.htm|title=New National Smoking Ban|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917141006/http://english.cri.cn/7146/2011/05/06/2702s635887.htm|archivedate=17 September 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On June 1, 2015, Beijing enacted a new law banning smoking in public spaces such as restaurants and bars, offices, shopping malls, on public transportation and at airports. Those breaking the law will be fined 200 yuan ($32) and will be "named and shamed" on a government website after three times. Businesses allowing patrons to light up could be fined up to 10,000 yuan ($1,600) and could have their licenses revoked for repeat offences. The new law also cracks down on advertising.<ref>({{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/01/asia/china-beijing-smoking-crackdown/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705185134/http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/01/asia/china-beijing-smoking-crackdown |archivedate=5 July 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>({{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32954884 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-07-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150803014943/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32954884 |archivedate=3 August 2015 |df=dmy-all }})</ref>
===Colombia=== {{Main|Smoking in Colombia}} In 2009, Colombia extended its existing tobacco control regulations by requiring all indoor work places and public places be immediately smoke-free; prohibiting tobacco advertising, promotions and sponsorship, and the use of terms such as ‘light’ and ‘mild’ on packaging, requiring large, pictorial health warnings on tobacco packaging (covering 30 per cent of the front and back) within a year, preventing the sale of tobacco products to minors; and mandating public education programs on the deadly effects of tobacco use.
===Comoros=== Comoros has a smoking ban in place for certain public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/comoros/summary|title=Comoros Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093058/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/comoros/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Costa Rica=== {{main|Smoking in Costa Rica}} In 2012, Costa Rica passed one of the strictest smoking regulations in the world. This legislation has banned smoking in buses, taxis, trains and their terminals, work places (including parking lots), public buildings, restaurants, bars, casinos, and all enclosed public-access buildings, granting no exceptions (no separate "smoking areas" are permitted). It also bans smoking in outdoor recreational or educational areas such as parks, stadia and university campuses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ticotimes.net/Current-Edition/News-Briefs/Costa-Rican-lawmakers-pass-sweeping-anti-tobacco-reforms-_Monday-February-27-2012 |title=Costa Rican lawmakers pass sweeping anti-tobacco reforms / News Briefs / Current Edition / Costa Rica Newspaper, The Tico Times |publisher=Ticotimes.net |date=27 February 2012 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130114201639/http://www.ticotimes.net/Current-Edition/News-Briefs/Costa-Rican-lawmakers-pass-sweeping-anti-tobacco-reforms-_Monday-February-27-2012 |archivedate=14 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It introduced a 20 colones tax per cigarette and prohibits any form of tobacco advertising, the use of misleading terms such as "light" or "mild" and the sale of small packages or individual cigarettes. It also prohibits bars and restaurants from selling cigarettes. Violators will be fined a minimum of 180.000 colones (US$355).<ref>{{cite web |author=http://www.insidecostarica.com/ |url=http://www.insidecostarica.com/dailynews/2012/february/28/costarica12022801.htm |title=It's Butts Out In Costa Rica! |publisher=Insidecostarica.com |date=28 February 2012 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620161335/http://www.insidecostarica.com/dailynews/2012/february/28/costarica12022801.htm |archivedate=20 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Croatia=== On 22 November 2008 the Croatian Parliament passed legislation<ref>{{cite web |url=http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/342110.html |title=125 29.10.2008 Zakon o ograničavanju uporabe duhanskih proizvoda |publisher=Narodne-novine.nn.hr |date=29 October 2008 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090321084229/http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/342110.html |archivedate=21 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> prohibiting smoking in public institutions such as hospitals, clinics, schools, nurseries and universities with infractions punishable with up to 1000 [[kuna (currency)|kuna]] (140 euros). A notable exception in the Act are psychiatric wards in Croatia's hospitals. The law went further in May 2009 when smoking was banned in all enclosed public areas including bars, restaurants and cafes. The smoking ban applies to all public areas where non-smokers could suffer from [[second-hand smoke]] including open public areas like sport stadiums, arenas, open-air theatres, tram and bus stations etc.<ref>[http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2008_10_125_3560.html Law on restriction of tobacco-product use] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216010307/http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2008_10_125_3560.html |date=16 February 2009 }} ''Narodne novine 125/08'''</ref> <ref>[http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/main/news/14639/ "Croatia Bans Smoking"] ''[[Balkan Insight|balkaninsight.com]]'' 7 November 2008 Link accessed 7 November 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.vecernji.hr/newsroom/news/croatia/2984810/index.do;jsessionid=D79A733AC59D1CA3E5574A6864ED2916.2 Croatia banning smoking]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''vecernji.hr'''</ref> On 10 September 2009 the regulations restricting smoking in bars and cafes in Croatia was partially repealed for a grace period until 9 April 2010, local media has reported. Proprietors with establishments that are up to 50 sq m that meet very strict conditions will now be able to choose whether to allow smoking. One of the conditions is a ventilation system that is able to change indoor air at least 10 times per hour. By March 2010 only 16 (out of 16,000) establishments in all of Croatia had met the conditions and been permitted to allow smoking.<ref>[http://www.novilist.hr/2010/03/15/od-16000-kafica-pusacki-status-z.aspx "Od 16.000 kafića, pušački status zatražilo samo 16 ''Novi list''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322210948/http://www.novilist.hr/2010/03/15/od-16000-kafica-pusacki-status-z.aspx |date=22 March 2010 }}</ref> Larger establishments will have to include a designated and separately ventilated smoking area<ref>{{cite web |author=Nick Iliev |url=http://sofiaecho.com/2009/09/11/783081_croatia-reverses-smoking-ban-in-public-places |title=Croatia reverses smoking ban in public places – Foreign |publisher=The Sofia Echo |date=11 September 2009 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107184413/http://sofiaecho.com/2009/09/11/783081_croatia-reverses-smoking-ban-in-public-places |archivedate=7 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Cuba=== {{main|Smoking in Cuba}} Cuba has prohibited smoking in most workplaces, removed cigarette machines and made it illegal to sell tobacco products near schools since February 2005.<ref>{{cite web |author=Antonio de la Cova |url=http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/cuba/no-smoking.htm |title=In a country famed for its cigars, Cuba adds no-smoking rules |publisher=Latinamericanstudies.org |date=18 January 2005 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609090609/http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/cuba/no-smoking.htm |archivedate=9 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The ban included prohibiting smoking in closed public spaces, public transport, educational, health and sporting institutions. However, the ban was not very effective as a study revealed that more than 50% of the population are being exposed to smoking in daily life. In 2014, Cuban authorities said that they are working on passing further anti-smoking legislation. Such legislation will prevent the sale of cigarettes to people under the age of eighteen. The new legislation will also require tobacco companies to add graphic warnings on the packaging.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cuba to Pass Stricter Anti-Smoking Legislation - Havana Times.org|url=http://www.havanatimes.org/?p=107601|work=www.havanatimes.org|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026110447/http://www.havanatimes.org/?p=107601|archivedate=26 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Cyprus=== On 9 July 2009 Cyprus passed a new law, tightening up ineffective 2002 legislation, which banned smoking in bars, restaurants, nightclubs and workplaces as of 1 January 2010.<ref>{{cite web |title= Cyprus smoking health |url= https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/cyprussmokinghealth |accessdate=12 July 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Since the implementation of the smoking ban on 1 January 2010, compliance levels have been variable, apparently mainly due to a lack of enforcement by the police. A spokesman for some restaurant & bar owners has nevertheless complained that the introduction of the ban has led to a drop in revenue<ref>{{cite web |author=+ – Text size //var addthis_pub="49f59059007d44e8"; // |url=http://www.cyprus-mail.com/cyprus/strong-compliance-smoking-ban/20100105 |title=Strong compliance with smoking ban |publisher=Cyprus Mail |date=5 January 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101207201747/http://www.cyprus-mail.com/cyprus/strong-compliance-smoking-ban/20100105 |archivedate=7 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> but produced no evidence to support this statement.
===Czech Republic=== The second German anti-tobacco organization, the ''Bund Deutscher Tabakgegner'' (Federation of German Tobacco Opponents), was established in 1910 in [[Trautenau]], [[Bohemia]]. In 1920, a ''Bund Deutscher Tabakgegner in der Tschechoslowakei'' (Federation of German Tobacco Opponents in Czechoslovakia) was formed in [[Prague]], after [[Czechoslovakia]] was separated from the Austro-Hungarian Empire at the end of World War I.<ref>{{citation|last=Proctor |first=Robert |title=The Nazi War on Tobacco: Ideology, Evidence, and Possible Cancer Consequences |journal=[[Bulletin of the History of Medicine]] |volume=71 |issue=3 |pages=435–88 |year=1997 |pmid=9302840 |url=http://environmentaloncology.org/files/file/secrethistorysupport/Chapt%203%20References/REF%207%20proctor.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=22 July 2008 |quote=The first German anti-tobacco organisation was established in 1904 (the short-lived Deutscher Tabakgegnerverein zum Schutze für Nichtraucher); this was followed by a Bund Deutscher Tabakgegner based in the town of Trautenau, in Bohemia (1910), and similar associations in Hanover and Dresden (both founded in 1912). When Czechoslovakia was severed from Austria after the First World War, a Bund Deutscher Tabakgegner in der Tschechoslowakei was established in Prague (1920); that same year in Graz a Bund Deutscher Tabakgegner in Deutschösterreich was founded. |doi=10.1353/bhm.1997.0139 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014053354/http://www.environmentaloncology.org/files/file/secrethistorysupport/Chapt%203%20References/REF%207%20proctor.pdf |archivedate=14 October 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> Currently, there is a law in force that restricts smoking in some public places such as institutions, hospitals, bus stops and other public service stops, in May 2017 restriction expanded to prohibit smoking in restaurants, bars and clubs. In June 2009 the parliament approved a bill ostensibly regulating smoking in public places. However, at the time this regulation only required bars and restaurants to post a sign saying whether smoking was allowed, not allowed, or whether there are separate rooms for smokers and non-smokers in the establishment. In February 2011, the popular initiative "stop kouření" announced, that 115,000 people had signed their petition demanding a ban on smoking in restaurants and denouncing the country's high cancer rate, poor rating concerning tobacco control and possible corruption of members of the Czech parliament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.praguepost.com/opinion/7561-petition-pushes-for-czech-smoking-ban.html|title=Petition pushes for Czech smoking ban – Prague Post|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120909155822/http://www.praguepost.com/opinion/7561-petition-pushes-for-czech-smoking-ban.html|archivedate=9 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On December 9, 2016, the Chamber of Deputies passed a law that bans smoking in all restaurants and bars. The bill was approved by the Senate on January 19, 2017,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/senatori-po-nekolikahodinove-debate-schvalili-protikuracky-z/r~8ebbc240de4611e69d46002590604f2e/?_ga=1.31693306.575588695.1466714897&redirected=1484920821|title=Senátoři schválili protikuřácký zákon beze změn, diskutovali o něm pět hodin|website=Aktuálně.cz – Víte co se právě děje|language=cs|access-date=2017-01-20|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201235316/https://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/senatori-po-nekolikahodinove-debate-schvalili-protikuracky-z/r~8ebbc240de4611e69d46002590604f2e/?_ga=1.31693306.575588695.1466714897&redirected=1484920821|archivedate=1 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and signed by the President Miloš Zeman on February 14, 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.praguemorning.cz/milos-zeman-signed-anti-smoking-law |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215131929/http://www.praguemorning.cz/milos-zeman-signed-anti-smoking-law/ |archivedate=15 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It came into effect on May 31, 2017.
===Democratic Republic of the Congo=== The Democratic Republic of the Congo has a smoking ban in place for certain public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/summary|title=Democratic Republic of the Congo Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093056/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Denmark=== Since 15 August 2007, smoking in hospitality facilities, restaurants, bars, clubs, [[public transport]], and all private and public workplaces has been forbidden. Exemptions to the law are bars with a floor space of less than 40m². Separate smoking rooms are allowed in hospitality facilities as long as no food or beverage is served there. The law's initially controversial reception was accompanied by variable enforcement. As of July 1, 2014, smoking is prohibited in train stations including the platforms (whether inside or out),<ref>{{cite web |title= Roaming and smoking among July 1st changes |date= 30 June 2014 |url= http://www.thelocal.dk/20140630/cheaper-roaming-no-smoking-illegal-shooting-july-1-changes |publisher= [[The Local]] Denmark |accessdate= 2 July 2014 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140703023048/http://www.thelocal.dk/20140630/cheaper-roaming-no-smoking-illegal-shooting-july-1-changes |archivedate= 3 July 2014 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> it is however poorly enforced, and smoking is seen on both inside and outside platforms regularly. In 2017, a lot of different sectors grouped in order to work on a mobile app to combat underage smoking in Denmark.<ref>{{cite news|title=New mobile app to combat underage smoking and drinking in Denmark|url=http://cphpost.dk/news/business/new-mobile-app-to-combat-underage-smoking-and-drinking-in-denmark.html|publisher=[[The Copenhagen Post]]|date=1 May 2017|accessdate=28 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171202035819/http://cphpost.dk/news/business/new-mobile-app-to-combat-underage-smoking-and-drinking-in-denmark.html|archivedate=2 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the municipality of [[Randers]], politicians are preparing to implement outdoor anti-smoking recommendations, which will advise people not to smoke and without any fines applied.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thelocal.dk/20151026/danish-city-prepares-outdoor-smoking-ban|title=Danish city prepares outdoor smoking ban|date=26 October 2015|accessdate=28 November 2017|publisher=[[The Local]] Denmark|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026053906/https://www.thelocal.dk/20151026/danish-city-prepares-outdoor-smoking-ban|archivedate=26 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Djibouti=== Djibouti has a smoking ban in place for certain public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/djibouti/summary|title=Djibouti Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093118/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/djibouti/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Ecuador=== {{Main|Smoking in Ecuador}} [[Smoking in Ecuador|Smoking]] is more common among men and younger people in Ecuador.<ref name="Ockene">{{cite journal | pmc= 1759503 | title= Smoking in Ecuador: prevalence, knowledge, and attitudes | last= Ockene | first= J. K. | publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information | year= 1996 | pmid=8910993 | volume=5 | issue=2 | journal=Tob Control | pages=121–6 | doi=10.1136/tc.5.2.121 }}</ref> Smoking is common in bars and dance clubs, but non-smoking signs in restaurants in [[Quito]] are generally respected.
