A national law has forbidden smoking in bars.<ref>{{cite web |title= (page not found) |url= http://federacionmedicaecuatoriana.info/index.php/2013-01-10-04-24-32/nacionales/176-ecuador-listo-para-endurecer-aun-mas-normas-antitabaco |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140419044253/http://federacionmedicaecuatoriana.info/index.php/2013-01-10-04-24-32/nacionales/176-ecuador-listo-para-endurecer-aun-mas-normas-antitabaco |archivedate= 19 April 2014 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> A bill was passed in 2006 that prohibits smoking in indoor workplaces, public transportation and public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/ecuador/summary|title=Ecuador Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170927140841/http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/ecuador/summary|archivedate=27 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2011, Ecuador Parliament implemented a new tobacco control, that witnessed the addition of smoking ban in sport facilities and on all health or educational institutions. In addition, the sponsorships and advertisements were prohibited. And finally a ban on tobacco vending machines<ref>{{cite news|title=Ecuador – New tobacco control law adopted|url=http://www.who.int/fctc/implementation/news/ecuador_news/en/|work=World Health Organization|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413123503/http://www.who.int/fctc/implementation/news/ecuador_news/en/|archivedate=13 April 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Egypt=== Smoking ban in Egypt was first implemented in 2010 in Alexandria, when it banned smoking in governmental institutions.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Knell|first1=Yolande|title=Egypt introduces Alexandria smoking ban|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/10280900|work=BBC News|date=10 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180101040211/http://www.bbc.com/news/10280900|archivedate=1 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Now smoking in Egypt is prohibited in specific public places: health and educational facilities, government venues, social and sporting clubs, youth centers and public transportation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt Details – Tobacco Control Laws|url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/egypt/summary|work=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170525102019/http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/egypt/summary|archivedate=25 May 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Estonia=== Smoking has been restricted in indoor public areas and workplaces since 4 June 2005, except in restaurants. Subsequently, a ban on smoking in bars, restaurants, coffee shops and nightclubs started on 5 June 2007 (although smoking is still allowed in isolated smoking rooms).
===Falkland Islands=== Smoking has been prohibited in all enclosed public places (including pubs, restaurants, social clubs, hotels and shops), enclosed workplaces, and public vehicles (taxis and buses) since 1 February 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.falklandnews.com/public/story.cfm?get=5873 |title=Falkland Islands News Network |publisher=Falklandnews.com |date=22 January 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102144520/http://www.falklandnews.com/public/story.cfm?get=5873 |archivedate=2 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Faroe Islands=== As of 1 July 2008, smoking ban applied on all public and private workplaces. The ban also included public areas and transport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Smoking ban in Faroe%20Islands|url=http://en.rauchverbotweltweit.de/smokingban.php?land=Faroe%20Islands|work=en.rauchverbotweltweit.de|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171025022341/http://en.rauchverbotweltweit.de/smokingban.php?land=Faroe%20Islands|archivedate=25 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Finland=== {{Main|Smoking in Finland}} Smoking has been restricted in indoor public areas and workplaces from 1 March 1995, and permitted only in specially designated [[smoking room]]s; restaurants were included in 2007. Legislation aimed towards voluntary reduction of [[second-hand smoke]] was enacted, but was not successful; few establishments installed effective ventilation systems. Dividing a restaurant into a smoking and non-smoking section was also an ineffective measure. As a result, smoking has since been prohibited in all indoor public and workplaces, including bars, cafes, clubs and restaurants, from 1 June 2007, except in some places permitted a transition period of up to two years. Smoking was permitted in trains in designated smoking booths until June 2013, when it was banned by the national railway company. Smoking in bars is still allowed in enclosed smoking booths, where it is not permitted to serve or consume food or drink. Many smaller bars have not been able to build such smoking booths and patrons must smoke outside.
As of early 2010, Finland's government has openly considered planning gradual moves towards prohibiting smoking completely.<ref name="ban all smoking">{{cite web |url = http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/finland-embarks-plan-will-ban-all-smoking-117181 |title = Finland embarks on plan that will ban all smoking |publisher = National Business Review |date = 15 January 2010 |accessdate = 13 August 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100603163834/http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/finland-embarks-plan-will-ban-all-smoking-117181 |archivedate = 3 June 2010 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
===France=== {{Main|Smoking in France}} Smoking is banned in all indoor public places (stations, museums, restaurants, cafés, etc.) Establishments with the sign "Tabac" come within the same strict regulations. This sign only means that they are state-licensed to sell tobacco products.
===Gabon=== In Gabon, smoking is prohibited in many public places but the law requires designated smoking areas to be provided.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/gabon/summary|title=Gabon Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093104/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/gabon/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Gambia=== The Gambia has a smoking ban in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/gambia/summary|title=Gambia Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093114/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/gambia/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Georgia=== {{Main|Smoking in Georgia}}
On 1 May 2018 legislation banning smoking in public places (stations, hotels, restaurants, café-bars, etc.) was enacted. <ref>[https://www.georgianjournal.ge/society/34433-places-in-georgia-where-smoking-will-be-banned-from-may-1-2018.html] {{webarchive|url=|date=26 October 2018 }} – Georgian Journal</ref>
===Germany=== {{Main|Smoking in Germany}} The 16 states of Germany have their own smoking laws. As of July 2016, nearly 40% of the German population (Bavaria, North Rhine-Westphalia, Saarland) live in a state with a strict smoking ban including all restaurants, pubs, cafés and discos. In the other 13 states designated smoking rooms as well as one-room smoking bars with less than 75 m² are permitted.
===Gibraltar=== Smoking has been prohibited in all enclosed public spaces since 1 October 2012.<ref>[http://vox.gi/local/6005-smoking-ban-comes-into-force.html Smoking ban comes into force] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130102103832/http://vox.gi/local/6005-smoking-ban-comes-into-force.html |date=2 January 2013 }} – Vox Gibraltar</ref>
===Greece=== {{main|Smoking in Greece}} [[Image:Anti-smoking Law Greece 1856.PNG|thumb|right|235px|[[Royal decree]] of 1856, introducing the first restriction upon smoking in modern Greece. Prohibition was valid only within state buildings and was grounded on the need to prevent [[accident]]s.]] As of 2010, Greece was the country with the highest rate of tobacco consumption (more than 40%) in the European Union.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epha.org/a/4088|title=2010 Eurobarometer survey on tobacco – European Public Health Alliance|last=Staff|date=13 July 2010|publisher=[[European Public Health Alliance]]|accessdate=10 August 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728114359/http://www.epha.org/a/4088|archivedate=28 July 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Since older legislation was not very efficient; a new, more comprehensive law was passed. Effective from 1 September 2010, this law prohibits smoking ''and'' consumption of tobacco products by other means, in all workplaces, transport stations, taxis and passenger ships (in trains, buses and aeroplanes smoking is already prohibited), as well as in all enclosed public places including restaurants, nightclubs, etc., without any exception. Casinos and bars bigger than 300 m<sup>2</sup> were given eight months to apply the law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.us-winston.com/greece-to-ban-smoking-in-all-indoor-public-places/ |title=Greece to ban smoking in all indoor public places | US Winston Online Club |publisher=Us-winston.com |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717174253/http://www.us-winston.com/greece-to-ban-smoking-in-all-indoor-public-places/ |archivedate=17 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Enforcement of the law is reportedly weak, with most owners of coffee shops, pubs, and restaurants continuing to permit smoking, especially at outdoor sitting areas. In [[Santorini]], there appears to be no enforcement.
===Guinea=== Guinea has a smoking ban in place for certain public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/guinea/summary|title=Guinea Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093124/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/guinea/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Guatemala=== Guatemala has implemented a comprehensive smoking ban covering all types of places and institutions. In December 2008 the Guatemalan Congress approved Decree 74-2008 and it became effective in February 2009. This law restricts smoking in all work-places including health-care facilities, governmental facilities, schools, universities, airports, bars and restaurants. However, two years after the law's implementation enforcement has been deficient. Governments are facing pressures to permit work-place smoking once more by local tobacco companies.<ref>Decreto 74-2008, Ley de Creación de los Ambientes Libres de Humo de Tabaco, El Congreso de la República de Guatemala Diciembre del 2008 url={{cite web |url=http://www.congreso.gob.gt/archivos/decretos/2008/gtdcx74-2008.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306092052/http://www.congreso.gob.gt/archivos/decretos/2008/gtdcx74-2008.pdf |archivedate=6 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Guernsey=== Smoke-free ordinances were introduced at different times in the [[Bailiwick of Guernsey]], a [[British Islands|British]] [[Crown dependency]]. Smoking was restricted in all enclosed public places in the island of [[Guernsey]], including workplaces, bars, clubs and restaurants, on 2 July 2006, under the ''"Smoking (Prohibition in Public Places and Workplaces) (Guernsey) Law 2005"''. Anyone who breaks the law, upon conviction, could be fined up to the maximum of £1000 (~€1150, ~$1470). Smoking is allowed anywhere outside and in whatever company.<ref>[http://www.gov.gg/ccm/navigation/health---social-services/environmental-health---pollution-regulation/smoke-free-guernsey/ Information about the Guernsey smoking ban] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928033314/http://www.gov.gg/ccm/navigation/health---social-services/environmental-health---pollution-regulation/smoke-free-guernsey/ |date=28 September 2007 }}</ref>
In [[Alderney]], the [[States of Alderney]] passed a smoke-free law with the President's casting vote on 13 January 2010; the legislation came into force at 4 am on 1 June 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alderneyjournal.com/readnews.php?id=1145 |title=Alderney Journal |publisher=Alderney Journal |date=14 January 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707104350/http://www.alderneyjournal.com/readnews.php?id=1145 |archivedate=7 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Smoking in indoor public places continues to be permitted in [[Sark]], except in pubs and restaurants.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-guernsey-14062258 | work=BBC News | title=Sark bans smoking in pubs but not offices or churches | date=7 July 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101161256/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-guernsey-14062258 | archivedate=1 January 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Honduras=== Honduras strictly banned smoking in all indoors places in Feb 2011.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/22/smoking-ban-in-honduras-_n_826490.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Honduras' Smoking Ban Takes It To The Next Level | date=22 February 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130530115432/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/22/smoking-ban-in-honduras-_n_826490.html | archivedate=30 May 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> It carries fines of $311 per incident, with police involvement, and fines up to $6,000 for businesses with possibility of being forced to close, and has been strongly enforced, even in provincial areas, including in large bars and nightclubs. Billiards areas at night continue to allow smokers.
===Hong Kong=== {{Main|Smoking in Hong Kong}} [[Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China|Hong Kong]] has seen all public smoking restricted from 1 January 2007 under the [[Hong Kong Government|government]]'s revised [[Smoking (Public Health) Ordinance]] (Cap. 371), first enacted in 1982 with several amendments subsequently. The latest amendment enlarges the smoke-free regulations to include indoor workplaces, most public places including restaurants, Internet cafés, public lavatories, beaches and most public parks. Some bars, karaoke parlors, saunas and nightclubs were exempt until 1 July 2009. Smoke-free regulations pertaining to lifts, public transport, cinemas, concert halls, airport terminals and escalators had been phased in between 1982 and 1997. The smoke-free requirements in shopping centres, department stores, supermarkets, banks, game arcades have been in place since July 1998.
An anomaly exists on cross-border trains between Hong Kong and mainland China as they are operated jointly between MTR Corporation and China Railways, of whom the latter allows smoking in the restaurant car and in the vestibules at the end of the cars, but not in the seating area.
Any person who smokes or carries a lighted tobacco product in a statutory no smoking area commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a maximum fine of HK$5,000. Unlike many other jurisdictions, Hong Kong does not place the onus on licensees of liquor licensed premises to enforce smoke-free regulations bans with subsequent loss of licence for non compliance. A 2009 law provides for fixed-penalty arrangement (HK$1,500) for smoking, on a par with that for littering. At the same time smoking was to be prohibited in designated public transport interchanges, but the government has yet to clarify how it will enforce this against non Hong Kong ID card-holders and tourists, since the offender has 21 days after the ticket issue to pay up.
The overall daily smoking rate in Hong Kong is 11.8% (HK Department of Census and Statistics Household Thematic Survey 36) with 25% of males smoking whereas in China 63% of males smoke.
===Hungary=== [[Image:Nemzeti dohánybolt Békéscsaba.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Nemzeti dohánybolt (National Tobacco Shop) in [[Békéscsaba]]. These state-controlled shops have the same design and regulation all over [[Hungary]].]] Smoking has been restricted for several years on public transport, in hospitals and airports and in public and national buildings; including the [[Hungarian Parliament Building|Parliament]]. From 2010, a smoke-free policy has been in effect in [[playground]]s and [[underpass]]es.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://index.hu/belfold/budapest/2010/08/05/matol_tilos_a_dohanyzas_az_aluljarokban/ |title=Index – Belföld – Mától tilos a dohányzás az aluljárókban |publisher=Index.hu |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229220609/http://index.hu/belfold/budapest/2010/08/05/matol_tilos_a_dohanyzas_az_aluljarokban/ |archivedate=29 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Several cities, including [[Budapest]], have prohibited smoking at public transport stops.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://index.hu/belfold/2009/03/12/varosok_csatlakoztak_a_dohanytilalomhoz/|title=Újabb városok csatlakoztak a kültéri dohánytilalomhoz|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303234827/http://index.hu/belfold/2009/03/12/varosok_csatlakoztak_a_dohanytilalomhoz/|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://index.hu/belfold/budapest/2010/12/15/tilos_lesz_a_dohanyzas_a_bkv-megallokban/ |title=Index – Belföld – Tilos lesz a dohányzás a BKV-megállókban |publisher=Index.hu |date=15 December 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219073455/http://index.hu/belfold/budapest/2010/12/15/tilos_lesz_a_dohanyzas_a_bkv-megallokban/ |archivedate=19 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Following a decade of resistance by the tobacco lobby, a comprehensive nationwide smoke-free law covering all indoors public spaces (including workplaces, clubs, pubs, restaurants) came into effect from January 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.napi.hu/magyar_gazdasag/kit_fognak_megbuntetni_ha_tiltott_helyen_dohanyzik.481182.html |title=Kit fognak megbüntetni, ha tiltott helyen dohányzik? – Megszavazták a törvényt – Napi Gazdaság |publisher=Napi.hu |date= |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102151825/http://www.napi.hu/magyar_gazdasag/kit_fognak_megbuntetni_ha_tiltott_helyen_dohanyzik.481182.html |archivedate=2 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.origo.hu/itthon/20110223-dohanyzas-betiltjak-a-vendeglatohelyeken-kocsmakban-ettermekben-a-cigit.html |title=Dohányzás, betiltják a vendéglátóhelyeken, kocsmákban, éttermekben a cigit |publisher=Origo.hu |date=31 January 1999 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030220311/http://www.origo.hu/itthon/20110223-dohanyzas-betiltjak-a-vendeglatohelyeken-kocsmakban-ettermekben-a-cigit.html |archivedate=30 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Since July 2013, the sale of tobacco is limited to state-controlled (but privately-owned) tobacco shops called ''Nemzeti Dohánybolt'' (National Tobacco Shop), the number of stores where people can buy tobacco reduced from 40,000–42,000 to 5,300.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://index.hu/gazdasag/2013/07/01/trafik/ |title=Index – Gazdaság – Itt vannak a nemzeti dohányboltok |publisher=Index.hu |date=1 July 2013 |accessdate=9 July 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703205619/http://index.hu/gazdasag/2013/07/01/trafik/ |archivedate=3 July 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In March 2017, Hungary was one of only seven EU member states that have a complete ban on smoking in all public places.<ref>{{cite news|last1=SurferToday.com|first1=Editor at|title=European Union calls for smoking ban on beaches|url=https://www.surfertoday.com/environment/13536-european-union-calls-for-smoking-ban-on-beaches|work=SurferToday|language=en-us|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330194646/http://www.surfertoday.com/environment/13536-european-union-calls-for-smoking-ban-on-beaches|archivedate=30 March 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Iceland=== {{Main|Smoking in Iceland}} Smoking and the use of other tobacco products are prohibited in most public spaces in Iceland. This includes all enclosed spaces in common ownership, all public land intended for use by children, all public transport and all services; including restaurants, bars, clubs and cafés.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.althingi.is/lagasofn/134/2002006.html |title=2002 nr. 6 31. janúar/ Lög um tóbaksvarnir |publisher=Althingi.is |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302164409/http://www.althingi.is/lagasofn/134/2002006.html |archivedate=2 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===India=== {{Main|Smoking in India}} A nationwide smoke-free law pertaining to public places came into effect from 2 October 2008. Places where smoking is restricted include auditoriums, movie theatres, hospitals, public transport (aircraft, buses, trains, metros, monorails, taxis, [[Auto rickshaw|autos]]) and their related facilities (airports, bus stands/stations, railway stations), restaurants, hotels, bars, pubs, amusement centres, offices (government and private), libraries, courts, post offices, markets, shopping malls, canteens, refreshment rooms, banquet halls, discothèques, coffee houses, educational institutions and parks. Smoking is allowed on roads, inside one's home or vehicle.<ref name="expressindia1">{{cite web|author=Agencies |url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/Smoking-ban-to-be-enforced-from-Oct-2-Ramadoss/317035/ |title=Smoking ban to be enforced from Oct 2: Ramadoss |publisher=Express India |date= |accessdate=13 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203204150/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/Smoking-ban-to-be-enforced-from-Oct-2-Ramadoss/317035/ |archivedate=3 December 2008 |df= }}</ref> Smoking is also permitted in airports, restaurants, bars, pubs, discothèques and some other enclosed workplaces if they provide designated separate smoking areas.<ref name="expressindia1"/> Anybody violating this law will be charged with a fine of {{INR}}200.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiritindia.com/health-care-news-articles-11644.html |title=India to declare all places of work as smoke free |publisher=Spiritindia.com |date=23 July 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430061955/http://www.spiritindia.com/health-care-news-articles-11644.html |archivedate=30 April 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> The sale of tobacco products within 100 yards of educational institutions is also prohibited. This particular rule is strictly enforced.Further as of 2014, there is strict provision of imprisonment for selling tobacco products to any person aged below 18 years of age .
The Cable Television Network (Regulation) Amendment Bill, in force since 8 September 2000, completely prohibits cigarette and alcohol advertisements.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ias.org.uk/resources/publications/theglobe/globe200103-04/gl200103-04_p27.html |title=Alcohol in India |publisher=Ias.org.uk |date=8 September 2000 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130114035029/http://www.ias.org.uk/resources/publications/theglobe/globe200103-04/gl200103-04_p27.html |archivedate=14 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Indonesia=== {{main|Smoking in Indonesia}} In [[Jakarta]]'s restaurants, hotels, office buildings, airports and public transport, and overall public areas smoking is not permitted. Restaurants wanting to allow smoking must provide a separate smoking space, as of 4 February 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/01/18/bloomberg/sxsmoke.php |title=A smoking ban fires up Jakarta – ''International Herald Tribune'' |work=International Herald Tribune |date=29 March 2009 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312065704/http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/01/18/bloomberg/sxsmoke.php |archivedate=12 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> As in some other Asian nations, it remains to be seen whether it can be enforced. Building separate facilities for smokers had only taken place in half of establishments by June 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tobacco.org/news/248932.html |title=Buildings in hot seat over smoking ban |publisher=Tobacco.org |date=27 June 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726133841/http://www.tobacco.org/news/248932.html |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Smoke-free regulations were extended to [[Bali]] in November 2011, affecting tourist sites, including restaurants and hotels; plus schools, government buildings, places of worship and other public places.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/home/a-holiday-without-cigarettes-smoking-ban-to-hit-bali/481329 |title=A Holiday Without Cigarettes: Smoking Ban To Hit Bali |publisher=The Jakarta Globe |date= |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130224740/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/home/a-holiday-without-cigarettes-smoking-ban-to-hit-bali/481329 |archivedate=30 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A ban on sale and advertising tobacco in schools was also enacted, although this would not stop tobacco companies offering sponsorship to schools.<ref>{{cite web |last=Roberts |first=George |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-30/cigarette-ads-banned-in-bali-schools/3702976 |title=Cigarette ads banned in Bali schools – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=30 November 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127093552/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-30/cigarette-ads-banned-in-bali-schools/3702976 |archivedate=27 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, regulations were not strong enough, leading to a new stricter promulgation for June 2012.
Smoking in trains of state company PT Kereta Api Indonesia has been banned as of 1 March 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://baliholidayinfo.com/content/smoking-trains-be-banned |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418050905/http://baliholidayinfo.com/content/smoking-trains-be-banned |archivedate=18 April 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Bali has banned smoking to be effective 1 June 2012, also having heavy fines. Hotels, restaurants, tourist attractions, places of worship, healthcare facilities and schools are to be smoke-free areas. Smoking and advertising for tobacco products have also been banned in playgrounds, traditional and modern markets, transportation terminals, airports, government offices and on public transportation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnngo.com/explorations/life/smokers-bali-your-days-are-numbered-452425 |title=Calling all smokers in Bali: The end is nigh | CNN Travel |publisher=Cnngo.com |date=29 November 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201123800/http://www.cnngo.com/explorations/life/smokers-bali-your-days-are-numbered-452425 |archivedate=1 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Iran=== {{main|Smoking in Iran}}
Smoking in Iran has been banned in all public places since 2007. This includes all state bodies, hotels, restaurants. The law also bans the smoking of traditional waterpipes (ghalyun) which were common in Iranian tea houses. A smoking ban for all car drivers nationwide was implemented in March 2006, and although offenders can face fines, the ban has been widely ignored. The sale of tobacco products to anyone under the age of 18 is prohibited and is punishable by the confiscation of the vendor's tobacco products and a fine.
===Ireland=== {{Main|Smoking in Ireland}} [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] became the first country in the world to institute a nationwide comprehensive smoke-free workplaces law on 29 March 2004. Prior to this, comprehensive smoke-free law was instituted, smoking had already been outlawed (1988) in public buildings, hospitals, pharmacies, schools, banking halls, cinemas, public hairdressing premises, restaurant kitchens, part of all restaurants, on public aircraft and buses, and some trains (Intercity trains provided smokers' carriages).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.e-sheesh.com/ireland-work-place-ban|title=Ireland Work Place Ban|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818091718/http://www.e-sheesh.com/ireland-work-place-ban|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 1 July 2009, Ireland banned in-store [[tobacco advertising]] and [[Tobacco display ban|displays of tobacco products]] at retail outlets and introduced new controls on tobacco [[vending machine]]s.
===Isle of Man=== The [[Isle of Man]]'s smoke-free law is similar to the one introduced in England, and came into effect on 30 March 2008. This also included Europe's first fully smoke-free prison.<ref>[http://www.iomtoday.co.im/ViewArticle.aspx?SectionID=870&articleid=2015621 Exact Date Set For Smoking Ban – Isle Of Man Today] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929112057/http://www.iomtoday.co.im/ViewArticle.aspx?SectionID=870&articleid=2015621 |date=29 September 2007 }}</ref>
===Israel=== In Israel, smoking is prohibited in public enclosed places or commercial areas via several laws: particularly, since 1983, the "Israel Clean Air Act" ([[:he:חוק אוויר נקי לישראל|חוק אוויר נקי לישראל]] (in Hebrew)).<ref>{{cite web|title=Law for the restriction of smoking in public places|publisher=(in Hebrew)|url=http://www.linshom.com/law/public.htm|accessdate=21 November 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112141608/http://www.linshom.com/law/public.htm|archivedate=12 November 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The law was amended in 2007 so that owners are held accountable for smoking in premises under their responsibility. The second means by which smoking is regulated in Israel is via the environmental hazard law,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avir-naki.com/Laws/%D7%97%D7%95%D7%A7%20%D7%9C%D7%9E%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%A2%D7%AA%20%D7%9E%D7%A4%D7%92%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%9D.doc|title=(in Hebrew)|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> and via criminal law smoking (or the introduction of second-hand smoke) may even be considered an assault.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.1439141|title=בימ"ש: עישון במסעדה הוא תקיפה ועילה לפיטורים|first=כרמל בן|last=צור|date=3 September 2007|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|via=Haaretz|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406084342/http://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.1439141|archivedate=6 April 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>[http://www.avir-naki.com/Laws/%D7%97%D7%95%D7%A7%20%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%A9%D7%99%D7%9F.doc the criminal act law defines smoking as an assault] (in Hebrew)</ref>
The restrictions include all commercial entities such as lavatories, office buildings, gyms, cafés, restaurants, discos, pubs and bars, and it is illegal for the owners of such places to put ashtrays anywhere inside enclosed spaces. Also, owners of public places must display "no smoking" signs and prevent visitors from smoking. They can also designate a well-ventilated and completely separate area for smokers, as long as the non-smokers' area does not fall below 75% of the whole area. The fine for owners of public places is [[New Israeli sheqel|₪]] 5,000 (around US$1400) and for smokers – ₪ 1000. In spite of all of this, the smoke-free law has not met with 100% compliance and smoking is still encountered in some pubs, bars and clubs. In Israel, a 2011 law restricts smoking in railway stations and at bus stops, and prohibits the sale of tobacco from automated vending machines.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} An individual may call the police in cases of smoking in a restricted environment and can also sue (via the citizen's court) the smoking entity (i.e., both the person smoking and the facility that allowed smoking to occur).<ref>[http://www.articles.co.il/article/24611/%D7%90%D7%93%D7%9D%20%D7%A9%D7%A0%D7%A4%D7%92%D7%A2%20%D7%9E%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F%20%D7%A4%D7%A1%D7%99%D7%91%D7%99%20%D7%A8%D7%A9%D7%90%D7%99%20%D7%9C%D7%94%D7%92%D7%99%D7%A9%20%D7%92%D7%9D%20%D7%AA%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A2%D7%94%20%D7%90%D7%96%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%99%D7%AA%20%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%93%20%D7%94%D7%9E%D7%A2%D7%A9%D7%9F passive smoker is allowed to sue smokers when he can prove damages] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720050325/http://www.articles.co.il/article/24611/%D7%90%D7%93%D7%9D%20%D7%A9%D7%A0%D7%A4%D7%92%D7%A2%20%D7%9E%D7%A2%D7%99%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F%20%D7%A4%D7%A1%D7%99%D7%91%D7%99%20%D7%A8%D7%A9%D7%90%D7%99%20%D7%9C%D7%94%D7%92%D7%99%D7%A9%20%D7%92%D7%9D%20%D7%AA%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A2%D7%94%20%D7%90%D7%96%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%99%D7%AA%20%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%93%20%D7%94%D7%9E%D7%A2%D7%A9%D7%9F |date=20 July 2012 }} (in Hebrew)</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3584649,00.html|title=תקדים: מעשנת תפצה אדם שנפגע מעישון פסיבי|date=19 August 2008|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|via=Ynet|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114221747/http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3584649,00.html|archivedate=14 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20120724202309/http://www.avir-naki.com/Verdicts_Summary.aspx aggregation of verdicts against smokers in Israel](in Hebrew)</ref>
Some cities are known for their rigorous enforcement of the smoke-free laws, such as the city of [[Be'er Sheva]] (which raised revenue of 799,000 NIS (~215K USD) in 2011 through fining smoking in public places)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/54/ART2/335/689.html?hp=54&cat=873&loc=8|title=מקומי – באר שבע nrg – ...הרווח של עיריית ב"ש מקנסות על|website=www.nrg.co.il|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171111041716/http://www.nrg.co.il/online/54/ART2/335/689.html?hp=54&cat=873&loc=8|archivedate=11 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and [[Tel-Aviv]],<ref name="ynet.co.il">{{cite web|url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3974539,00.html|title=כך קוברות הרשויות המקומיות את חוק העישון|date=25 October 2010|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|via=Ynet|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509045545/http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3974539,00.html|archivedate=9 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> but in many municipalities the law isn't enforced.<ref name="ynet.co.il"/>
===Italy=== {{Main|Smoking in Italy}} Since 2003 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2013/01/13/italia/cronache/dieci-anni-senza-fumo-cosi-la-legge-sirchia-ha-cambiato-l-italia-QFUyYYi1EnWXPGGPcr6q8N/pagina.html|title=Dieci anni senza fumo, così la legge Sirchia ha cambiato l’Italia|author=|date=|website=lastampa.it|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126071026/http://www.lastampa.it/2013/01/13/italia/cronache/dieci-anni-senza-fumo-cosi-la-legge-sirchia-ha-cambiato-l-italia-QFUyYYi1EnWXPGGPcr6q8N/pagina.html|archivedate=26 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> it is forbidden to smoke in all public indoor spaces, including bars, cafés, restaurants and discos. However, special smoking rooms are allowed. In such areas food can be served, but they are subjected to strict conditions: they need to be separately ventilated, with high air replacement rates; their air pressure must constantly be lower than the pressure in the surrounding rooms; they must be equipped with automatic sliding doors to prevent smoke from spreading to tobacco-free areas; they may occupy at most 50% of the establishment. Only 1% of all public establishments have opted for setting up a smoking room. Smoking is also forbidden in all enclosed workplaces – this includes also trains and underground stations. It is, indeed, permitted to smoke outdoors, which means that since Italy has sunny weather more than half of the year, people can still smoke at restaurants and bars as long as they sit at the outside tables and the establishment permits it.
===Ivory Coast=== Ivory Coast has a smoking ban in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/cote-divoire/summary|title=Cote d'Ivoire Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093055/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/cote-divoire/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Jamaica=== {{Main|Smoking in Jamaica}} Smoking is not permitted in the airport or generally indoors at shops and malls and places of business. However smoking is usually permitted in bars, discos and other licensed premises that serve alcohol indoors, but not in restaurants or casinos. Smoking is often permitted in tourist resorts in places that would be typically considered indoors in North America (roof but no walls), but this does not apply to indoor air-conditioned places. Jamaica has no national smoke-free law, but most places have a no-smoking sign if smoking is not permitted and it is open-air with a roof. Most places that permit smoking indoors will have ashtrays on the table to signify that it is permitted. However, if there is a sandbox at the entrance of a building then it usually signals that the place you are entering does not permit indoor smoking.
Effective 15 July 2013, Jamaica's Health Minister banned smoking in all covered public places on the island.
===Japan=== {{Main|Smoking in Japan}} Although there are no consistent nationwide smoke-free regulations in Japan, and all moves to introduce such reforms are strongly opposed by the powerful [[Lobbying|lobby]] groups, there are a growing number of local ordinances restricting smoking. Smoking is forbidden on the streets of the [[Chiyoda, Tokyo|Chiyoda]], [[Shinagawa, Tokyo|Shinagawa]], [[Shinjuku, Tokyo|Shinjuku]] and [[Nakano, Tokyo|Nakano]] wards of Tokyo<ref>{{Cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/2292007.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Smoking ban on Tokyo's streets | date=2 October 2002 | accessdate=4 April 2010 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060525020519/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/2292007.stm | archivedate=25 May 2006 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> for reasons of child safety (not health). Smoking is prohibited on public transport and subway platforms, while above ground train station platforms typically have smoking areas. Unlike Tokyo wards' ability to fine people for smoking on the streets, public transportation companies don't have the authority to enforce no smoking rules. Due to this inability, there are smokers not respecting no smoking rules, in some cases on a very frequent basis such as at Minami Urawa station in Saitama Prefecture, adjacent to Tokyo. [[Kanagawa Prefecture]] has implemented in April 2010 the nation's first prefecture-wide smoking ban, banning smoking in public facilities, including hospitals, schools and government offices. The ordinance requires large restaurants and hotels to choose whether to become nonsmoking or create separate smoking areas, while [[mah-jong]] and [[pachinko]] parlours, restaurants with floor space of up to 100 sq. meters and hotels of up to 700 sq. metres are merely required to "make efforts" to reduce [[second-hand smoke]]. Another Kanagawa ordinance to restrict smoking at swimming beaches was expected to be implemented in May 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100402a5.html |title=Kanagawa enforces first antismoking code | The Japan Times Online |publisher=Search.japantimes.co.jp |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607134219/http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100402a5.html |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Although still relatively few, there are a growing number of private businesses implementing voluntary smoking restrictions bans in restaurants, taxis, buildings and bars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.wa-shoi.com/?page=100595 |title=Wa-Shoi.com |publisher=En.wa-shoi.com |date= |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815164615/http://en.wa-shoi.com/?page=100595 |archivedate=15 August 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/7083.php |title=Noose tightening on Japanese smokers |publisher=Medicalnewstoday.com |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611054406/http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/7083.php |archivedate=11 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2017, Japan experienced pressure from the International Olympics Committee (IOC) to implement smoking bans in all public areas to offer for healthy sporting environment. Japan are planning to host the 2020 Summer Olympics and are risking to be the unhealthiest country to host the Olympics in years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-smokingban-idUSKBN17X2J8|title=Japan wrestles over smoking ban as Olympics loom|date=2 May 2017|accessdate=27 November 2017|agency=Reuters|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201042222/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-smokingban-idUSKBN17X2J8|archivedate=1 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Jersey=== Smoking is restricted in public places in [[Jersey]] (a [[British Islands|British]] [[Crown dependency]]).
The ''Restriction on Smoking (Jersey) Law 1973''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerseylegalinfo.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce/consolidated/superseded/20/20.825_restrictiononsmokinglaw1973_revisededition_31august2004.htm |title=Jersey Smoking Law |publisher=Jerseylegalinfo.je |date=20 March 2009 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927024120/http://www.jerseylegalinfo.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2Fsuperseded%2F20%2F20.825_restrictiononsmokinglaw1973_revisededition_31august2004.htm |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> enabled the [[States of Jersey]] to pass regulations prohibiting or restricting smoking in places of entertainment and public transport. In pursuance of this law, smoking was banned on public transport by the ''Smoking (Public Transport) (Jersey) Regulations 1982''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerseylegalinfo.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce/consolidated/superseded/20/20.825.30_restrictiononsmoking(publictransport)regs.1982_revisededition_31august2004.htm |title=Jersey Regulations |publisher=Jerseylegalinfo.je |date=20 March 2009 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929090703/http://www.jerseylegalinfo.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2Fsuperseded%2F20%2F20.825.30_restrictiononsmoking%28publictransport%29regs.1982_revisededition_31august2004.htm |archivedate=29 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The ''Restriction on Smoking (Jersey) Law 1973'' was amended by the ''Restriction on Smoking (Amendment No. 2) (Jersey) Law 2006''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerseylegalinfo.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fhtm%2fLawFiles%2f2006%2fL-24-2006.htm |title=Jersey Law | RESTRICTION ON SMOKING (AMENDMENT NO. 2) (JERSEY) LAW 2006 |publisher=Jerseylegalinfo.je |date=23 November 2006 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927024025/http://www.jerseylegalinfo.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fhtm%2fLawFiles%2f2006%2fL-24-2006.htm |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> adopted 16 May 2006 that enabled the States to make regulations that prohibit or restrict smoking tobacco or a substance (or a mixture of substances) other than tobacco, or the use of tobacco, in a workplace or other defined places.
===Jordan=== "Smoking is banned in hospitals, health centers, schools, cinemas, theaters, public libraries, museums, governmental and non-governmental public premises, means of transportation, arrivals and departures halls at airports, enclosed stadiums, lecture-halls".<ref>{{cite news|title=Jordan Details – Tobacco Control Laws|url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/jordan/summary|work=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170523035049/http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/jordan/summary|archivedate=23 May 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 14 April 2015, three coffee shops closed for violating smoking ban laws and their owners went to court.<ref>{{cite news|title=Three coffee shops closed for violating smoking ban|url=http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/three-coffee-shops-closed-violating-smoking-ban|work=Jordan Times|date=14 April 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171223044002/http://www.jordantimes.com/news/local/three-coffee-shops-closed-violating-smoking-ban|archivedate=23 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Kazakhstan=== Kazakhstan partially restricted smoking in public places on 1 April 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tobacco.org/articles/country/kazakhstan/?top_only=1 |title=Articles:Listing Kazakhstan |publisher=Tobacco.org |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927115708/http://www.tobacco.org/articles/country/kazakhstan/?top_only=1 |archivedate=27 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A comprehensive smoke-free law was instituted in September 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Kazakhstan bans public smoking, raises drinking age|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=29 September 2009|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j-NAuAgHUsedOw6RSuV_07PHo-5g|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225215738/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j-NAuAgHUsedOw6RSuV_07PHo-5g|archivedate=25 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Enforcing the smoke-free law appears to be somewhat problematic as far as public bus services are concerned. While smoking by passengers on the public bus services was never an issue, bus operators on duty were being consistently reported as smoking inside the bus vehicles and persistently ignoring requests by the passengers not to do so.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.respublika-kaz.info/news/society/9121/ |title=Алматинские потомки японских камикадзе – Общество – Информационно-аналитический портал РЕСПУБЛИКА |publisher=Respublika-kaz.info |date=22 May 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227195712/http://www.respublika-kaz.info/news/society/9121/ |archivedate=27 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Kenya=== Smoking in public indoor areas is restricted in [[Nairobi]], Kenya, since July 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L11808541.htm |title=Reuters AlertNet – Kenyan capital Nairobi starts smoking ban |publisher=Alertnet.org |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108133109/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L11808541.htm |archivedate=8 January 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Small private bars will be exempted. [[Mombasa]] already has a similar pre-existing smoke-free ordinance.
===Kuwait=== Kuwait has outlawed smoking indoors in public places as of 2012, including restaurants, cafes and hotels, but exempting shisha parlours.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lyon |first=Charlie |url=http://www.hoteliermiddleeast.com/13687-kuwait-smoking-ban-good-for-restaurant-business/ |title=Kuwait smoking ban 'good for restaurant business' |publisher=HotelierMiddleEast.com |date=26 February 2012 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924044620/http://www.hoteliermiddleeast.com/13687-kuwait-smoking-ban-good-for-restaurant-business/ |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2015, Kuwait's General Traffic Department considered banning smoking when driving, which is considered the major cause of accidents in Kuwait.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kuwait: smoking ban in malls implemented – violators may expect fines {{!}} WHO FCTC Implementation Database|url=http://apps.who.int/fctc/implementation/database/groups/kuwait-smoking-ban-malls-implemented-–-violators-may-expect-fines|work=apps.who.int|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511140142/http://apps.who.int/fctc/implementation/database/groups/kuwait-smoking-ban-malls-implemented-%E2%80%93-violators-may-expect-fines|archivedate=11 May 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In February 2016, smoking in malls was banned and fine of 50KD for the first time and 100 KD for the second time getting caught. While the owner of restaurants and cafes inside the malls could face a fine of 5000KD if someone is caught smoking inside their facilities.<ref>{{cite news|title=Smoking Banned in Malls Starting This Week|url=http://248am.com/mark/information/smoking-banned-in-malls-starting-this-week/|work=2:48AM – Everything Kuwait|date=21 February 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171223043258/http://248am.com/mark/information/smoking-banned-in-malls-starting-this-week/|archivedate=23 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Latvia=== As of 1 May 2010, smoking has been completely outlawed in restaurants and bars. Previously non-smoking areas had to be larger than half of the total area of the establishment. In addition, more than half of the summer terraces of bars and restaurants are required to be smoke-free. Smoking is also restricted in parks and for ten metres around entrances of public buildings as well as public transportation stops. Smoking on public transportation, except for ferries, is also forbidden.
In late 2011 some municipalities, for example, [[Ozolnieku novads]], prohibited smoking on balconies and by open windows in apartment blocks and others multi-storey buildings.
In late 2014 amendments to the law considering smoking ban took effect and included whole areas surrounding educational institutions, apartment building balconies, entrances and staircases as prohibited areas where smoking is not allowed. Also additions to law states that every person, located in the vicinity of the smoker, now are given rights to ask the smoker to extinguish the cigarette at once upon request. Smoking in vicinity of underage children is now classified as child abuse, and punished respectively.
===Liechtenstein=== There have been several smoking bans put into place. These include the restriction of smoking in government buildings, places of employment, and all forms of public transportation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rauchverbotweltweit.de/smokingban.php?land=Liechtenstein|title=Smoking ban in Liechtenstein|last=|first=|date=|website=en.rauchverbotweltweit.de|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170514185214/http://en.rauchverbotweltweit.de/smokingban.php?land=Liechtenstein|archivedate=14 May 2017|deadurl=no|accessdate=11 November 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In March of 2009, Liechtenstein held a public vote to ban smoking in restaurants. However, the ban was strongly opposed with over 80% of the voters opposing the ban.<ref>[[Dieter Nohlen]] & Philip Stöver (2010) ''Elections in Europe: A data handbook'', p 2057 {{ISBN|978-3-8329-5609-7}}</ref>
===Lithuania=== Smoking has been restricted in restaurants, bars, places where food is served, clubs (except for special cigar and pipe clubs), and nightclubs since 1 January 2007. Furthermore, smoking on public transportation is forbidden (except on long-distance trains with special facilities), and workplaces inside a building (except designated places). It is also illegal to smoke inside public halls where non-smoking people might have to breathe tobacco fumes. The law is well respected (at least in the largest cities) but smoking in hallways and staircases is still common. The age restriction is 18 years old.
===Lebanon=== {{main|Smoking in Lebanon}} As of 3 September 2012, smoking has been prohibited in enclosed public places such as restaurants, cafes, and hotel. Anybody violating this ban will be charged with a fine of over $100, and the restaurant, the cafe or the hotel will be charged with a fine between $1300 and $4000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blogger.com/blogger.g?blogID=2354743938494310251#editor/target=post;postID=2455717628525252480|title=Blogger|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref>
===Luxembourg=== Smoking is prohibited in all indoor public places, like hospitals, shopping centres, schools and restaurants. However, cafés and bars that only serve snacks are exempt. There is a smoking prohibition from 12 noon to 14:00h and 19:00h to 21:00h in cafés where meals are served. From 1 January 2014, the smoking ban will also cover all cafés and bars, except in specially ventilated smoking rooms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guichet.public.lu/entreprises/fr/commerce/horeca/cafe/debit-boissons/|title=Gestion d'un débit de boissons (café, salon de consommation, etc.) – Entreprises // Luxembourg|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160515051233/http://www.guichet.public.lu/entreprises/fr/commerce/horeca/cafe/debit-boissons/|archivedate=15 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As of 13 August 2017, smoking is prohibited in playgrounds, sporting venues in which under 16s will be playing and private vehicles in which under 12s are present. The law was also changed to prohibit under 18s from purchasing tobacco and to treat e-cigarettes in the same fashion as tobacco. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sante.public.lu/fr/actualites/2017/08/nouvelle-loi-anti-tabac/index.html|title=La nouvelle loi anti-tabac entre en vigueur: qu'est-ce qui changera à partir du 1er août 2017?|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817034424/http://www.sante.public.lu/fr/actualites/2017/08/nouvelle-loi-anti-tabac/index.html|archivedate=17 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Macedonia=== Macedonia has a comprehensive national smoke-free law covering all public indoor areas, and in some cases in outdoor areas. Smoking is prohibited in bars, cafes, restaurants, and nightclubs starting 1 January 2010.<ref name="SETimes"> {{Cite news |title = Business: Railway line making a comeback |url = http://www.setimes.com/cocoon/setimes/xhtml/en_GB/features/setimes/roundup/2009/10/23/roundup-bs-03 |publisher = SETimes.com |date = 23 October 2009 |accessdate = 23 October 2009 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091031204354/http://www.setimes.com/cocoon/setimes/xhtml/en_GB/features/setimes/roundup/2009/10/23/roundup-bs-03 |archivedate = 31 October 2009 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Smoking is permitted only in people's homes, at open spaces and public areas free of sporting competitions, cultural and entertainment events, gatherings and other public events.<ref name="MINA"> {{Cite news |title = Business: Macedonia's Smoking Ban Obeyed |url = http://macedoniaonline.eu/content/view/11591/2/ |publisher = MINA |date = 4 January 2010 |accessdate = 4 January 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120301211119/http://macedoniaonline.eu/content/view/11591/2/ |archivedate = 1 March 2012 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
===Madagascar=== By official law, smoking is prohibited in [[taxi-brousse]]s, but this is not enforced. The only transport environments in which smoking is prohibited are Antananarivo International Airport and on Air Madagascar flights. It is also forbidden to smoke in pubs and clubs.
===Malawi=== No smoke-free ordinance is in place, nor is one planned (December 2012)
===Malta=== In April 2004, smoking was restricted in all enclosed public spaces, including public transportation, clubs and restaurants, although smoking areas are allowed.
===Malaysia=== In all, 21 areas are smoke-free, including hospitals/clinics, airports, public lifts and toilets, air-conditioned restaurants, public transport, government premises, educational institutions, petrol stations, Internet cafes, shopping complexes and private office spaces with central air-conditioning. However, enforcement is lax, and the government claims to have plans to get tougher on offenders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2007/6/17/nation/18052672&sec=nation |title=Smoking ban to be extended |work=Toronto Star .my |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622040833/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2007%2F6%2F17%2Fnation%2F18052672&sec=nation |archivedate=22 June 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.e-sheesh.com/tobacco_use|title=Tobacco Use|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818104800/http://www.e-sheesh.com/tobacco_use|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Starting 1 June 2010, it is an offence to smoke at private office spaces with central air-conditioning. People who violate the rules can be fined up to RM10,000 (US$3,333), or two years of imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2010/6/1/nation/6374646&sec=nation |title=No more puffing away at work |work=Toronto Star .my |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622040903/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2010%2F6%2F1%2Fnation%2F6374646&sec=nation |archivedate=22 June 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Mauritius=== Since 1 March 2009, smoking is completely prohibited in all public places, workplaces and inside vehicles if they are carrying people other than the driver.
===Mexico=== Smoking in hospitals and airports has been restricted for at least 15 years. Smoking is allowed in designated areas at the Cancun Airport, although there are no longer any smoking areas within the international terminal. Mexico City's current smoking policy, passed in April 2004, requires physically separate smoking and non-smoking areas, and for non-smoking areas to make up at least 30% of all space in restaurants and bars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://no-smoking.org/april04/04-07-04-2.html |title=Mexico City Imposes Tougher Smoking Laws (7 April 2004) |publisher=No-smoking.org |date=25 October 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120713082925/http://no-smoking.org/april04/04-07-04-2.html |archivedate=13 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A proposal debated early in 2007 to extend Mexico City's smoking policy to provide completely smoke-free restaurants, bars, schools, taxis, and buses, did not pass.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-mexsmoke29jun29,0,4368264.story?coll=la-home-center Mexican Smoking Bans] ''Los Angeles Times''</ref> It was proposed again in the middle of 2007.
Since April 2008 the law has covered Mexico City, and since 28 August 2008 the law has been extended nationwide, although now some restaurants and other public places have the same designated areas for smokers as those that existed before the introduction of the law. Some bars and clubs continue to tolerate illegal indoor smoking at night, regardless of the law.
Advertisement of tobacco products has been barred from TV and radio for approximately 6 years.
===Monaco=== There has been a smoke-free law pertaining to public indoor places in Monaco since 1 November 2008, including bars, restaurants and nightclubs.
===Montenegro=== Smoking in public places is prohibited in Montenegro, unless you obtain a smoking permit from the government. Most cafes and bars in Montenegro continue to permit smoking on the premises, although several organizations like https://www.facebook.com/smokefreemontenegro are putting pressure on more local businesses to forbid smoking indoors. The law also forbids smoking advertising and the display of people smoking on television.<ref>{{Cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3527234.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Montenegro bans smoking in public | date=2 August 2004 | accessdate=4 April 2010 | first=Matt | last=Prodger | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110113055040/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3527234.stm | archivedate=13 January 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Morocco=== Morocco's House of Representatives unanimously passed a smoke-free law pertaining to public places.{{when|date=July 2014}}
===Mozambique=== Since 2007, smoking has been restricted in indoor public places including public transport, government buildings, schools, hospitals, libraries, cinemas, theatres, restaurants and bars, with the exception of specially designated smoking rooms.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogsofbainbridge.typepad.com/francisco/2007/11/smoking-banned.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20080331113900/http://blogsofbainbridge.typepad.com/francisco/2007/11/smoking-banned.html |archivedate=31 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Blog of Francisco Cabo</ref><ref>[http://blogsofbainbridge.typepad.com/jackie/2007/12/mozambique-bans.html#more] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090615140341/http://blogsofbainbridge.typepad.com/jackie/2007/12/mozambique-bans.html|date=15 June 2009}} Blog of Jackie Tumwine</ref>
===Myanmar=== Myanmar has a smoking ban in place for certain public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/myanmar/summary|title=Myanmar Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093120/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/myanmar/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Namibia=== On 8 October 2009, the Namibian National Assembly adopted the Tobacco Products Control Bill, potentially one of the most comprehensive smoke-free ordinances. The law, (once implemented) will prohibit "the smoking of tobacco in a public place, any outdoor public place or any area within a certain distance of a window, ventilation inlet, door or entrance". The bill was voted into law on 16 February 2010, became effective on 1 April 2014, and a public ban on smoking was in effect by 1 July 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.az.com.na/politik/grnes-licht-fr-gesetzentwurf.102269.php |title=Namibian Newspaper |publisher=Az.com.na |date=17 February 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722235215/http://www.az.com.na/politik/grnes-licht-fr-gesetzentwurf.102269.php |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.gov.na/bills_documents/44_tobacco_products_control_bill_b7-2009.pdf |title=B7-2009 Tobacco Control |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111207160046/http://www.parliament.gov.na/bills_documents/44_tobacco_products_control_bill_b7-2009.pdf |archivedate=7 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://sun.com.na/business/no-public-smoking-after-july-1.63824 |title=Namibian Newspaper |publisher=sun.com.na |date=13 March 2014 |accessdate=28 August 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905014600/http://sun.com.na/business/no-public-smoking-after-july-1.63824 |archivedate=5 September 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Nepal=== Nepal Government implemented a smoke-free law covering public places, effective from 7 August 2011. The Tobacco (Control and Regulatory) Act restricts smoking in airports, hotels, restaurants, government offices and other public places. The act also makes it obligatory for tobacco product manufacturers to ensure that product packs carry graphic warnings about the adverse effects of smoking and the harmful ingredients the products contain. The warnings should cover at least 75% of the total pack area.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/ITC-subsidiary-faces-double-whammy-in-Nepal/articleshow/9684569.cms |work=The Times Of India |title=ITC subsidiary faces double whammy in Nepal – The Times of India |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822134006/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/ITC-subsidiary-faces-double-whammy-in-Nepal/articleshow/9684569.cms |archivedate=22 August 2011 }}</ref> The act also prohibits sales of tobacco products to pregnant women and people below the age of 18.
The Tobacco Control and Regulation Act-2068 was signed by President Dr. Ram Baran Yadav on 29 April.
The Act includes provisions for officials to inspect implementation of the new law. A fine of Rs 100-100,000 will be slapped on anyone who smokes in public places or sells tobacco products to people below 18 or to pregnant women.
===Netherlands=== The smoking of tobacco is prohibited by law in all public buildings and on public transport. On railway platforms, the limited smoking areas are not enforced. As of 1 January 2004, every employee has the right to work in a smoke-free environment. Tobacco legislation states that employers are obliged to take measures to ensure that employees are able to carry out their work without being bothered or affected by secondhand smoke from other people. On 1 January 2008, [[Amsterdam Airport Schiphol]] became the first completely smoke-free European airport{{Citation needed|reason=Surely Irish airports were smoke-free in 2004?|date=September 2016}}; however, since August 2008; smoking has been permitted in designated smoking rooms. Since 1 July 2008, the smoke-free law has also applied to all hotels, restaurants, bars and cafes in the Netherlands. Separate smoking rooms are allowed in hospitality facilities as long as no food or beverage is served there, although the court banned them as of February 2018. All forms of tobacco advertising, promotion or sponsorship are prohibited. Smoking of [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] (including [[hashish]]) in coffeeshops is permitted as long as it is not mixed with tobacco. In 2010, the new government spoke out against the effects of the smoke-free law upon small catering businesses. The law was widely ignored with statistics showing that around 41% of bars and discos had flouted it.<ref name="BT">{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/smoking-ban-uturn-by-dutch-government-14995132.html |title=Smoking ban U-turn by Dutch government, Belfast Telegraph, 4 November 2010 |publisher=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk |date=4 November 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref> On 3 November 2010, the new government lifted the smoke-free regulations for bars of 70 square metres or less, on the condition that the bar did not employ any staff other than the owner.<ref name="BT"/> Around 3,000 of the 5,500 bars in the Netherlands are staffed by the owner alone.<ref name="BT"/>
On 12 February 2013, the Dutch [[Tweede Kamer|lower house]] agreed on a total ban in the hospitality sector with 77-73, with no exception for smaller, owner-operated bars. Special smoking rooms without service were not affected by the change in the law.
Since 1 January 2017, smoking rooms are no longer to be allowed in city hall and other municipal buildings of Amsterdam and within a 20-meter distance of these buildings.<ref name="AMS">{{cite web |url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/4/AMSTERDAM/article/detail/4238510/2016/02/04/Amsterdam-moet-minder-roken.dhtml |title=Amsterdam moet minder roken, Parool, 4 February 2016 |publisher=Parool.nl |date=4 February 2016 |accessdate=14 February 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216120408/http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/4/AMSTERDAM/article/detail/4238510/2016/02/04/Amsterdam-moet-minder-roken.dhtml |archivedate=16 February 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 13 February 2018, the court in [[The Hague]] decided that smoking rooms are no longer legal in pubs, clubs and restaurants. [https://www.rechtspraak.nl/Organisatie-en-contact/Organisatie/Gerechtshoven/Gerechtshof-Den-Haag/Nieuws/Paginas/Rookruimtes-in-horeca-niet-toegestaan.aspx]
===New Zealand=== {{Main|Smoking in New Zealand}} [[File:'Cancer', 1958 (17909231579).jpg|thumb|Prevention poster, New Zealand Department of Health, 1958.]]
The first building in the world to have a smoke-free policy was the [[Old Government Buildings (Wellington)|Old Government Building]] in [[Wellington, New Zealand]], in 1876. This was over concerns about the threat of fire, as it is the second largest wooden building in the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=Historic Government Buildings|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/conservation/historic/by-region/wellington-kapiti/wellington/government-buildings/|publisher=Department of Conservation|accessdate=3 February 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130210022222/http://doc.govt.nz/conservation/historic/by-region/wellington-kapiti/wellington/government-buildings/|archivedate=10 February 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
New Zealand passed an amendment to the [[Smoke-free Environments Act 1990]] law on 3 December 2003 (effective in 2004) that covers all indoor public workplaces and inside hospitality venues (pubs, bars, restaurants and casinos). Studies have shown very high levels of compliance with the law. Also the air quality inside hospitality venues is very good compared to similar settings in other countries where smoking is still permitted. In New Zealand, tobacco and tobacco products cannot be sold or supplied to anyone under 18.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/smokefreelaw |title=Smokefree Law |publisher=Moh.govt.nz |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129001044/http://www.moh.govt.nz/smokefreelaw |archivedate=29 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Outdoor smoke-free laws cover the grounds of all schools, the grounds of some hospitals, stadiums and two university campuses (Massey University, and the [[University of Auckland]], in 2010). Victoria University of Wellington has restricted smoking rules with specified areas where one may smoke. The government has not moved to restrict smoking in cars but has run mass media campaigns that promote smoke-free cars and homes.
There are also increasing numbers of local councils implementing educative smokefree policies. South Taranaki District Council was the first. In May 2005 the Council made its playgrounds, parks and swimming pools smokefree, as well as ensuring that all Council events held in South Taranaki parks were to be promoted as smoke-free events and in May 2006 the [[Upper Hutt]] city council followed suit and declared all "open areas for which members of the public gather" (i.e., parks, playgrounds, pools) smoke-free however this by-law lacks in enforcement other than a polite request by city council officials and [[Security Guards]] (rather than confiscation and court penalty). At least 19 of New Zealand's other Councils have followed suit. (Source: www.smokefreecouncils.org.nz).
On 5 September 2007, [[Action on Smoking and Health]] (ASH) New Zealand called for the removal of tobacco from sale by 2017.<ref>[http://www.ash.org.nz/index.php?pa_id=4&news_id=159&expand_section=1 Welcome to ASH – Action on Smoking and Health] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090610024556/http://www.ash.org.nz/index.php?pa_id=4&news_id=159&expand_section=1 |date=10 June 2009 }}</ref> The Government wants to be smokefree by 2025.<ref name="stuff.co.nz">{{cite web|author=Jody O'Callaghan |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/taranaki-daily-news/features/6822327/Running-out-of-puff |title=Running out of puff |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date= |accessdate=14 January 2013}}</ref>
===Nigeria=== {{Main|Smoking in Nigeria}} Smoking is prohibited in public places in [[Lagos]], Nigeria, and is punishable by a fine of not less than N200 and not exceeding N1000 or to imprisonment to a term of not less than one month and not exceeding two years or to both such fine and imprisonment.<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200806030435.html Nigeria: Smoking – Top Officials Defy Govt Order] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080606225206/http://allafrica.com/stories/200806030435.html |date=6 June 2008 }} Leadership, 3 June 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.afriquenligne.fr/news/africa-news/nigeria's-capital-city-bans-smoking-in-public-200806015574.html Nigeria's capital city bans smoking in public] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080604034925/http://www.afriquenligne.fr/news/africa-news/nigeria's-capital-city-bans-smoking-in-public-200806015574.html |date=4 June 2008 }} Afrique en ligne, 1 June 2008</ref>
===Norway=== ''Main article: [[Smoking in Norway]]''
In Norway, smoking has been restricted in public buildings, workplaces and public transportation since 1988, often allowing for separate, walled-off smoking areas of restaurants, pubs, etc. Since 1 June 2004, smoking has been prohibited in all indoor public areas. Outside some places this ban includes the immediate area surrounding the doorways, etc.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Norwegians ban smoking in bars |publisher=BBC News |date=1 June 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3765071.stm |accessdate=23 December 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226161606/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3765071.stm |archivedate=26 February 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visitnorway.com/uk/Articles/Corporate/Before-you-go/Smoking-restrictions/ |title=Smoking restrictions in Norway |date=7 August 2008 |work=[[Innovation Norway]] |publisher=|accessdate=23 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|title=Norway’s ban on smoking in bars and restaurants – A review of the first year|publisher=Directorate for Health and Social Affairs|date=May 2005|pages=|url=http://www.helsedirektoratet.no/vp/multimedia/archive/00003/Norway_s_ban_on_smoki_3413a.pdf|format=PDF|version=IS-1275 E|accessdate=23 December 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720000343/http://www.helsedirektoratet.no/vp/multimedia/archive/00003/Norway_s_ban_on_smoki_3413a.pdf|archivedate=20 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Advertising for tobacco has been illegal by law since 1975 (The tobacco related damage protection act). The smoking ban also includes vaping since 1 July 2017.
===Panama=== As of 2008, smoking is prohibited at all restaurants, bars, and dance clubs, outdoor dining areas, balconies, and indoor areas such as transport terminals and areas that locals would consider a workplace.
===Paraguay=== Effective April 2010, Paraguay has restricted smoking in all indoor areas including bars and restaurants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/health1/paraguay-bans-smoking-in-all-closed-public-spaces_100346455.html |title=Paraguay bans smoking in all ‘closed public spaces’ |publisher=Thaindian.com |date=11 April 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318122734/http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/health1/paraguay-bans-smoking-in-all-closed-public-spaces_100346455.html |archivedate=18 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Pakistan=== The Prohibition of Smoking and Protection of Non-Smokers Health Ordinance-2002 came into effect on 30 June 2003. The law had the following aspnects: restriction upon tobacco use in public buildings and transportation, limiting tobacco advertising, prohibiting tobacco sale within 50 metres of educational institutions, and requiring "no smoking" signs displayed in public places, public buildings and transportation, limiting tobacco advertising.
===Peru=== In Peru, it is illegal to smoke in any enclosed public place (inc public transport), according to Law 25357, since December 1993. This has been re-inforced with the Anti-Tobacco Law 28705 and 29517.
===Philippines=== ''Main article: [[Smoking in the Philippines]]''
[[Davao City|Davao]] has prohibited smoking in a large number of public places, including public buildings, entertainment venues, hospitals, shopping malls, concerts since 2002. Smoking at gasoline stations is also banned.<ref>{{cite web |author=Virgilio M Gaje |url=http://www.pia.gov.ph/?m=12&sec=reader&rp=1&fi=p060627.htm&no=3&date= |title=PIA Information Services – Philippine Information Agency |publisher=Pia.gov.ph |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611095335/http://www.pia.gov.ph/?m=12&sec=reader&rp=1&fi=p060627.htm&no=3&date= |archivedate=11 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Manila]] has restricted smoking in large public areas like hospitals, malls, public transport, as well as [[Makati]] in 2002 Ordinance 2002-090, banning all public transport and enclosed indoor smoking.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.makati.gov.ph/ |title=(Philippines) government news bulletin |publisher=Makati |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110214000210/http://www.makati.gov.ph/ |archivedate=14 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> After many attempts, finally in June 2011 Metro Manila banned smoking with heavy penalties including community service time for offenders, after 3 months the ban seems to be well respected.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mb.com.ph/node/331193/public- |title=Public smoking ban stays – MMDA | The Manila Bulletin Newspaper Online |publisher=Mb.com.ph |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713043705/http://www.mb.com.ph/node/331193/public- |archivedate=13 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
President Duterte has ordered a strict smoking ban, [[Nationwide smoking ban order (Philippines)|Executive Order 26]], forbidding tobacco and e-cigarette use in all public spaces. No one under 18 can use, sell or buy cigarettes or tobacco products. Tobacco cannot be sold where children might gather and be kept 100 meters from schools and playgrounds. Citizens are encouraged to help apprehend violators. Those who violate the ban could face up to four months in jail and a fine of 5,000 pesos (around $100). As of 2017, a pack of cigarettes is still cheap, costing about 27 pesos (54 cents) and more than 74 percent of that is taxes.<ref>{{cite web |author=Fellipe Villamormay |publisher=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/18/world/asia/rodrigo-duterte-smoking-ban-philippines.html?mcubz=0 |title=Duterte Orders Strict Smoking Ban in Philippines, and Asks Citizens to Help |date=18 May 2017 |accessdate=1 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170801170317/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/18/world/asia/rodrigo-duterte-smoking-ban-philippines.html?mcubz=0 |archivedate=1 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Poland=== Smoking is prohibited in schools, hospitals or other medical facilities and public transport (including the vehicles such as train or bus and bus stops, train stations, etc. within the 10 metres radius).
In March 2010, an attempt to introduce a complete smokefree law failed.
Since 1 January 2011, it is forbidden to smoke in indoor workplaces, and all public indoor spaces, including public offices, museums, bars, cafés, discos, shops or restaurants smaller than 100 square metres.
