In larger restaurants enclosed smoking areas are permitted, provided they are physically separated and properly ventilated.<ref>{{cite web |author=Agnes Sekowski, The Krakow Post |url=http://sofiaecho.com/2010/11/09/990229_poland-smoking-ban-economics |title=Poland: smoking ban economics – Foreign |publisher=The Sofia Echo |date=9 November 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110108075806/http://sofiaecho.com/2010/11/09/990229_poland-smoking-ban-economics |archivedate=8 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Smoking is also prohibited in venues for cultural and sporting events.
===Portugal=== Portuguese Law 37/2007 (in force since 1 January 2008) governs various aspects of the consumption, sale and control of tobacco in Portugal, and lists a large number of enclosed spaces where smoking is not permitted, including such obvious cases as schools, hospitals and theatres. The law states that exceptions to the no-smoking rule may be made in the cases, inter alia, of enclosed eating and drinking establishments (i.e. restaurants, cafes and bars) not frequented by under-18s if the smoking area is physically separated from the non-smoking area or where ventilation and air extraction systems directed towards the exterior are effective to the point of preventing smoke from entering the non-smoking area, and that in the case of establishments with a floor area of more than 100 square metres no more than 40% (if physically separated) or 30% otherwise may be designated a smoking area. In effect, restaurants are almost always smoke-free as are most cafes whose trade is mainly for food, whereas in bars the law is ignored by customers and bar owners alike. A study published in 2011 by the Ministry of Health showed 90% compliance with the law in establishments with a total smoking ban, but only 50% compliance in establishments where smoking is partly or wholly permitted (i.e., most bars). <ref>Infotabac Relatório page 71 {{cite web |url=http://www.dgs.pt/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111217004817/http://www.dgs.pt/ |archivedate=17 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://antt.dgarq.gov.pt/files/2008/10/37_2007.pdf|title=Diário da República, 1a. série, No. 156, 14 de Agosto de 2007, Lei 37/2007 de 14 de Agosto|publisher=Imprensa Nacional (PDF)|date=|accessdate=9 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120192430/http://antt.dgarq.gov.pt/files/2008/10/37_2007.pdf|archivedate=20 January 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.angloinfo.com/lisbon/how-to/page/lisbon-lifestyle-entertainment-smoking-law|title=Smoking & Tobacco Law in Portugal|date=|publisher=[[Angloinfo]]|accessdate=15 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808092633/https://www.angloinfo.com/lisbon/how-to/page/lisbon-lifestyle-entertainment-smoking-law|archivedate=8 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Puerto Rico=== The Law No. 40 from 1993, the ''Law to Regulate the Smoking Practice in Public Places'', and its later 1996 amendment Law 133, regulate smoking in private and public places. The most recent modification established in [2 March 2007], Law 66, amended articles 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9 and 11 of Law Num. 40, forbids this practice inside jails, pubs, restaurants (including open-air terraces with one or more employees), bars, casinos, workplaces, educational institutions, cars with children under age 13 and most public places. Smoking sections are not allowed. Fines start at $250.
===Qatar=== The capital of Qatar, [[Doha]], restricted smoking in public or closed areas in 2002. The law discouraged shopkeepers from selling to under-aged people and completely banned tobacco advertisements in the country and punished violaters with hefty fines. However, the law is openly flouted especially by the youth.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=192251&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 |title=Gulf Times – Qatar’s top-selling English daily newspaper – Qatar |publisher=Gulf-times.com |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607103719/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=192251&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Romania=== [[File:Visieu de Jos Gara1.jpg|thumb|right|No smoking sign in a rural train station in Romania]] Smoking is banned in "indoor public places" such as schools, office buildings and public institutions, though specially designed smoking areas may be established on the premises under certain conditions. Hospitals, [[Căile Ferate Române|CFR]] passenger trains and the [[Bucharest Metro]], among others, are completely smoke-free.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.avocatnet.ro/content/articles/id_30234/Fumatul-in-spatii-publice-inchise-Cand-este-permis.html#axzz2IFbtpQIq | title=Fumatul in spatii publice inchise: Cand este permis? | date=8 September 2012 | accessdate=17 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-arhiva-1160447-cfr-interzice-fumatul-tren.htm | title=CFR interzice fumatul in tren | date=29 August 2006 | accessdate=17 January 2013 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102153410/http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-arhiva-1160447-cfr-interzice-fumatul-tren.htm | archivedate=2 November 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.9am.ro/stiri-revista-presei/Social/9658/Fumatul-la-metrou-se-amendeaza-cu-zece-milioane-de-lei.html | title=Fumatul la metrou se amendeaza cu zece milioane de lei | date=27 April 2005 | accessdate=17 January 2013 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130618092621/http://www.9am.ro/stiri-revista-presei/Social/9658/Fumatul-la-metrou-se-amendeaza-cu-zece-milioane-de-lei.html | archivedate=18 June 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Since 2011, bars and restaurants may be designated either as smoke-free or exclusively for smokers.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/fumatul-interzis-complet-in-localuri-restaurante-si-alte-spatii-inchise-933138.html | title= Senatul României a interzis complet fumatul în localuri, restaurante şi alte spaţii închise | date= 8 June 2011 | accessdate= 17 January 2013 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131102211400/http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/fumatul-interzis-complet-in-localuri-restaurante-si-alte-spatii-inchise-933138.html | archivedate= 2 November 2013 | df= dmy-all }}</ref> On 15 December 2015, the Romanian Parliament adopted a law banning smoking in public areas. The law, that came into effect on March 2016 forbids smoking in any closed environment for public use, defining a closed environment as one having at least two walls.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.gandul.info/stiri/legea-antifumat-a-fost-adoptata-spatiile-publice-in-care-va-fi-interzis-sa-aprinzi-o-tigara-14920612 |title=Legea antifumat a fost adoptata |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914075233/http://m.gandul.info/stiri/legea-antifumat-a-fost-adoptata-spatiile-publice-in-care-va-fi-interzis-sa-aprinzi-o-tigara-14920612 |archivedate=14 September 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Russia=== Russia had been highly tolerant of smoking for a long time, with almost no regulation. However, the Soviet Union had approved countrywide campaigns against smoking. <ref name="Cooper1982">{{cite journal|last1=Cooper|first1=R|title=Smoking in the Soviet Union.|journal=[[BMJ (Clin Res Ed)]]|volume=285|issue=6341|year=1982|pages=549–551|issn=0959-8138|doi=10.1136/bmj.285.6341.549|url=http://europepmc.org/articles/PMC1499048/pdf/bmjcred00621-0025.pdf|pmid=6809168|pmc=1499048|access-date=}}</ref> The law "on the protection of the population from the harmful effects of cigarette smoke and the consequences of tobacco consumption" has passed the third and final vote in the State Duma and has been effective partly from 1 July 2013 and has completely from 1 July 2014. Starting 1 June 2013, smoking in workplaces, on aircraft, trains and municipal transport as well as in schools, hospitals, cultural institutions and government buildings has been restricted and tobacco advertising and sponsorship forbidden. Graphic warnings have become compulsory. Starting 1 June 2014, smoking has also been prohibited in restaurants and cafés. Smokers will also be fined for smoking within a distance of 15 meters in front of entrances of subway stations, the airport or in children playgrounds and parks, as well as places and squares that attract many people.
===Rwanda=== Rwanda has a smoking ban in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/rwanda/summary|title=Rwanda Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093122/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/rwanda/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Saudi Arabia=== Saudi Arabia had almost no restrictions against smoking until 2010 when the [[Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia|Council of Ministers]] urged the [[General Authority of Civil Aviation]] (GACA) to restrict smoking at all airports and their facilities in the Kingdom, and strict rules were imposed. It also advised GACA to impose a fine of SR200 (US$53) on people who violate the new regulations.<ref>{{cite web |last=News |first=Arab |url=http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article70606.ece |title=Smoking banned at airports |publisher=Arab News |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627124808/http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article70606.ece |archivedate=27 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Many commercial buildings and work places banned smoking at offices in an attempt to stop smoking in public places. In addition, [[King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals]] in [[Dhahran]], for instance, launched a program in 2010 to make their university smoke-free, and [[Umm al-Qura University]] in [[Mecca]] launched a campaign with the same title{{clarify|date=November 2015}} in 2011.<ref>[http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article571987.ece] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209083100/http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article571987.ece|date=9 February 2012}}</ref> In May 2012, [[King Faisal Specialist Hospital and Research Centre]] in [[Riyadh]] banned people from smoking in and around its buildings, the first such move in the country. The hospital implemented fines of SR200 for violations.
On 30 July 2012, [[Ministry of Interior (Saudi Arabia)|Interior Minister]] Prince [[Ahmed bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|Ahmed bin Abdulaziz]] ordered the implementation of a royal ban on smoking in all government facilities (ministries, buildings, institutions, offices etc.)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/saudi-arabia-stresses-ban-on-public-smoking-1.1056087 |title=Saudi Arabia stresses ban on public smoking |publisher=gulfnews.com |date=1 August 2012 |accessdate=11 March 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130122145418/http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/saudi-arabia-stresses-ban-on-public-smoking-1.1056087 |archivedate=22 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and most indoor public places. The ban also prohibits smoking of [[hookah]]s in public places, and prohibits selling tobacco to anyone under 18.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/30/saudi-arabia-stubs-out-smoking |title=Saudi Arabia stubs out smoking in public places |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 July 2012 |accessdate=11 March 2013 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113042821/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/30/saudi-arabia-stubs-out-smoking |archivedate=13 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/30/saudi-arabia-smoking-ban_n_1718619.html |title=Saudi Arabia Bans Smoking In Most Public Places |publisher=[[Huffington Post]] |date=30 July 2012 |accessdate=11 March 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120802224526/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/30/saudi-arabia-smoking-ban_n_1718619.html |archivedate=2 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 1 December 2012, the [[Saudi Commission for Tourism & Antiquities]] (SCTA) imposed a ban on smoking in all tourism facilities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/riyadh-bans-smoking-in-tourist-facilities-1.1113241 |title=Riyadh bans smoking in tourist facilities |publisher=gulfnews.com |date=2 December 2012 |accessdate=11 March 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121207200313/http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/riyadh-bans-smoking-in-tourist-facilities-1.1113241 |archivedate=7 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
From 6 June 2016, smoking is prohibited in the vicinity of religious, educational, health, sport and cultural institutions, social and charity institutions. Smoking is also prohibited at private and government offices, factories, banks, public transport facilities, in areas for manufacturing and processing food products and drinks, petrol, gas and fuel distribution systems, warehouses, elevators and restrooms, in addition to several other public places. Violating the law is punishable by a fine of SAR 200, which increases for repeat violations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saudigazette.com.sa/saudi-arabia/smoking-ban-public-areas-takes-effect/|title=Smoking ban in public areas takes effect – Saudi Gazette|first=Sadiq|last=Hussain|date=13 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617191324/http://saudigazette.com.sa/saudi-arabia/smoking-ban-public-areas-takes-effect/|archivedate=17 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Serbia=== The Serbian Parliament passed a new law on public smoking in November 2010. It forbids smoking in every indoor working or public space, and any outdoor space that is a functional part of a facility connected with health care, education, or child care. This law prescribes very high fines for employers and restaurant owners who do not post smoking ban notifications. Outlets (bars, cafés, restaurants, night clubs etc.) smaller than 80 sq m can choose whether to ban smoking or not, and outlets larger than this margin have to have divided areas for smokers and non-smokers.
===Singapore=== {{Main|Smoking in Singapore}} [[Image:Singapore-smoking-area.jpg|thumb|right|150px|A sign in Singapore to indicate that smoking is allowed]] Smoking was restricted in [[hawker centre]]s, coffee-shops, cafes and fast-food outlets beginning 1 July 2006. For establishments with an outdoor area, 10–20% of the area can be set aside for smoking, although they would have to be clearly marked to avoid confusion. Gradually, the regulations have been extended to bus interchanges and shelters, public toilets and public swimming complexes.<ref>[http://app.mewr.gov.sg/view.asp?cid=168&nid=168&id=SAS765 Smoking Ban in Singapore] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003024903/http://app.mewr.gov.sg/view.asp?cid=168&nid=168&id=SAS765 |date=3 October 2006 }}</ref>
On 1 July 2007, the regulations were extended to entertainment nightspots. The rule allows for construction of designated smoking rooms that can take up to 10% of the total indoor space.
On 1 January 2009, the regulations were extended to all children's playgrounds, exercise areas, markets, underground and multi-storey carparks, ferry terminals and jetties. Coverage was also extended to non-air conditioned areas in offices, factories, shops, shopping complexes and lift lobbies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/332003/1/.html |title=Smoking ban to be extended to more areas from January 2009 |publisher=Channelnewsasia.com |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120412205058/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/332003/1/.html |archivedate=12 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Smokers found flouting the rules are fined [[S$]]200 while the owners of the establishments are fined S$200 and S$500 for a subsequent offence.
On 22 November 2010, the Towards Tobacco-Free Singapore online<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.chillybin.com.sg/portfolio/towards-tobacco-free-singapore/ |title=Towards Tobacco Free Singapore |publisher=ChillyBin WordPress Web Design |accessdate=4 March 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306163911/https://www.chillybin.com.sg/portfolio/towards-tobacco-free-singapore/ |archivedate=6 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> campaign was launched to support the initiative to phase out tobacco in Singapore by preventing the supply of tobacco to Singaporeans born from the year 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/tobaccofreesingapore/ |title=Towards Tobacco-Free Singapore | publisher=Facebook}}</ref> Social movements such as [[Tobacco Free Generation]] also exist on the island.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccofreegen.com |title=Tobacco Free Generation |publisher=Tobacco Free Generation |accessdate=4 March 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317025234/http://www.tobaccofreegen.com/ |archivedate=17 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Slovakia===
Smoking is prohibited in most indoor places. Since 2004, employers have been obliged to provide separate smoking rooms or a designated outdoor smoking place if smoking is allowed at work. Smoking is also prohibited in the majority of indoor public places. The regulations currently exempt bars that do not serve food. Restaurants are also excepted from indoor smoking restrictions. Since 2010 there has been no requirement for restaurants to have separate smoking and non-smoking areas. Smoking is also prohibited in shopping centres but a loop-hole in the law allows smoking on the balconies of cafeterias in shopping centres. Enforcement of this law is the responsibility of the Slovak Business Inspection (SOI) service.
There is also a partial restriction upon outdoor smoking, especially around railways stations and bus termini, and close to the entrances of government buildings. Local police forces are responsible for enforcing these laws, although this has on occasion been lax, reportedly due to a mix of corruption and insufficiently clear legislative requirements.
===Slovenia=== On 22 June 2007, the Slovenian National Assembly approved a law prohibiting smoking in all indoor public and work places, effective 5 August 2007. Exempted from the ban are "open public areas, special smoking hotel rooms, special smoking areas in [[elderly care]] centres and jails, and special smoking chambers in bars and other work places. The smoking chambers, which will have to meet strict technical standards, will however not be allowed to occupy more than 20% of an establishment."<ref>[http://www.ukom.gov.si/eng/slovenia/publications/slovenia-news/4994/5005/ Slovenia Gets Tough Anti-Smoking Legislation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121084844/http://www.ukom.gov.si/eng/slovenia/publications/slovenia-news/4994/5005/ |date=21 November 2007 }}</ref> The law also raised the minimum age to purchase tobacco products from 15 to 18 and mandated that tobacco labels carry the telephone number of a quit-smoking hotline.
===South Africa=== [[File:Rook Verbode Sign.JPG|thumb|Bilingual "No Smoking" sign in English and [[Afrikaans]] at a state-owned facility.]] The [[South Africa]]n government passed the first [[Tobacco Products Control Act]] in 1993 and started implementing the act in 1995. The act regulated smoking in public areas and prohibited tobacco sales to people under the age of 18. Some aspects of tobacco advertising were also regulated for example labelling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acts.co.za/tobacco/index.htm|title=Tobacco Products Control Act 1993<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411010737/http://www.acts.co.za/tobacco/Index.htm|archivedate=11 April 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The 1993 act was not considered to be comprehensive enough and the Tobacco Products Control Amendment Act was passed in 1999. This act prohibits all advertising and promotion of tobacco products, including sponsorship and free distribution of tobacco products. The act also restricts smoking in public places, which includes workplaces, restaurants, bars, and public transport. The act does allow for designated smoking areas (no more than 25% of the total floor area). The act also stipulates penalties for transgressors of the law, and specifies the maximum permissible levels of [[tar]] and [[nicotine]]. The regulations were implemented in 2001.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.multinationalmonitor.org/mm2001/01jan-feb/corp8.html |title=The Great South African Smokeout: Anna White, 2001 |publisher=Multinationalmonitor.org |date=1 October 2000 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614173057/http://www.multinationalmonitor.org/mm2001/01jan-feb/corp8.html |archivedate=14 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The government proposed further amendments to the bill in 2007 that sought to deal with new practices designed to circumvent the Act. These amendments also aim to bring the current law into [[compliance (regulation)|compliance]] with the [[World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control]] (FCTC). This framework has been [[ratified]] by the [[South African government]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polity.org.za/article.php?a_id=106646 |title=Madlala-Routledge: Tobacco Products Control Amendment Bill (29/03/2007) |publisher=Polity.org.za |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref>
The South African government has currently set the minimum legal age for smokers to 18.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/News24/South_Africa/Politics/0,,2-7-12_2285432,00.html |title=News24, South Africa's premier news source, provides breaking news on national, world, Africa, sport, entertainment, technology & more. |publisher= |accessdate=26 June 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612210735/http://www.news24.com/News24/South_Africa/Politics/0%2C%2C2-7-12_2285432%2C00.html |archivedate=12 June 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southafrica.net/za/en/travel-tips/entry/travel-tip-smoking|title=Smoking laws in South Africa|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624192612/http://www.southafrica.net/za/en/travel-tips/entry/travel-tip-smoking|archivedate=24 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===South Korea=== {{main|Smoking in South Korea}} South Korea enforced strict smoking bans in public places since July 2013, with fines of ₩100,000 [[South Korean won|won]] on any spotted smoker and up to ₩5 million won on shop owners not following the law. It is illegal and strictly prohibited to smoke in all bars and restaurants, cafes, internet cafes, government buildings, kindergartens, schools, universities, hospitals, youth facilities, libraries, children's playgrounds, private academies, subway or train stations and their platforms and underground pathways, large buildings, theaters, department stores or shopping malls, large hotels and highway rest areas.
The strict bans came into force gradually beginning with a ban on places larger than 150 square meters in 2012, extended to 100 square meters in 2014, with a full-fledged complete nationwide ban on 1 January 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2999132|title=New Year brings in smoking ban|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803223148/http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2999132|archivedate=3 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Spain=== Since 1 January 2006 Spain had a partial restriction upon smoking in most public places. Offices, schools, hospitals and public transportation were smoke-free, but restaurants and bars could create a "smokers' section" or allow smoking if they were small (under 100m²).<ref>{{Cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4574734.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Spain sees smoking ban take hold | date=2 January 2006 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070121122934/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4574734.stm | archivedate=21 January 2007 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Since 2 January 2011 smoking has been restricted in every indoor public place, including restaurants, bars and cafes. Hotels may designate up to 30% of rooms for smoking; mental hospitals, jails and old people's residences may have public rooms where workers cannot enter. Outdoor smoking is also prohibited at childcare facilities, in children's playparks and around schools and hospital facilities.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/spain/8236170/Spain-introduces-smoking-ban.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Fiona | last=Govan | title=Spain introduces smoking ban | date=2 January 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402142914/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/spain/8236170/Spain-introduces-smoking-ban.html | archivedate=2 April 2016 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Establishments can be closed by the authorities for repeatedly violating the smoke-free law, as happened for the first time on 10 February 2011 in [[Marbella]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/02/10/spain.smoking/index.html?hpt=T2|title=Spain shutting down restaurant for defying smoking ban|date=10 February 2011|publisher=CNN|accessdate=10 February 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110213042820/http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/02/10/spain.smoking/index.html?hpt=T2|archivedate=13 February 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Suriname=== Suriname has a smoking ban in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/suriname/summary|title=Suriname Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093102/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/suriname/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Sweden=== ''Main article: [[Smoking in Sweden]]''
In Sweden, smoking was restricted in restaurants, cafes, bars and nightclubs in June 2005. Smoking rooms are, however, allowed in these institutions. The smoking rooms contain a few restrictions: no serving or consumption of food or beverages is allowed in the smoking rooms and it may not cover more than 25% of the institution's total area. The smoke-free law was very popular amongst the population and even the industries affected.<ref>[http://www.sweden.se/templates/cs/Article____13429.aspx Swedish snuff – not just for men – SWEDEN.SE] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080112140126/http://www.sweden.se/templates/cs/Article____13429.aspx |date=12 January 2008 }}</ref> In January 2008, [[Swedish Prison and Probation Service|The Swedish Prison and Probation Service]] prohibited smoking indoors in prisons.<ref>{{cite web | title='Rökfri kriminalvård' | publisher=Swedish Prison and Probation Service | language=Swedish | url=http://www.kriminalvarden.se/templates/KVV_InfopageGeneral.aspx?id=4846 | date=1 January 2008 | accessdate=28 March 2008 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090214010057/http://www.kriminalvarden.se/templates/KVV_InfopageGeneral.aspx?id=4846 | archivedate=14 February 2009 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Switzerland=== The [[Swiss Federal Assembly]] enacted a law for protection against [[second-hand smoke]] in 2008, which came into force on 1 May 2010. It prohibits smoking in enclosed, publicly accessible areas and in rooms that are workplaces for several persons. There are exceptions for bars and restaurants, which may allow smoking in separate, ventilated rooms or in establishments smaller than 80m², but the federal statute allows for more stringent cantonal smoking bans.<ref name="BAG2">{{cite web|url=http://www.bag.admin.ch/themen/drogen/00041/00612/00764|title=Passivrauchen|last=[[Swiss Federal Office of Health]]|language=German, French, Italian|accessdate=29 June 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20071220232238/http://www.bag.admin.ch/themen/drogen/00041/00612/00764|archivedate=20 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> 10 cantons (Jura, Aargau, Obwalden, Nidwalden, Zug, Schwyz, Glarus, Schaffhausen, Thurgau, Appenzell Innerrhoden) have imposed only the national mandated restrictions, with the remaining 16 (Geneva, [[Vaud]], Neuchâtel, Valais, Fribourg, Bern, Solothurn, Basel-City, Basel-Land, Zürich, Uri, Ticino, Graubünden, St. Gallen, Lucerne, Appenzell Ausserrhoden) imposing stricter laws by not excluding establishments smaller than 80 square meters. All 16 cantons however permit separate smoking rooms with 7 (Bern, Solothurn, Zürich, Uri, Ticino, Graubünden, St. Gallen) permitting service.
===Syria=== {{Main|Smoking in Syria}} Smoking is restricted inside cafes, restaurants and other public spaces by a presidential decree issued on 12 October 2009 and came into force on 21 April 2010. Syria claims to be the first Arab country to introduce such a ban.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} The decree also outlaws smoking in educational institutions, health centres, sports halls, cinemas and theatres and on public transport. The restrictions include the [[nargile]], or waterpipe. According to the official news agency [[Syrian Arab News Agency|SANA]], fines for violating the law range from 500 to 100,000 Syrian pounds (US$11 to $2,169).<ref>{{Cite news |title = Syria smoking ban enters into force |newspaper = BBC News |date = 21 April 2010 |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8634411.stm |accessdate = 22 April 2010 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100425004025/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8634411.stm |archivedate = 25 April 2010 |df = dmy-all }} </ref><ref name="BBC">{{Cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8302794.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Assad decrees Syria smoking ban | date=12 October 2009 | accessdate=4 April 2010 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091028154225/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8302794.stm | archivedate=28 October 2009 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A decree in 1996 banned tobacco advertising while a 2006 law outlawed smoking on public transport and in some public places, introducing fines for offenders. Under-16s are not allowed to buy tobacco.<ref name="BBC"/>
===Taiwan=== {{Main|Smoking in Taiwan}} Smoking is regulated by the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act (Taiwan), promulgated on 11 July 2007.
===Thailand=== Indoor smoking restrictions have been in effect in all indoor air-conditioned establishments throughout Thailand since November 2002, with entertainment areas exempted. Cigarettes have had graphic pictures since 2005, and advertising is banned. Enforcement and compliance have been strong.
On 10 January 2008, Thailand announced further restrictions that came into force on 10 February 2008, in that smoking would be banned (indoors and outdoors) in establishments open to the public, including restaurants, bars, and open-air markets. Members of the public face a 2,000 baht fines for not complying, and establishments face a 20,000 baht fine for not enforcing the ban (including not displaying mandated 'no smoking' signs). In addition to fines, those who fail to comply may be arrested. Most legal bars comply with these regulations, but in establishments that operate illegally or semi-legally they are mostly disregarded.
===Togo=== Togo has a smoking ban in place for certain public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/togo/summary|title=Togo Details – Tobacco Control Laws|website=www.tobaccocontrollaws.org|accessdate=4 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205093052/https://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/legislation/country/togo/summary|archivedate=5 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Turkey=== {{Main|Smoking in Turkey}} Turkey currently restricts smoking in government offices, workplaces, bars, restaurants, cafes, shopping malls, schools, hospitals, and all forms of public transport, including trains, taxis and ferries.<ref name=BBC719>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8157747.stm|title=Turkey smoke ban extends to bars|publisher=BBC News|date=18 July 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719100705/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8157747.stm|archivedate=19 July 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Turkey's smoke-free law ban includes provisions for violators, where anyone caught smoking in a designated smoke-free area faces a fine of 83 liras (~€35/$47/£30) and bar owners who fail to enforce the law could be fined from 560 liras for a first offence up to 5,600 liras.<ref name=BBC719 />
Smoking was first restricted in 1997 in public buildings with more than four workers, as well as planes and public buses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/article.php?enewsid=92824 |title=New era begins in Turkish social life with smoking ban |publisher=Turkish Daily News }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
On 3 January 2008, Turkey passed a law prohibiting smoking in all indoor spaces including bars, cafés and restaurants. It also restricts smoking in [[stadium|sports stadia]], and the gardens of mosques, hospitals and schools. The smoking ban came into force on 19 May 2008; however, bars, restaurants and cafes were exempted until mid-July 2009. On 19 July 2009, Turkey extended the indoor public smoking restrictions to include bars, restaurants, village [[coffeehouse]]s and [[nargile]] (hookah) bars.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7407985.stm|title=Turkey expands curbs on smoking |publisher=BBC News |date=19 May 2008}}</ref>
===Turkmenistan=== In 1998, a ban on tobacco advertising was enacted. Under decree from [[President for life]] [[Saparmurat Niyazov]], has prohibited the chewing of tobacco.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ria.ru/world/20131225/986298716.html|title=Антитабачный закон вступил в силу в Туркмении|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304053753/http://ria.ru/world/20131225/986298716.html|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2000, Turkmenistan banned smoking in all public places. People say the ban was implemented because the president was advised by his doctor to quit smoking.<ref>[[BBC News]]: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/602581.stm Turkmen face smoking ban] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630134731/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/602581.stm |date=30 June 2012 }}. 13 January 2012</ref> In 2002, it was forbidden to smoke while behind the wheel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trend.az/regions/casia/turkmenistan/1985666.html|title=Туркменистан принял программу по борьбе с табакокурением|date=30 January 2012|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213191624/http://www.trend.az/regions/casia/turkmenistan/1985666.html|archivedate=13 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to the Code of Administrative violations for smoking cigarettes, including hookah and other tobacco products in the bodies of state power and administration, executive bodies and local authorities, enterprises, institutions and organizations irrespective of ownership, military units and formations, educational institutions, theaters and cinemas, public transport, parks and other places of mass visiting citizens – punishable by a fine in the amount of 100 manats.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.turkmenistan.gov.tm/?id=4878|title=Туркменистан: золотой век|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414143253/http://turkmenistan.gov.tm/?id=4878|archivedate=14 April 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In January 2016, Turkmen President [[Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow]] banned the sales of all tobacco-related products nationwide, making Turkmenistan the second country in the world (after [[Bhutan]]) to implement such policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-35325840|title=Turkmenistan: Authorities 'ban tobacco sales' – BBC News|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160425180706/http://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-35325840|archivedate=25 April 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/this-entire-country-has-banned-smoking-a6816141.html|title=This entire country has banned smoking|date=16 January 2016|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20160616024223/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/this-entire-country-has-banned-smoking-a6816141.html|archivedate=16 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.albawaba.com/loop/turkmenistan-becomes-he-first-country-effectively-ban-tobacco-products-793994|title=Turkmenistan becomes the first country to effectively ban tobacco products|date=17 January 2016|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507155111/http://www.albawaba.com/loop/turkmenistan-becomes-he-first-country-effectively-ban-tobacco-products-793994|archivedate=7 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Uganda=== In March 2004, smoking was prohibited in public places, including workplaces, restaurants and bars. An extension to private homes is being considered.
===Ukraine=== Smoking is banned in all indoor public places, including restaurants, discos, nightclubs, indoor workplaces and all state and cultural institutions, including football stadiums.<ref name=whoukr>{{cite news | url = http://www.euro.who.int/en/where-we-work/member-states/ukraine/sections/news/2012/06/ukraine-moves-closer-to-full-implementation-of-who-framework-convention-on-tobacco-control | title = Ukraine moves closer to full implementation of WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control | work = World Health Organization | date = 20 June 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130301215254/http://www.euro.who.int/en/where-we-work/member-states/ukraine/sections/news/2012/06/ukraine-moves-closer-to-full-implementation-of-who-framework-convention-on-tobacco-control | archivedate = 1 March 2013 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=kp120613>{{cite news | url = http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/yanukovych-signs-law-prohibiting-smoking-in-certai.html#.T-_2d7We6y5 | title = Yanukovych signs law prohibiting smoking in certain areas | work = Interfax-Ukraine | publisher = Kyiv Post | date = 13 June 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120701180420/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/yanukovych-signs-law-prohibiting-smoking-in-certai.html#.T-_2d7We6y5 | archivedate = 1 July 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
===United Arab Emirates=== Emirates in the United Arab Emirates recently started restricting smoking in shopping malls, beaches, gardens. The states leading the regulations on smoking are [[Abu Dhabi]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle.asp?xfile=data/theuae/2008/January/theuae_January264.xml&section=theuae |title=Abu Dhabi plans ban on smoking in malls |publisher=Khaleej Times |date=11 January 2008 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608084440/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle.asp?xfile=data%2Ftheuae%2F2008%2FJanuary%2Ftheuae_January264.xml&section=theuae |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Ajman]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.gulfnews.com/articles/07/10/05/10158079.html |title=Gulf News – Ajman bans smoking in malls and markets |publisher=Archive.gulfnews.com |date=5 October 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629152854/http://archive.gulfnews.com/articles/07/10/05/10158079.html |archivedate=29 June 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Dubai]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?xfile=data/theuae/2007/May/theuae_May244.xml&section=theuae&col |title=Stricter smoking ban in Dubai |publisher=Khaleej Times |date=9 May 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608084514/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?xfile=data%2Ftheuae%2F2007%2FMay%2Ftheuae_May244.xml&section=theuae&col |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and [[Sharjah (emirate)|Sharjah]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle.asp?xfile=data/theuae/2007/March/theuae_March403.xml&section=theuae |title=Smoking ban to be in place next year |publisher=Khaleej Times |date=14 March 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608084551/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle.asp?xfile=data%2Ftheuae%2F2007%2FMarch%2Ftheuae_March403.xml&section=theuae |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{Main|Smoking in the United Kingdom}} Since 1 July 2007 smoke-free workplace laws have been in effect across the whole of the UK. These were introduced in each constituent administration of the United Kingdom separately, as decided by the partially [[devolved]] governments of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, and the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|UK Parliament]] acting for England. For details, see (in chronological order of bans): [[List of smoking bans#Scotland|Scotland]], [[List of smoking bans#Wales|Wales]], [[List of smoking bans#Northern Ireland|Northern Ireland]] and [[List of smoking bans#England|England]].
====England==== [[File:Smoking shelter, Encon, Deighton Close, Wetherby (25th October 2015).JPG|thumb|right|A smoking shelter outside on office building in England. Since 2007 such shelters have become commonplace at workplaces.]] {{Main|Health Act 2006|Smoking ban in England}} Smoke-free regulations covering all indoor work-places in England, including bars, clubs and restaurants, came into force on 1 July 2007. Some places, such as certain smoking hotel rooms, nursing homes, prisons, submarines, offshore oil rigs, and stages/television sets (if needed for the performance) were initially exempted, as well as Royal Palaces,<ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Parliamentary Privilege First Report |work= |publisher=The Stationery Office |date=4 September 2007 |url=http://www.parliament.the-stationery-office.co.uk/pa/jt199899/jtselect/jtpriv/43/4309.htm |doi= |accessdate=4 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930032749/http://www.parliament.the-stationery-office.co.uk/pa/jt199899/jtselect/jtpriv/43/4309.htm |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> although members of the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] and the [[House of Lords]] agreed to ban all smoking in the [[Palace of Westminster]].<ref>{{Cite news| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =MPs 'smoking in Commons toilets'| work =| publisher =BBC News Online| date =5 July 2007| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6273830.stm| doi =| accessdate =12 August 2007| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070908002006/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/6273830.stm| archivedate =8 September 2007| df =dmy-all}}</ref>
The on-the-spot fine for smoking in a workplace is £50 (~€60/~$75), £30 (~€35/~$45) if one pays within 15 days, while a business that allows smoking can be fined £2,500 (~€3,700/~$3,800). Smoking largely remains permitted outdoors, apart from railway stations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smokefreeengland.co.uk/ |title=Smoking ban information website |publisher=smokefreeengland.co.uk |date=1 July 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20091005123812/http://www.smokefreeengland.co.uk/ |archivedate=5 October 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, an internal government briefing obtained by ''[[The Independent on Sunday]]'' newspaper reveals that powers are available to extend coverage to further outdoor areas if required.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/health/article2725720.ece |work=The Independent |location=London |title=Going for smoke: Today's ban is just the start. Could your home be next? |date=1 July 2007 |accessdate=4 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705162657/http://news.independent.co.uk/health/article2725720.ece |archivedate=5 July 2008 }}</ref> A legal loophole exists for cigar smokers who are allowed to smoke in store to 'sample' the cigar in England only.
====Northern Ireland==== ''Main article: [[Smoking in Ireland]]''
In [[Northern Ireland]], a smoke-free law has been in effect since 30 April 2007. It is illegal to smoke in all enclosed workplaces. This includes bars, restaurants, offices (even if the smoker is the only person in the office) and public buildings. Like Scotland, the smoke-free law is comprehensive in that places such as telephone boxes and enclosed bus/train shelters are included. The on-the-spot fine for smoking in a workplace is £50 (~€70/~$100), while a business that allows smoking can be fined £2,500 (~€3,700/~$5,000).
A £200 fine may be levied by local councils if businesses fail to display no-smoking signs. An opinion poll showed that 91% of people supported the law.<ref>{{cite web |author=30 April 2007 – 07:15:42 |url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/?jp=308472&rss=rss2 |title=Northern Irish Smoking Ban |publisher=Breakingnews.ie |date=30 April 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614043017/http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/?jp=308472&rss=rss2 |archivedate=14 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spacetobreathe.org.uk/ |title=Smoking ban information website |publisher=spacetobreathe.org.uk |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101012191557/http://www.spacetobreathe.org.uk/ |archivedate=12 October 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Scotland==== {{Main|Smoking, Health and Social Care (Scotland) Act 2005}} On 26 March 2006, Scotland prohibited smoking in enclosed (more than 50% covered) public places, which includes public buildings, workplaces, sports stadiums, bars and restaurants. Exemptions are in place to allow hotel guests to smoke in their own rooms, as long as the hotel has designated them as smoking rooms. The law restricts smoking in bus shelters, phone boxes or other shelters that are more than 50% enclosed. It also prohibits smoking in trucks and vans owned by a company, whether or not the driver is the only person inside (though smoking while driving was already legally questionable as it could be presented as "[[driving without due care and attention]]"). Nevertheless, the ban on smoking in work vehicles is commonly flouted, especially by tradesmen, and compliance with outdoor bans is minimal. There are no restrictions on smoking in railway stations as the railway bylaw applies only to England, and smoking remains common in outdoor areas of railway stations. Compliance with the indoor ban in pubs, restaurants and other workplaces is almost universal. Businesses covered by the smoking ban must display a statutory smoking sign at the entrance to, and around the building<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clearingtheairscotland.com/faqs/pdf/A4Poster.pdf |title=Standard no smoking sign in Scotland |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708163736/http://www.clearingtheairscotland.com/faqs/pdf/A4Poster.pdf |archivedate=8 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> as well as a smoke-free policy. Opinion polls at its introduction showed a clear majority of the Scottish public were in favour of the ban<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marketresearchworld.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=629&Itemid= |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-05-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070805010531/http://www.marketresearchworld.net/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=629&Itemid= |archivedate=5 August 2007 |df=dmy-all }} 'Widespread support for smoking ban in Scotland'</ref>
As in New Zealand, the smoke-free law was initially criticised by certain interested groups (e.g., publicans, cafe and [[Bingo (UK)|bingo]] hall owners, etc.) who feared that it would adversely impact their businesses. A survey published by the Scottish Beer & Pubs Association one year on from implementation concluded that "the number of pub licensed premises in Scotland has remained more or less constant over the last year"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scottishpubs.co.uk/Aboutus/News/PR%202006%20Licensing%20Statistics.pdf |title='Research on liquor licenses for Scotland, March 2007, SBPA' |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205124507/http://www.scottishpubs.co.uk/Aboutus/News/PR%202006%20Licensing%20Statistics.pdf |archivedate=5 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> indicating fears of an adverse impact of the ban on the hospitality industry were unfounded. Widespread concerns prior to implementation about the impact on bingo halls<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/half-of-scottish-bingo-halls-threatened-by-smoking-ban-405794.html |title='Half of Scottish bingo halls threatened by smoking ban' |work=The Independent |location=London |date=28 June 2006 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |first=Julia |last=Kollewe |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108063659/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/half-of-scottish-bingo-halls-threatened-by-smoking-ban-405794.html |archivedate=8 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> prove harder to objectively assess: As at May 2008 there is anecdotal evidence<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smokersclubinc.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=4140 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019075526/http://www.smokersclubinc.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=4140 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 October 2007 |title='Bingo related News, the Smokers Club inc.' |publisher=Smokersclubinc.com |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 }}</ref> to suggest an increase in closures of bingo halls since implementation. However, no statistical analysis has been conducted and speculation within the betting and gaming industry is that a decline could also be the result of demographic changes and increases in online gaming.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bingo-uk.co.uk/smoking-bingo-players.htm |title='Smoking Ban, bingo.co.uk' |publisher=Bingo-uk.co.uk |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809054437/http://www.bingo-uk.co.uk/smoking-bingo-players.htm |archivedate=9 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The [[NHS Scotland]] Quit Smoking Line reported it received an additional 50,000 calls from people wishing to give up in the six months after the smoke-free law was introduced.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clearingtheairscotland.com/ |title=Smoking ban information website |publisher=clearingtheairscotland.com |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207180325/http://clearingtheairscotland.com/ |archivedate=7 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In September 2007 a study of nine Scottish hospitals over the twelve months following implementation reported positively on its impact on the country's health, including a 17% drop in admissions for heart attacks, compared with average reductions of 3% per year for the previous decade.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.gov.scot/News/Releases/2007/09/10081400 |title=Smoking ban brings positive results |publisher=[[Scottish Government]] |date=10 September 2007 |accessdate=30 April 2017}}</ref>
====Wales==== {{Main|Health Act 2006}} Smoking was restricted across all enclosed public premises and work premises in Wales on 2 April 2007. Adherence is widespread and many public houses have closed since the law came into place.<ref name="BBC2011">[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-13948624 "MPs campaign to relax smoking ban in pubs"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528042503/http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-13948624 |date=28 May 2014 }}, BBC, 29 June 2011</ref>
Public places must display a special bilingual no smoking sign: * "Mae ysmygu yn y fangre hon yn erbyn y gyfraith" (Welsh) * "It is against the law to smoke in these premises" (English)
In addition, Wales is due to introduce a smoking ban outside schools and hospitals from Summer 2019.<ref name=wales2019>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/may/25/wales-to-ban-smoking-outside-hospitals-and-schools-in-uk-first |title=Wales to ban smoking outside hospitals and schools in UK first |accessdate=29 May 2018 |first=Steven |last=Morris |date=25 May 2018 |publisher=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref>
===United Nations=== As United Nations buildings are not the subject of any national jurisdiction, the United Nations has its own smoking and non-smoking policies. Following the gradual introduction of partial smoking restrictions between 1985 and 2003, Secretary-General [[Kofi Annan]] introduced in 2003 a total prohibition upon smoking at [[United Nations Headquarters]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/N03/468/96/doc/N0346896.DOC?OpenElement|title=Smoking ban at United Nations Headquarters|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718234131/http://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/N03/468/96/doc/N0346896.DOC?OpenElement|archivedate=18 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Similar restrictions have not been introduced in field offices of the United Nations worldwide. Some specialised agencies of the United Nations, such as the [[UNICEF|United Nations Children's Fund]] and the [[WHO|World Health Organization]] have their own strict smoke-free regulations that apply to their offices worldwide, but the same is not necessarily true for entities of the Secretariat, such as the [[Department of Peacekeeping Operations]] and the [[OCHA|Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)]]. Only on 13 December 2007, OCHA introduced a smoke-free regulation applicable to all its field offices.
===United States=== {{double image|right|US states smoking bans.svg|325|Smoking ban key.svg|250|Map of current and scheduled future statewide smoking bans as of 6 November 2012.}} {{Main|List of smoking bans in the United States}} In the United States, [[United States Congress|Congress]] has not attempted to enact any nationwide [[law of the United States|federal]] smoking ban. Therefore, smoking bans in the United States are entirely a product of state and [[local government in the United States|local]] [[criminal law|criminal]] and [[occupational safety and health]] laws. As a result, the existence and aggressiveness of smoking bans varies widely throughout the United States, ranging from total bans (even outdoors), to no regulation of smoking at all. Jurisdictions in the greater [[Southern United States|South]] tend to have the least restrictive smoking bans or no statewide bans at all. Of the 60 [[List of United States cities by population|most populated cities in the United States]], all but 17 ban smoking in all bars and restaurants.
According to Americans for Nonsmokers' Rights, as of October 2012, 81.3% of the U.S. population is covered by bans on smoking in "workplaces, and/or restaurants, and/or bars, by either a state, commonwealth, or local law,"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.no-smoke.org/pdf/mediaordlist.pdf |title=Overview List – How many Smokefree Laws? |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=5 October 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101121233/http://www.no-smoke.org/pdf/mediaordlist.pdf |archivedate=1 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> although only 48.7% are covered by bans in all workplaces ''and'' restaurants ''and'' bars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.no-smoke.org/pdf/SummaryUSPopList.pdf |title="Summary of 100% Smokefree State Laws and Population Protected by 100% U.S. Smokefree Laws", Americans for Nonsmokers' Rights, 2 October 2012 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=5 October 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029060223/http://no-smoke.org/pdf/SummaryUSPopList.pdf |archivedate=29 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
As of November 2012, 28 states have banned smoking in all general workplaces and public places, including bars and restaurants (though many of these exempt tobacconists, cigar bars, casinos, private clubs, and/or small workplaces). Six have enacted smoking bans exempting all adult venues including bars, and in some cases casinos and restaurants (Tennessee exempts any place not admitting patrons under 21). [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Idaho]], [[Nevada]], [[New Hampshire]], [[North Carolina]], and [[Virginia]] have particularised state laws banning smoking in specific places but leaving out all others. The remaining 10 states have no statewide smoking bans at all, though many cities and/or counties in those states have enacted local smoking bans to varying degrees (except [[Oklahoma]], which prohibits local governments from regulating smoking at all).
As for U.S. jurisdictions that are not states, as of November 2012 smoking is banned in all public places (including bars and restaurants) in [[American Samoa]], the [[District of Columbia]], [[Puerto Rico]] and [[United States Virgin Islands]]. [[Guam]] prohibits smoking in restaurants, but not in any other workplaces. The [[Northern Mariana Islands]] prohibits smoking in most workplaces and in restaurants but not in bars.
In [[Indianapolis]], [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] announced that it will ban smoking in its grandstands starting fall 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Press|first1=Associated|title=Indianapolis Motor Speedway to ban smoking in grandstands|url=http://www.kokomotribune.com/news/state_news/indianapolis-motor-speedway-to-ban-smoking-in-grandstands/article_e3aece3e-2b42-11e7-be0a-53b8d69864cc.html|website=Kokomo Tribune|publisher=Michael Conroy|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427185726/http://www.kokomotribune.com/news/state_news/indianapolis-motor-speedway-to-ban-smoking-in-grandstands/article_e3aece3e-2b42-11e7-be0a-53b8d69864cc.html|archivedate=27 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Uruguay=== {{Main|Smoking in Uruguay}} In March 2006, it became illegal in Uruguay to smoke in enclosed public spaces. Now bars, restaurants or offices where people are caught smoking face fines of more than $1,100 or a three-day closure. This makes Uruguay the first country in South America to ban smoking in enclosed public spaces.<ref name=bbcuruguay>{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4761624.stm |title=Uruguay curbs smoking in public |publisher=BBC News |date=1 March 2006 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125195733/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4761624.stm |archivedate=25 January 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Anti-smoking groups estimate that as many as a third of Uruguay's 3.4 million people smoke. [[President of Uruguay|President]] [[Tabaré Vázquez]], a practicing [[oncologist]], has cited reports suggesting about seven people die each day in Uruguay (an estimated 5,000 people a year) from smoking-related causes including lung cancer, emphysema and other illnesses.<ref>[http://www.tobaccofree.org/news%20articles/2006-03-02-Associated-Press/2006-03-02-Associated-Press-Uruguay.htm?SITE=VACUL&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT Public smoking ban takes effect in Uruguay] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614100802/http://www.tobaccofree.org/news%20articles/2006-03-02-Associated-Press/2006-03-02-Associated-Press-Uruguay.htm?SITE=VACUL&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |date=14 June 2007 }} – TobacoFree.org</ref>
===Vatican City=== A July 2002 law signed by [[Pope John Paul II]] banned smoking on all places accessible to the public, and in all closed places of work within the [[Vatican City]], and within all extraterritorial [[properties of the Holy See]]. Smoking bans in museums, libraries and churches on Vatican territory had already been in force for a long time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zenit.org/article-4800?l=english|title=Smoking Banned in Public Areas of Vatican|publisher=Zenit|date=28 June 2002|accessdate=26 March 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216162249/http://www.zenit.org/article-4800?l=english|archivedate=16 February 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In November 2017, [[Pope Francis]] banned the sale of cigarettes throughout Vatican City, the sale of cigars is still legal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cruxnow.com/vatican/2017/11/09/pope-francis-bans-cigarette-sales-vatican/|title=Pope Francis bans cigarette sales in the Vatican|date=9 November 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109191612/https://cruxnow.com/vatican/2017/11/09/pope-francis-bans-cigarette-sales-vatican/|archivedate=9 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Venezuela=== On 31 May 2011 [[Venezuela]] introduced a ban on smoking in all enclosed public and commercial spaces, including malls, restaurants, bars, discos, workplaces, etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsj.gov.ve/gaceta/Marzo/232011/232011-3087.pdf#page=63|title=Official publication of the law|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113035304/http://www.tsj.gov.ve/gaceta/Marzo/232011/232011-3087.pdf#page=63|archivedate=13 November 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The owners or managers of the establishments where smoking is banned, must post a notice <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpps.gob.ve/images/stories/pdf/aviso_oficial_articulo_4.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=18 September 2013|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130918173823/http://www.mpps.gob.ve/images/stories/pdf/aviso_oficial_articulo_4.pdf|archivedate=18 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> measuring 80 cm. (31.5 inches) wide and 50 cm (19.7 inches) high; The poster should contain an international smoking ban pictogram and the following text: "Este es un ambiente 100% libre de humo de tabaco, por resolución del Ministerio del Poder Popular para la Salud" (This is a 100% smoke-free environment, by resolution of the Ministry of Popular Power for Health). Owners or managers also have the obligation to ensure compliance with this rule.
Owners or managers that do not post the notice or do not ensure compliance with the rule may be penalized with the closure of the establishment and / or a fine that can be up to 190,000 VEF (1.9 USD), however, regulation does not provide sanctions for smokers.<ref>[[Venezuelanalysis.com]], 30 May 2011, [http://venezuelanalysis.com/news/6226 Smoking Banned in Public and Commercial Closed Spaces in Venezuela] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603122413/http://venezuelanalysis.com/news/6226 |date=3 June 2011 }}</ref>
===Vietnam=== ''Main article: [[Smoking in Vietnam]]''
The Vietnamese government has banned smoking and cigarette sales in offices, production facilities, schools, hospitals, and on public transport. However, bus drivers, especially in north Vietnam, occasionally smoke. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-05/17/content_6112701.htm |title=Xinhua – English |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=17 May 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020140525/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-05/17/content_6112701.htm |archivedate=20 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Smoking was banned in enclosed indoor spaces and public facilities in [[Ho Chi Minh City]] in 2005 with the exception of entertainment areas.
A ban has also been imposed on all forms of advertisement, trade promotion, and sponsorship by tobacco companies, as well as cigarette sales through vending machines, or over the telephone and on the Internet.
===Zambia=== Smoking is prohibited in public places in Zambia and is punishable by a fine of K400 or imprisonment of up to two years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200805290606.html|title=Zambia: The Move by the Government to Ban Smoking in Public Places|date=29 May 2008|publisher=|accessdate=10 November 2017|via=AllAfrica|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102201422/http://allafrica.com/stories/200805290606.html|archivedate=2 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=775667 |title=Zambia gets tough on smokers |work=The Times |location=UK |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530131233/http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=775667 |archivedate=30 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Specific restrictions==
===Outdoor smoking restrictions=== *It is illegal to smoke at a bus shelter in [[Ireland]]. It was also the first country in the world to impose a restriction upon smoking outdoors within 3-metres of a public building. *In [[Costa Rica]], it is also illegal to smoke at a bus shelter or at queues for the bus, train, etc. It is also forbidden to smoke in public parks and recreational areas. *In the Australian state of [[Queensland]], smoking is prohibited within four metres of entrances to public buildings, within 10 metres of children's playground equipment, in commercial outdoor eating or drinking areas, at patrolled beaches, and at all major sports stadiums.<ref>[http://www.health.qld.gov.au/atods/tobaccolaws/outdoor/default.asp Outdoor public areas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060822001712/http://www.health.qld.gov.au/atods/tobaccolaws/outdoor/default.asp |date=22 August 2006 }} Queensland Government</ref> **Some beaches in [[Sydney, Australia]] have smoking restrictions in place. **Smoking on land owned by the New South Wales Department of Education is prohibited. *[http://www.cmh.org/ Cambridge Memorial Hospital] in [[Cambridge, Ontario]], Canada, enacted a total (outdoor) smoke-free regulation, believed to be the first in the entire province if not country, as of October 2004. At the same time, [[Wilfrid Laurier University]] in the nearby [[Waterloo, Ontario|city of Waterloo, Ontario]], proposed a similar total smoke-free regulation on its property, after its [https://archive.is/20041205223116/http://www.wlu.ca/page.php?grp_id=158&s_id=146&sb_id=286&p_id=147 10 metre outdoor proximity restriction] (enacted in 2002) failed. WLU was presumed to be the third Canadian (public) post-secondary institution to consider such measures, after Carleton and Acadia. **Smoking is prohibited in [[Hamilton Street Railway]] bus shelters in [[Hamilton, Ontario]]. **It is illegal to smoke on a bus or at a bus shelter in [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]]. **It is illegal to smoke on a bus or at a bus shelter as well as less than 4 metres from any entrance in [[Halifax Urban Area|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]]. **[[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], prohibited all outdoor patio smoking at bars, restaurants and casinos on 1 July 2005. Nova Scotia did the same on 1 December 2006. *[[Calabasas]], California, United States, prohibited smoking in almost all indoor and outdoor public places in 2006, believed to be the strictest such regulations in the United States. At least 13 California cities (including Los Angeles) have prohibited smoking on their beaches, at least four other California cities (including San Francisco) ban smoking in parks or outdoor venues. For more information, see [[List of smoking bans in the United States#Outdoor smoking bans]]. **[[Belmont, California]], prohibited smoking in outdoor places on 25 September 2007; this also applies inside condominiums, apartments and other kinds of multi-unit housing.<ref>[http://www.belmont.gov Welcome to Belmont] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012222947/http://www.belmont.gov/ |date=12 October 2007 }} The City of Belmont</ref><ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/03/12/BAG9ROK7LN3.DTL Belmont to hold meeting about proposed anti-smoking law] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070604043526/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2007%2F03%2F12%2FBAG9ROK7LN3.DTL |date=4 June 2007 }} San Francisco Chronicle, 12 March 2007</ref> **California has prohibited smoking within {{convert|20|ft|m}} of entrances to any public building. *Selected wards in [[Tokyo]], Japan, prohibit smoking on the streets; this is enforced and violators are fined. **56% of [[Chiyoda, Tokyo|Chiyoda ward]]'s land area is a no-smoking zone as of April 2007. **[[Kyoto]], Japan, has prohibited smoking on 7.1km of its streets in 2007, including busy areas along [[Kawaramachi Street|Kawaramachi]], [[Karasuma Street|Karasuma]]-dori and [[Shijo Street]] avenues. **[[Railway stations]] in Japan are no-smoking except for a few remaining long distance services. *Many UK [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]] organisations prohibit smoking on their premises both inside and outside hospitals, including places such as car parks. **[[Addenbrooke's Hospital]] in [[Cambridge]], has banned smoking on all of its sites, including private homes that are on hospital grounds since 1 January 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brown|first=Raymond|title=Staff at Addenbrooke's Hospital in Cambridge banned from smoking in their own homes – and warn of danger to women smokers at night|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/News/Rape-threat-blamed-on-ban-by-Addenbrookes-Hospital-chiefs-on-staff-smoking-in-own-homes-20140104051430.htm|work=Cambridge News|publisher=Cambridge News|accessdate=5 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106031955/http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/News/Rape-threat-blamed-on-ban-by-Addenbrookes-Hospital-chiefs-on-staff-smoking-in-own-homes-20140104051430.htm|archivedate=6 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> **[[Oxford University Hospitals NHS Trust]] has had a ban on smoking on its sites since 2007, but in 2013 admitted that the ban was unenforceable, and will be installing outdoor smoking shelters.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-oxfordshire-23537888 |title=Oxford hospitals apply for smoking shelters |publisher=bbc.co.uk |date=1 August 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223090439/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-oxfordshire-23537888 |archivedate=23 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Wales is due to introduce a smoking ban outside schools and hospitals from Summer 2019.<ref name=wales2019/> * In [[Hong Kong]], smoking restrictions are imposed on most public recreational areas and beaches. It is up to districts to designate which public recreational areas are exempt, and some prohibit smoking districtwide. Many playgrounds in public housing estates have also become smoke-free. Some public transport interchanges, as designated by the government, have been smoke-free since 1 September 2009. *Smoking is prohibited on all railway platforms in England, regardless of whether they are covered or not. These measures were introduced before any national smoking ban for safety reasons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smokefreeengland.co.uk/faq/vehicles.html#train |title=Non-smoking train platforms |publisher=Smokefreeengland.co.uk |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805154651/http://www.smokefreeengland.co.uk/faq/vehicles.html#train |archivedate=5 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *It is illegal to smoke on the outdoor property of the institutions of public education in [[Slovenia]], penalties are dictated by internal orders of the concerned institutions. *It is illegal to smoke at some bus shelters (complex rules determine which, leading to variable compliance) and inside telephone boxes in [[Scotland]].
===Other restrictions=== In some countries, such as [[Germany]], [[India]] and [[Russia]], earlier smoke-free regulations allowed for smoking sections in restaurants, as well as possible special rooms for use by smokers in other workplaces (though many employers prefer not to incur the costs of building and maintaining such rooms).
*All public and Catholic schools in the [[Region of Waterloo]] in [[Ontario]], Canada, prohibited smoking on school property in Autumn 1994. A province-wide smoking ban on school property was scheduled to begin for the 2007/2008 school year in [[British Columbia]], Canada. *A [[tobacco fatwa]] was issued in Iran in 1891 and Egypt in 2000. *Australia has a federal law prohibiting the manufacture and sale of all smokeless tobacco products. The sale of oral snuff and [[chewing tobacco]] has been banned since 1989 under the Trade Practices Act 1974.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/_srcfiles/P278_IA.pdf |title=Please Refer To Anzfa'S Guide To Applications And Proposals For A More Detailed Explanation Of The Process On How To Undertake |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629142343/http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/_srcfiles/P278_IA.pdf |archivedate=29 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *Many [[Tobacco-Free College Campuses|colleges and universities]] have banned smoking on campus.
==International treaties== International treaties that ban smoking:
*Australia, Canada and the United States banned smoking on flights between their countries on 1 March 1995.<ref>[http://www3.austlii.edu.au/au/other/dfat/treaties/1995/5.html "Agreement to Ban Smoking on International Passenger Flights ATS 5 of 1995“] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170416133437/http://www3.austlii.edu.au/au/other/dfat/treaties/1995/5.html |date=16 April 2017 }}. Australasian Legal Information Institute, Australian Treaties Library. Retrieved on 15 April 2017.</ref>
==Proposed smoke-free laws== [[New Caledonia]] is likely to introduce restrictions on smoking in public places following a 2007 25-nation global air-quality monitoring initiative.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=32704 |title=New Caledonia in line for anti-smoking law |publisher=Rnzi.com |date=2 June 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616111737/http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=32704 |archivedate=16 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Niue]] is considering banning tobacco completely, and is seeking the cooperation of Australia and New Zealand to ensure that no tobacco can be imported into the country.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10520567 |title=World's smallest state aims to become first smoke-free island paradise – World – NZ Herald News |publisher=Nzherald.co.nz |date=9 July 2008 |accessdate=15 February 2011 |first=Kathy |last=Marks}}</ref> In 2008, a bill was introduced in outlawing both the sale of tobacco and smoking, but it is yet to be implemented.<ref name="stuff.co.nz"/>
Some Singapore citizens have launched an online campaign to support the proposal to prevent the supply of tobacco to Singaporeans born from the year 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccofreesingapore.info |title=Towards Tobacco-Free Singapore | Support the proposal to prevent the supply of tobacco to Singaporeans born from the year 2000 |publisher=Tobaccofreesingapore.info |date= |accessdate=15 February 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110505033301/http://www.tobaccofreesingapore.info/ |archivedate=5 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[New Zealand]] hopes to be smoke-free in 2025. ASH New Zealand is a group of people who believe [[New Zealand]] should be smoke-free and have become popular. The Ministry of Health and the Minister of Health also are trying to promote the idea that [[New Zealand]] should be smoke-free.
In the [[United Kingdom]], there have been calls from MPs for the prohibition of [[smoking]] in cars that have children in them.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-13875513 | work=BBC News | title=MP calls for smoke ban in cars carrying children | date=22 June 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206124045/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-13875513 | archivedate=6 February 2017 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> This has been further advocated by doctors and the devolved governments of Wales and Northern Ireland.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-politics-16065035|title=bbc.co.uk|work=BBC News|date=7 December 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307185521/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-politics-16065035|archivedate=7 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Lack of smoke-free regulation== Some countries have no legislation restricting smoking whatsoever; these include [[Cameroon]],{{as of?|date=August 2016}} [[Central African Republic]],{{as of?|date=August 2016}} [[Chad]],{{as of?|date=August 2016}} and a number of other countries in Central and Western Africa.
==See also== *[[Anti-tobacco movement in Nazi Germany]] *[[Regulation of electronic cigarettes]] *[[Philip Morris v. Uruguay]] *[[Smokeasy]] *[[TNCO ceilings]] *[[Tobacco control]] *[[World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070525003031/http://www.inforesearchlab.com/bansmoking.chtml Smoking bans around the world] (updated) *[http://ask.yahoo.com/20070214.html List of countries with smoking bans (Yahoo)] *[http://www.cbc.ca/news/interactives/map-globalsmokingbans/ Interactive map on some global smoking bans] *[http://edutube.org/interactive/prevalence-smoking-men-and-women/ Interactive map on prevalence of smoking among men and women] *[http://www.tobacco.org/articles/category/smoking_bans/ Smoking ban news] *[https://archive.is/20130209093246/http://howtoquitcigarettes.web-omnibus.com/ Quitting Smoking Blog – Help With Quitting]

{{About|ecoregions designated by the WWF|alternate classifications|Lists of ecoregions}} This is a '''list of terrestrial [[ecoregions]]''' as compiled by the [[World Wildlife Fund]] (WWF). The WWF identifies [[terrestrial ecoregion|terrestrial]], [[freshwater ecoregion|freshwater]], and [[marine ecoregion]]s.
The terrestrial scheme divides the Earth's land surface into 8 [[ecozone|terrestrial ecozones]], containing 867 smaller ecoregions. Each ecoregion is classified into one of 14 '''major habitat types''', or [[biome]]s.

Antarctic Realm - Tundra Biome: 1 North-east Antarctic Peninsula; 2 South Orkney Islands; 3 North-west Antarctic Peninsula; 4 Central south Antarctic Peninsula; 5 Enderby Land; 6 Dronning Maud Land; 7 East Antarctica; 8 North Victoria Land; 9 South Victoria Land; 10 Transantarctic Mountains; 11 Ellsworth Mountains; 12 Marie Byrd Land; 13 Adelie Land; 14 Ellsworth Land; 15 South Antarctic Peninsula.
Terauds, A, SL Chown, F Morgan, HJ Peat, DJ Watts, H Keys, P Convey, DM Bergstrom. 2012. Conservation biogeography of the Antarctic. Diversity and Distributions 1–16. DOI: 10.1111/j.1472-4642.2012.00925.x
