[[Image:Niue1.png|thumb|right|300px|Villages of Niue]] [[Image:Niue Verwaltungsgliederung.png|300px|thumb|right|Administrative village boundaries]] [[Niue]] is subdivided into 14 villages (that is, [[municipalities]]). Each village has a village council that elects its chairman. The villages are at the same time electoral districts. Each village sends an assemblyman to the [[Parliament of Niue]].[http://www.paclii.org/nu/legis/num_act/nivco1967321/ Niue Village Councils Ordinance 1967] ==List== The table lists the villages with population and area. These are the administrative subdivisions of Niue. Some of them include smaller settlements and hamlets. The villages Alofi North and Alofi South together serve as the [[Capital (political)|capital]] of Niue, [[Alofi]] (pop. 614). In the following table, the villages are listed in clockwise sequence. {| class="wikitable" |-style="background: #CCC;" ! align ="right"|No. || align ="left"|Village || align="right"| Population
([[Census]] 2001) || align="right"| Area[http://www.spc.int/prism/country/NU/stats/Nu_Environment/NU_Land/Land.htm The Total Land Area of Niue]

revision.text:
The [[Czech Republic]]'s official formal and short names at the [[United Nations]] are {{lang|cs|'''Česká republika'''}} and {{lang|cs|'''Česko'''}} in [[Czech language|Czech]], and '''the Czech Republic''' and '''Czechia''' in English.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unterm.un.org/UNTERM/Display/Record/UNHQ/NA/4275087d-4018-4082-899d-95f37efeda65|title=the Czech Republic|publisher=The United Nations Terminology Database |accessdate=2 September 2016}}</ref> All these names derive from the name of the [[Czechs]], the [[West Slavs|West Slavic]] ethnic group native to the [[Czech lands]]. ''Czechia'' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|tʃ|ɛ|k|i|ə}}), the official English short name specified by the Czech government, is used by many international organisations and attested as early as 1841. However, most English speakers use ''[the] Czech Republic'' in all contexts.<ref>[https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/04/a-scandal-in-czechia/478635/ Fallows, James. 2016. A Scandal in Czechia. ''The Atlantic'' (April 22).]</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.praguepost.cz/tempo/17285-czech-out-the-proposed-name.html | title=Czech out the proposed name | first=Daniel | last=Bardsley | date=October 16, 2013 | work=The Prague Post | access-date=2014-05-07 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508025619/http://www.praguepost.cz/tempo/17285-czech-out-the-proposed-name.html | archive-date=2014-05-08 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> [[Name of the Czech Republic#Other languages|Other languages]] generally have greater official use of a short form analogous to ''Česko'' or ''Czechia''<ref name="Pavel Boháč 1993"/><ref name="books.google.cz">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.cz/books?id=lCdMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA496&dq=%22czechia%22&hl=cs&sa=X&ei=4nzdU6X4G4T4yQO_goH4DQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22czechia%22&f=false|title=A New General Biographical Dictionary Projected and Partly Arranged|first1=Hugh James|last1=Rose|first2=Henry John|last2=Rose|first3=Thomas|last3=Wright|date=1 January 1841|publisher=Fellowes|accessdate=10 May 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> (such as French {{lang|fr|[la] Tchéquie}}, or Korean {{lang|ko|체코}}/''Cheko'') although forms equivalent to "Czech Republic" are not uncommon.<!-- see choices at [https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q213] -->
The Czech name {{lang|cs|'''Čechy'''}} is from the same root but means [[Bohemia]], the westernmost and largest historical region of the [[Czech lands]] and the modern Czech Republic. The name ''Bohemia'' is an [[exonym]] derived from the [[Boii]], a Celtic tribe inhabiting the area before the [[early Slavs]] arrived. The [[Lands of the Bohemian Crown]] (1348–1918) were part of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]; often called "the Czech lands", they sometimes extended further, to all of [[Silesia]], [[Lusatia]], and various smaller territories. The Czech adjective {{lang|cs|'''český'''}} means both "Czech" and "Bohemian".
The Czech Republic's official formal and short names in Czech were decided at its creation after the [[dissolution of Czechoslovakia]] in the so-called "Velvet Divorce" of 1993.<ref name="zakonyprolidi.cz">{{cite web|url=http://www.zakonyprolidi.cz/cs/1990-53|title=53/1990 Sb. Ústavní zákon České národní rady o změně názvu České socialistické republiky|first=AION CS -|last=info@aion.cz|website=Zákony pro lidi|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Pavel Boháč 1993"/><ref name="UNGEGN World Geographical Names"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.psp.cz/docs/laws/constitution.html|title=Ústava České republiky|website=www.psp.cz|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Pavel Boháč 1993">Pavel Boháč, Jaroslav Kolář (1993): Jména států a jejich územních částí = Names of states and their territorial parts. Český úřad zeměměřický a katastrální, Praha.</ref><ref name="UNGEGN World Geographical Names">[http://unstats.un.org/unsd/geoinfo/geonames/ UNGEGN World Geographical Names]</ref><ref name="Pavel Boháč 1993"/><ref name="nase-rec.ujc.cas.cz">{{cite web|url=http://nase-rec.ujc.cas.cz/archiv.php?art=6404|title=Naše řeč – Česko = Česká socialistická republika|first=redakce Naše řeč, ÚJČ AV ČR, v. v. i. -|last=naserec@ujc.cas.cz|website=nase-rec.ujc.cas.cz|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130309081723/http://www.ujc.cas.cz/jazykova-poradna/porfaq.html#cesko Česko (archivovaná verze z 9. března 2013)], Na co se nás často ptáte, Jazyková poradna, Ústav pro jazyk český AV ČR, Středisko společných činností AV ČR, nedatováno</ref><ref name="ceskoprirucka">[http://prirucka.ujc.cas.cz/?id=725 Česko], heslo v Internetové jazykové příručce, 2008–2014 Ústav pro jazyk český AV ČR, naposledy změněno 8. ledna 2012</ref>
==Czech-language name== The country is named after the Czechs ({{lang-cs|Čechové}}), a Slavic tribe residing in central [[Bohemia]] that subdued the surrounding tribes in the late 9th century and created the Czech/Bohemian state. The origin of the name of the tribe itself is unknown. According to legend, it comes from their leader [[Lech, Czech, and Rus|Čech]], who brought them to Bohemia. Research regards Čech as a derivative of the root ''čel-'' (member of the people, kinsman).<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://nase-rec.ujc.cas.cz/archiv.php?art=4320 | publisher=The Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic | title=Původ jména Čech | trans-title=Origin of the name ''Čech'' | first=Jaromír | last=Spal | journal=Naše řeč (Our Speech) | pages=263–267 | volume=36 | issue=9-10 | year=1953 | language=Czech | accessdate=2012-10-11}}</ref>
Several variants of the name have been used over the centuries, due to the evolution of the Czech language. The digraph "cž" was used from the time of the 16th-century ''[[Bible of Kralice]]'' until the [[Czech orthography#History|reform of 1842]], being eventually replaced by "č" (changing ''Cžechy'' to ''Čechy''). In the late 19th century the suffix for the names of countries changed from -y to -sko (e.g. ''Rakousy''-''Rakousko'' for Austria, ''Uhry''-''Uhersko'' for Hungary). While the notion of ''Česko'' appears for the first time in 1704, it only came into official use in 1918 as the first part of the name of the newly independent [[Czechoslovakia]] (''Česko-Slovensko'' or ''Československo'') . Within that state, the [[Czech Socialist Republic]] (''Česká socialistická republika'', ''ČSR'')<ref name="nase-rec.ujc.cas.cz"/> was created on 1 January 1969.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.psp.cz/docs/texts/constitution_1968.html|title=Ústava 1968|website=www.psp.cz|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> On 6 March 1990 the Czech Socialist Republic was renamed the [[Czech Republic]] (''Česká republika'', ''ČR'').<ref name="zakonyprolidi.cz"/> When Czechoslovakia broke up in 1993, the Czech part of the name was intended to serve as the name of the Czech state. The decision started a dispute as many perceived the "new" word ''Česko'', which before had been only rarely used alone, as harsh sounding or as a remnant of ''Československo''.<ref>[http://www.radio.cz/en/article/53850 Looking for a name – Radio Prague] Radio.cz (2011-01-21). Retrieved on 2011-01-27.</ref> The older term ''Čechy'' was rejected by many because it was primarily associated with Bohemia proper and to use it for the whole country was seen as inappropriate. This feeling was especially prominent among the inhabitants of [[Moravia]].
The use of the word "Česko" within the country itself has increased in recent years.<ref>According to the official Czech list of country names (Jména států a jejich územních částí. Český úřad zeměměřický a katastralní, Praha 2009, {{ISBN|978-80-86918-57-0}}): ''Česko je kodifikovaný jednoslovný název státu, který se podle ústavy oficiálně nazývá Česká republika'' ("Česko is a standardized one-word name of the state, which is officially named Česká republika according to its constitution")</ref> During the 1990s, "Česko" was rarely used and viewed as controversial: some Czech politicians and public figures (e.g. media magnate [[Vladimír Železný]]) expressed concern about the non-use of ''Česko'' and ''Czechia''; on the other side, individuals such as president [[Václav Havel]] and minister [[Alexandr Vondra]] have strongly opposed using these forms. In 1997, the Civic initiative Czechia was formed by linguists and geographers in [[Brno]] to promote the use of Czechia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.czechia-initiative.com/index.html|title=Official pages|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> The following year, a conference of professionals aimed at encouraging the use of the name was held at [[Charles University in Prague]]. The Czech [[Senate of the Parliament of the Czech Republic|Senate]] held a session on the issue in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.senat.cz/xqw/xervlet/pssenat/htmlhled?action=doc&value=26753|title=Senát PČR: Náhled dokumentu|website=www.senat.cz|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.senat.cz/xqw/xervlet/pssenat/htmlhled?action=doc&value=27462|title=Senát PČR: Náhled dokumentu|website=www.senat.cz|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref>
== English-language name == The historical English name of the country is Bohemia. This name derives from the Celtic tribe of [[Boii]], who inhabited the area from the 4th century BC. ''Boiohaemum'', as it was originally known in Latin, comes from the Germanic "Boi-haima", meaning "home of the Boii". The name survived all the later migrations affecting the area, including the arrival of the [[Slavs]] and the creation of the Czech state. In the 9th century, the country became officially known as the Duchy of Bohemia, changing to the Kingdom of Bohemia in the 11th century, and the Crown of Bohemia in the 14th century. A number of other names for the country have been used, including Lands of the Bohemian Crown, Czech/Bohemian lands, Bohemian Crown, the lands of the Crown of Saint Wenceslas and others.<ref name="Šitler 2017" /><ref>see Moryson 1626; https://archive.org/stream/fynesmorysons04moryuoft/fynesmorysons04moryuoft_djvu.txt</ref> The Bohemian state included the three historical lands: Bohemia (''Čechy'') in narrower meaning, [[Moravia]] (''Morava'') and [[Silesia]] (''Slezsko''). From the 14th century until 1635 it also included Upper and Lower [[Lusatia]]. The higher hierarchical status of the Bohemian region led to that name being used for the larger country, with the people and language of this country being commonly referred to as Bohemian.
The first known usage of the word Czechia in English comes from a book of 1841 by Henry and Thomas Rose ""A New General Biographical Dictionary Projected and Partly Arranged".<ref name="Šitler 2017" /><ref name="books.google.cz" />
Shortly before the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire, there were proposals to use the traditional name Bohemia for the newly-formed state.<ref>{{cite_book |last=Beneš |first=Edvard |authorlink=Edvard Beneš |year=1917 |title=Bohemia's case for independence |publisher=Allen & Unwin |location=London |isbn=0-405-02734-6}}</ref> However, out of consideration for Slovak national aspirations, the name "Czecho-Slovakia" (later "Czechoslovakia") was adopted instead.
After the establishment of Czechoslovakia, the name ''Czechia'' appeared in English, alongside the official name, as a reference to all the Czech lands<ref>Munzar J., Drápela M.V.: Czechia = Bohemia + Moravia + Silesia (Moravian Geographical Report. Brno: Ústav Geoniky, 1999. s. 58-61. Moravian Geographical Report, sv. 7, č. 2.) [http://www.muni.cz/research/publications/353778/], 1999</ref> and to differentiate between the Czech and [[Slovakia|Slovak]] parts of the state. It was used at least as early as 4 January 1925; appearing in the article "Literary History of the Czechs", published by ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://i1203.photobucket.com/albums/bb383/JanBlanicky/LiteraryhistoryoftheCzechs.jpg|title=New York Times: Literary history of Czechs (Jan.4, 1925)|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> The name was used in the Anglophone press before the German occupation of the Czech lands in 1939.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1939/03/20/archives/soviet-note-to-germany.html|title=Soviet Note to Germany|date=20 March 1939|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpress.org.il/Olive/APA/NLI/SharedView.Article.aspx?parm=%2FwB8ANL%2BnPwlFbqqHZmiA2bODax0AAxGfBgq4FZFSaR94CtNu1UI%2FxFmhikXq9%2FgYw%3D%3D&mode=image&href=PLS%2f1939%2f12%2f28&page=6|title=RUSSIA BETRAYED BY FROST|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48344226|title=Dr. Benes Broadcasts To His Countrymen - LONDON, March 15. - Barrier Miner (Broken Hill, NSW : 1888 - 1954) - 16 Mar 1940|website=Trove|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/search/pages/results/?state=&date1=1789&date2=1943&proxtext=Czechia&x=15&y=10&dateFilterType=yearRange&rows=20&searchType=basic|title=Search Results « Chronicling America « Library of Congress|website=chroniclingamerica.loc.gov}}</ref>
The current English ethnonym ''Czech'' comes from the [[Polish language|Polish]] ethnonym associated with the area, which ultimately comes from the Czech word ''Čech''.<ref name="CollinsDictionary">{{cite web|title=Czech definition and meaning|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/czech|website=''[[Collins English Dictionary]]''|publisher=[[HarperCollins]]|accessdate=19 November 2012|quote="'''C19: from Polish, from Czech ''Čech'''''"}}</ref><ref name="American Heritage Dictionary">{{cite web|title=Czech|url=https://ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=Czech|website=''[[American Heritage Dictionary]]''|publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]]|accessdate=24 January 2018|quote="'''[Polish, from Czech ''Čech''.]'''"}}</ref><ref name="OxfordDictionary">{{cite web|title=Czech - Definition in English|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/czech|website=''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]''|publisher=[[Oxford University]]|accessdate=11 April 2018|quote="'''Origin Polish spelling of Czech ''Čech''.'''"}}</ref> The words "Czechian", "Czechish", "Czechic" and later "Czech" (using antiquated Czech spelling)<ref name="Šitler 2017" /> have appeared in English-language texts since the 17th century. During the 19th-century national revival, the word "Czech" was also used to distinguish between the Czech- and German-speaking peoples living in the country. The term "Czechia" is attested as early as 1569 in Latin<ref name="Šitler 2017">{{cite news |last=Šitler |first=Jiří |date=July 1, 2017 |title=Czechia si to bude muset protrpět |trans-title= |url=http://www.pressreader.com/czech-republic/lidove-noviny/20170701/281973197671948 |language=Czech |work=Lidové noviny |location= |access-date=July 6, 2017 }}</ref> and 1841 in English (''Poselkynie starych Przjbiehuw Czeskych – Messenger of the old Fates of Czechia'').<ref name="Šitler 2017" /><ref name="books.google.cz"/> There were other early mentions in 1856<ref name=":0">{{cite book|ref=harv|title=Notes and Queries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wbs9AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA20|year=1856|publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> and in an 1866 report on the [[Austro-Prussian War]].<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article8840587|title=LATEST FROM PRUSSIA. - (From The Times' own Correspondent.) BERLIN, May, 23rd. - The Mercury (Hobart) - 21 Jul 1866|website=Trove|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref>
===Adoption of ''Czechia''=== In accordance with Resolution No. 4 I. of the UN conference on the standardization of geographic names (Geneva 1967) and Resolution No. 2 III. of the UN conference on the standardization of geographic names (Athens 1977), the Terminological Committee of the Czech Office for Surveying, Mapping, and Cadaster in cooperation with the Czech Ministry of Foreign Affairs standardized ''Czechia'' as the English translation of ''Česko'' in early 1993.<ref>Names of States and their Territorial Parts, The Terminological Committee of the Czech Office for Surveying, Mapping and Cadaster, Prague 1993.</ref>
Other names suggested in the 1990s included ''Czechomoravia'' or ''Czechlands''.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-05-10/news/9805100369_1_czech-republic-czechomoravia-moravia-and-silesia Rocks, David. 1998. After 5 Years, Czech Republic Still Searching for a Short Name. ''Chicago Tribune'' (May 10), p. 4.]</ref> However, by 2000 a short name had still not been fully adopted by the Czech authorities. At that time, the Second Secretary, Press and Politics at the British Embassy in Prague, Giles Portman, showed a willingness to accept the name ''Czechia''. Portman said in 2000, "Czechs still use the name ''Česká republika'' rather than ''Česko'', and the English equivalent, ''the Czech Republic'', rather than ''Czechia''. Were that pattern to change, we would have no problem at all with adapting accordingly. But we feel that the initiative for that change must come from the Czech side and not from us."<ref>Horová E.: Record of Proceedings of the 7th Public Hearing of the Senate, May 11, 2004 (Czech) recording Portman's letter from April 4, 2000 from the British embassy in Prague</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.senat.cz/cinnost/slyseni_petice/stenozaznamy/|title=Senát Parlamentu České republiky|first=Kancelář Senátu Parlamentu České|last=republiky|date=1 January 2012|website=www.senat.cz}}</ref>
In 2013, Czech president [[Miloš Zeman]] recommended the wider official use of ''Czechia'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/whats-in-a-name-czech-republic-mulls-shock-rebranding-as-czechia-8874839.html|title=What's in a name? Czech Republic mulls shock rebranding as Czechia|date=11 October 2013|publisher=|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> and on 14 April 2016, the government agreed to make ''Czechia'' the official short name.<ref>{{cite web|title=Czechia: English speakers told to use new name for Czech Republic|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/czechia-czech-republic-new-name-english-speakers-a7323596.html|website=independent.co.uk}}</ref> The new name was approved by the Czech cabinet on 2 May 2016 and registered on July 5, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vláda schválila doplnení jednoslovného názvu Cesko v cizích jazycích do databází OSN|date=May 5, 2016|url=https://www.mzv.cz/jnp/cz/udalosti_a_media/archiv_zprav/rok_2016/tiskove_zpravy/x_2016_05_02_vlada_schvalila_czechia.html|language=Czech|website=Ministerstvo zahraničních věcí České republiky|access-date=August 28, 2018|trans-title=The government has approved the addition of one-word Czech name in foreign languages to UN databases}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Czechia Has Won The Czech Republic Name Debate|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/francistapon/2017/05/22/czechia-has-won-the-czech-republic-name-debate/#5c9d94527d66|website=forbes.com}}</ref> In November 2016 the Ministry of Foreign Affairs presented recommendations on how to use the short name "Czechia" in international contexts.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Use the Short Country name "Czechia"|url=https://www.mzv.cz/jnp/en/foreign_relations/public_diplomacy/digital_diplomacy/how_to_use_the_short_country_name.html|website=mzv.cz/jnp/en|language=English}}</ref> On 1 June 2017, the geography department of the Faculty of Sciences of [[Charles University]] in Prague organised a special conference to assess the progress of the name's proliferation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/panorama/czechia-mapping-progress-one-year-on|title=Czechia: mapping progress one year on – Radio Prague|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2018}}</ref>
The new short name was published in the United Nations UNTERM and UNGEGN country name databases on 17 May 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/geoinfo/geonames/|title=UNGEGN World Geographical Names|website=[[United Nations]]}}</ref><ref>https://unterm.un.org/UNTERM/Display/Record/UNHQ/NA/4275087d-4018-4082-899d-95f37efeda65</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Short country name "Česko"/"Czechia" to be entered in UN databases|url=https://www.mzv.cz/jnp/en/issues_and_press/factsheets/x2016_04_21_the_completion_of_translations_of_the.html|website=mzv.cz|language=English}}</ref> In September 2016, the British [[Permanent Committee on Geographical Names for British Official Use|Permanent Committee on Geographical Names]] (PCGN) recommended the use of ''Czechia'' and added it as the sole form of the country name to their list of country names.<ref>https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/554812/Czechia_Information_Paper-Updated_September_2016.pdf</ref> On 26 September 2016, the [[International Organization for Standardization]] included the short name ''Czechia'' in the official ISO 3166 country codes list.<ref>https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:CZ</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/weather/2016/apr/14/czech-republic-czechia-new-name|title=Czech Republic officials say country would like to be called 'Czechia' instead|first=Oliver|last=Laughland|work=The Guardian|date=April 14, 2016}}</ref> [[Google]] switched to ''Czechia'' on [[Google Maps]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] country settings in January, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.praguemorning.cz/czech-republic-czechia-google-maps/|title=Czech Republic To "Czechia" On Google Maps|first=Jessica|last=Jones|date=20 January 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.weeklystandard.com/the-scrapbook/thats-czechia-mate|title=That's Czechia, Mate|date=2 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/news/swaziland-places-we-call-wrong-name/|title=From Staines to Swaziland: the places you’ve been calling by the wrong name|publisher=}}</ref> The name ''Czechia'' and its respective translations are also included in the Interinstitutional style guide of the [[European Union]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://publications.europa.eu/code/en/en-370100.htm|title=Publications Office — Interinstitutional style guide — 7.1. Countries — 7.1.1. Designations and abbreviations to use|last=OP/B.3/CRI|first=Publications Office -|website=publications.europa.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://publications.europa.eu/code/en/en-000300.htm|title=Publications Office — Interinstitutional style guide — What’s new|last=OP/B.3/CRI|first=Publications Office -|website=publications.europa.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref>
==Other languages== The equivalent of the Czech short form {{lang|cs|Česko}} is in routine use by most other languages. In a few cases (for example [[Polish language|Polish]] {{lang|pl|Czechy}}, [[Croatian language|Croatian]] {{lang|sh|Češka}} and [[Serbian language|Serbian]] {{lang|sh|Чешка/Češka}}) this form had historically been used for Bohemia. Other languages adopted new short forms such as {{lang|ar|تشيكيا}} ''Tshīkyā'' in [[Arabic]].<!--Note that the example {{lang|zh|捷克}} (''Jiékè'' in [[Standard Mandarin|Mandarin]]) in [[Chinese language|Chinese]] does not make sense in this context because the exact same Chinese characters have been used to translate the Czech part of Czechoslovakia--> In most cases, the new form has more or less completely replaced the formal name for most usages. However, usage in Spanish and French remains mixed, with the forms {{lang|es|Chequia}} and {{lang|fr|Tchéquie}} occasionally being used alongside the longer formal names {{lang|es|República Checa}} and {{lang|fr|République tchèque}}.
===German=== In German, the term applicable to the Czech part of Czechoslovakia used to be {{lang|de|Tschechei}}, comparable to {{lang|de|Slowakei}} for [[Slovakia]]. However, the usage of that term began to have negative connotations in connection with the [[Nazis]], who used the term {{lang|de|Rest-Tschechei}} "remaining Czechia" when [[German occupation of Czechoslovakia|they annexed the western parts of Czechoslovakia in early 1939]]. Since the restoration of Czechoslovakia and after the Second World War, the term {{lang|de|Tschechien}} is in use instead, as suggested by the Czech Ministry of Foreign Affairs as well as German and Austrian linguists. {{lang|de|Tschechien}} is a term from the 19th century that was originally used for the Czech lands that were part of [[Austria-Hungary]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Zum Begriff "Tschechei": Problematik und Sprachgebrauch|url=http://www.czech-tourist.de/tschechei.htm|website=Czech Tourist (Germany)|accessdate=13 May 2017}}</ref> The [[Federal Foreign Office]] uses Tschechien on its official list of countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/DE/Aussenpolitik/Laender/Laenderinfos/01-Nodes_Uebersichtsseiten/TschechischeRepublik_node.html%7D%7D|title=Tschechien|website=Auswärtiges Amt|accessdate=2 August 2017}}</ref>

On the geographic name of the Czech Republic"] by Leoš Jeleček, paper presented at the 2nd Slovak-Czech-Polish Geographical Seminar, Bratislava, September 1–5, 1999.{{dead link|date=September 2017}} * {{en icon}} [http://www.radio.cz/en/section/letter/from-bohemia-to-czechia "From Bohemia to Czechia"] Jiří Šitler (12 July 2016) [[Radio Prague]]

{{See also|Index of Republic of the Congo-related articles}} <!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{double image|right|Flag of the Republic of the Congo.svg|184|Coat of arms of the Republic of the Congo.svg|110|The [[Flag of the Republic of the Congo]]|The [[Coat of arms of the Republic of the Congo]]}} [[Image:LocationRCongo.PNG|thumb|The location of the [[Republic of the Congo]]]] [[Image:Un-congo-brazzaville.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Republic of the Congo]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to the Republic of the Congo:
'''[[Republic of the Congo]]''' – also known as '''Congo-Brazzaville''' or the '''Congo''', is a [[List of sovereign states|sovereign country]] located in [[Central Africa]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 3, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/cf.html|title=Republic of the Congo|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> It is bordered by [[Gabon]], [[Cameroon]], the [[Central African Republic]], the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], the [[Angola]]n [[exclave]] province of [[Cabinda (province)|Cabinda]], and the [[Gulf of Guinea]].
The [[republic]] is a former [[France|French]] [[colony]]. Upon independence in 1960, the former French region of Middle Congo became the Republic of the Congo. After a quarter century of [[Marxism]], Congo became a [[multi-party democracy]] in 1992. However, a brief civil war in 1997 ended in the restoration of former Marxist President [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]] to power.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== General reference == [[Image:Republic of Congo Map.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable relief map of the [[Republic of the Congo]]]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: {{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ɒ|ŋ|ɡ|əʊ}} * Common English country names: (The) [[Republic of the Congo]], [[Congo-Brazzaville]] or Congo (Congo being ambiguous with Democratic Republic of the Congo) * Official English country name: (The) [[Republic of the Congo]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectives]]: Congolese, Congo * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[International rankings of the Republic of the Congo]] * [[ISO country codes]]: CG, COG, 178 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:CG]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.cg]]
== Geography of the Republic of the Congo == [[Image:Congo Brazzaville Topography.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of the [[Republic of the Congo]]]]
[[Geography of the Republic of the Congo]] * The Republic of the Congo is: a [[Nation state|country]] * Location: ** [[Eastern Hemisphere]], on the [[Equator]] ** [[Africa]] *** [[Middle Africa]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[UTC+01]] ** Extreme points of the Republic of the Congo *** High: [[Mont Nabeba]] {{convert|1020|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[South Atlantic Ocean]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: 5,504 km ::{{Flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} 2,410 km ::{{Flag|Gabon}} 1,903 km ::{{Flag|Cameroon}} 523 km ::{{Flag|Central African Republic}} 467 km ::{{Flag|Angola}} 201 km :* Coastline: [[Gulf of Guinea]] 169 km * [[:commons:Atlas of the Republic of the Congo|Atlas of the Republic of the Congo]]
=== Environment of the Republic of the Congo === [[Image:Republic of Congo BMNG.png|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of the [[Republic of the Congo]]]]
* [[Climate of the Republic of the Congo]] * [[List of ecoregions in the Republic of the Congo|Ecoregions in the Republic of the Congo]] * [[Wildlife of the Republic of the Congo]] ** Fauna of the Republic of the Congo *** [[List of birds of the Republic of the Congo|Birds of the Republic of the Congo]] *** [[List of mammals of the Republic of the Congo|Mammals of the Republic of the Congo]]
==== Natural geographic features of the Republic of the Congo ====
* Glaciers in the Republic of the Congo: none <ref>The only [[List of glaciers in Africa|glaciers in Africa]] are on Mt Kenya (in Kenya), on Kilimanjaro (in Tanzania), and in the Ruwenzori Mountains (which are located in [[Uganda]] and the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]). See [http://iahs.info/redbooks/a126/iahs_126_0197.pdf Proceedings of the Riederalp Workshop, September 1978; Actes de l'Atelier de Riederalp, septembre 1978): IAHS-AISH Publ. no. 126, 1980.]</ref> * [[List of rivers of the Republic of the Congo|Rivers of the Republic of the Congo]] * World Heritage Sites in the Republic of the Congo: None

==== International organization membership ==== The Republic of the Congo is a member of:<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook/> {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} *[[African, Caribbean, and Pacific Group of States]] (ACP) *[[African Development Bank Group]] (AfDB) *[[African Union]] (AU) *''[[Conference des Ministres des Finances des Pays de la Zone Franc]]'' (FZ) *[[Development Bank of Central African States]] (BDEAC) *[[Economic and Monetary Community of Central Africa]] (CEMAC) *[[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO) *[[Group of 77]] (G77) *[[International Bank for Reconstruction and Development]] (IBRD) *[[International Civil Aviation Organization]] (ICAO) *[[International Criminal Court]] (ICCt) *[[International Criminal Police Organization]] (Interpol) *[[International Development Association]] (IDA) *[[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]] (IFRCS) *[[International Finance Corporation]] (IFC) *[[International Fund for Agricultural Development]] (IFAD) *[[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) *[[International Maritime Organization]] (IMO) *[[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) *[[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) *[[International Organization for Migration]] (IOM) *[[International Telecommunication Union]] (ITU) {{Col-2}} *[[International Telecommunications Satellite Organization]] (ITSO) *[[International Trade Union Confederation]] (ITUC) *[[Inter-Parliamentary Union]] (IPU) *[[Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency]] (MIGA) *[[Nonaligned Movement]] (NAM) *''[[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie]]'' (OIF) *[[Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons]] (OPCW) *[[United Nations]] (UN) *[[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development]] (UNCTAD) *[[United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO) *[[United Nations Industrial Development Organization]] (UNIDO) *[[United Nations Institute for Training and Research]] (UNITAR) *[[Universal Postal Union]] (UPU) *[[World Confederation of Labour]] (WCL) *[[World Customs Organization]] (WCO) *[[World Federation of Trade Unions]] (WFTU) *[[World Health Organization]] (WHO) *[[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO) *[[World Meteorological Organization]] (WMO) *[[World Tourism Organization]] (UNWTO) *[[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) {{Col-end}}

== History of the Republic of the Congo ==

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox country | conventional_long_name = Puntland State of Somalia<ref>[http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Puntland-const2010.pdf]</ref> | native_name = {{unbulleted list|item_style=font-size:88%; |{{native name|so|Dowladda Puntland ee Soomaaliya}} |{{native name|ar|ولاية أرض البنط الصومالية|italics=off}} |''{{transl|ar|Wilāyat Arḍ al-Bunṭ aṣ-Ṣūmāliyyah}}''}} | image_flag = Flag of Puntland.svg | image_coat = Puntland_State_of_Somalia_Coat_of_Arms.png | common_name = Puntland | image_map = LocationPuntland3.png | map_caption = {{unbulleted list|{{map caption |country={{nobold|Puntland}} |location_color=blue and dark blue|region=Somalia|region_color=blue and grey}}}} | capital = [[Garowe]] | largest_city = [[Bosaso]] | coordinates = {{Coord|8|24|N|48|29|E|type:city}} | official_languages = {{hlist|[[Somali language|Somali]] | [[Arabic]]}} | demonym = [[Demographics of Somalia|Somali]] (Puntlander) | government_type = [[Autonomy|Autonomous]] [[Presidential system|presidential democracy]] | leader_title1 = [[List of Presidents of Puntland|President]] | leader_name1 = [[Abdiweli Mohamed Ali]] | leader_title2 = Vice-President | leader_name2 = [[Abdihakim Abdullahi Haji Omar]] | established_event1 = Established | sovereignty_type = [[Autonomy|Autonomous State]] | sovereignty_note = within [[Somalia]] | established_date1 = 1 August 1998 | area_km2 = 212,510<ref name="resources figures"/> | area_rank = | area_sq_mi = 73,317 | percent_water = 21,711 | population_estimate = 2,284,633<ref name="PL EST. (2018) Retrieved 2016, from http://www.goobjoog.com/english/?p=14253">{{cite news | url=http://www.goobjoog.com/english/?p=14253 | title=Puntland Population Estimation Survey.| date= 2015 | access-date=December 27, 2015}}</ref> | population_census = | population_estimate_year = 2016 | population_estimate_rank = | population_census_year = | population_density_km2 = 20.1 | population_density_rank = 6758520 | population_density_sq_mi = | GDP_PPP = $700 Million<ref>http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/247911468197970788/pdf/100964-WP-P151626-PUBLIC-Box393254B-1st-Edition-Somalia-Economic-Update-Report.pdf</ref> | GDP_PPP_year = 2010 | GDP_PPP_rank = | GDP_PPP_per_capita = $200 | GDP_PPP_per_capita_rank = | Gini = <!--number only--> | Gini_year = | Gini_change = <!--increase/decrease/steady--> | Gini_ref = | Gini_rank = | HDI = <!--number only--> | HDI_year = | HDI_change = <!--increase/decrease/steady--> | HDI_ref = | HDI_rank = | currency = [[Somali shilling]] | currency_code = SOS | time_zone = [[East Africa Time|EAT]] | utc_offset = +3 | utc_offset_DST = +3 | time_zone_DST = not observed | calling_code = [[+252]] {{small|(Somalia)}} | cctld = [[.so]] | motto = "Star of the North" | regional_anthem = | area_magnitude = | country_code = so }}
'''Puntland''' ({{lang-so|Puntlaand}}, {{lang-ar|أرض البنط}}), officially the '''Puntland State of Somalia''' ({{lang-so|Dowladda Puntland ee Soomaaliya}}, {{lang-ar|بونتلاند دولة الصومال}}), is a region in northeastern [[Somalia]]. Centered on the town of [[Garoowe]] in the [[Nugal, Somalia|Nugal]] province, its leaders declared the territory an [[States and regions of Somalia|autonomous state]] in 1998 but is internationally recognized as an [[autonomous region]] of [[Somalia]].<ref>[http://www.puntlandgovt.com/puntland-state-of-somalia Puntland State of Somalia]</ref>
Puntland is bordered by [[Somaliland]] to its west, the [[Gulf of Aden]] in the north, the [[Guardafui Channel]] in the east, the central [[Galmudug]] region in the south, and [[Ethiopia]] in the southwest. There are two major geographical apices in Puntland, namely the [[Cape Guardafui]] which forms the tip of the Horn of Africa, and [[Ras Hafun]], the easternmost place on the continent.
The name "Puntland" is derived from the [[Land of Punt]] mentioned in [[ancient Egypt]]ian sources, although the exact location of the fabled territory is still a mystery. Many studies suggest that the Land of Punt was located in present-day Somalia,<ref>Dan Richardson, ''Egypt'', (Rough Guides: 2003), p. 404 {{ISBN|1858281881}}</ref><ref>Ian McMahan, ''Secrets of the Pharaohs'', (HarperCollins: 1998), p. 92 {{ISBN|0380797208}}</ref> whereas others propose that it was situated elsewhere.<ref>David B. O'Connor, Stephen Quirke, Quir O'Connor, ''Mysterious lands'', (UCL Press: 2003), p. 64 {{ISBN|1598742078}}</ref>
==History==
===Northern Sultanates=== {{main article|Somali aristocratic and court titles}} [[File:Sultan Mohamoud Ali Shire 2.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Mohamoud Ali Shire]], [[Sultan]] of the [[Warsangali Sultanate]]]] The [[Warsangali Sultanate]] was an imperial ruling house centred in northeastern and in some parts of southeastern Somalia. It was one of the largest sultanates ever established in the territory, and, at the height of its power, included the [[Sanaag]] region and parts of the northeastern [[Bari, Somalia|Bari]] region of the country, an area historically known as [[Maakhir]] or the ''Maakhir Coast''. The Sultanate was founded in the 13th century in northern Somalia by a group of Somalis from the [[Warsangali]] branch of the [[Darod]] clan, and was ruled by the descendants of the [[Gerad Dhidhin]]. In the late 19th century, the influential [[Sultan]] [[Mohamoud Ali Shire]] governed the Sultanate, assuming control during some of its most turbulent years.<ref>[http://www.warsangeli.org Warsangeli Sultanate]. Warsangeli.org. Retrieved on 20 May 2012.</ref> [[File:Garesadihafun.jpg|thumb|left|One of the forts of the [[Majeerteen Sultanate]] (Migiurtinia) in [[Hafun]]]]
The [[Majeerteen Sultanate]] (Migiurtinia) was founded in the mid-18th century. It rose to prominence the following century, under the reign of the resourceful Boqor (King) [[Osman Mahamuud]].<ref name="Metz">Helen Chapin Metz, ''Somalia: a country study'', (The Division: 1993), p. 10 {{ISBN|0844407755}}.</ref> Centred in [[Aluula]], it controlled much of northern and central Somalia in the 19th and early 20th centuries. The polity maintained a robust trading network, entered into treaties with foreign powers, and exerted strong centralized authority on the domestic front.<ref>''Horn of Africa'', Volume 15, Issues 1–4, (Horn of Africa Journal: 1997), p. 130.</ref><ref>''Transformation towards a regulated economy'', (WSP Transition Programme, Somali Programme: 2000) p. 62.</ref> [[File:Haji Bashir Ismail Yusuf2.jpg|thumb|upright|MP [[Haji Bashir Ismail Yusuf]], first legislator for [[Bosaso]] and first president of Somali parliament]]
The Majeerteen Sultanate was nearly destroyed in the mid-1800s by a power struggle between Boqor Osman and his ambitious cousin, [[Yusuf Ali Kenadid]]. After almost five years of battle, the young upstart was finally forced into exile in [[Yemen]]. A decade later, in the 1870s, Kenadid returned from the [[Arabian Peninsula]] with a band of [[Hadhramaut|Hadhrami]] [[musketeer]]s and a group of devoted lieutenants. With their assistance, he managed to overpower the local clans and establish the [[Sultanate of Hobyo]] in 1878.<ref name="Metz"/><ref>Lee V. Cassanelli, ''The shaping of Somali society: reconstructing the history of a pastoral people, 1600–1900'', (University of Pennsylvania Press: 1982), p. 75 {{ISBN|0812278321}}.</ref>
In late 1889, Boqor Osman entered into a treaty with [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]], making his realm an Italian [[protectorate]]. His rival Sultan Kenadid had signed a similar agreement vis-a-vis his own Sultanate the year before. Both rulers had signed the protectorate treaties to advance their own expansionist objectives, with Boqor Osman looking to use Italy's support in his ongoing power struggle with Kenadid over the Majeerteen Sultanate. Boqor Osman and Sultan Kenadid also hoped to exploit the conflicting interests among the European imperial powers that were then looking to control the Somali peninsula, so as to avoid direct occupation of their territories by force.<ref name="Majsult">The Majeerteen Sultanates</ref>
With the gradual extension into northern Somalia of European colonial rule, all three sultanates were annexed to [[Italian Somaliland]] and [[British Somaliland]] in the early 20th century.<ref name="Majsult"/> The local commercial hub of [[Bosaso]] was represented in the [[Parliament of Somalia|parliament]] of the succeeding [[Trust Territory of Somaliland]] by the MPs [[Haji Bashir Ismail Yusuf]] and Ugaas Yassin Ugaas Abdirahman.<ref>International Labour Office & League of Nations, ''Record of proceedings'', (International Labour Office: 1956), p.249.</ref><ref name="Hehbiy">[http://puntlandi.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/ismail.pdf H. E. Hagi Bashir Ismail Yousuf] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6AdpucTkQ?url=http://puntlandi.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/ismail.pdf |date=13 September 2012 }}</ref> Much of the northern sultanates' former domain is today coextensive with the autonomous Puntland region in northeastern Somalia.<ref>Istituto italo-africano, ''Africa: rivista trimestrale di studi e documentazione'', Volume 56, (Edizioni africane: 2001), p. 591.</ref>
===Establishment=== [[File:Somalian10ef5-1.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed]], one of the founders of Puntland]] Following the outbreak of the [[Somali Civil War]] in 1991, a homegrown constitutional conference was held in Garoowe in 1998 over a period of three months. Attended by the area's political elite, traditional elders (''Issims''), members of the business community, intellectuals and other civil society representatives, the autonomous Puntland State of Somalia was established to deliver services to the population, offer security, facilitate trade, and interact with domestic and international partners.<ref>His Excellency Abdirahman Mohamed Mohamud (Farole). President of Puntland State of Somalia [http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_s_Experience_in_Peace-building_and_State-building.shtml Somalia: Puntland's Experience in Peace-building and State-building] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017121333/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_s_Experience_in_Peace-building_and_State-building.shtml |date=17 October 2013 }}. garoweonline.com (3 April 2012)</ref> [[Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed]] served as the fledgling state's founding president.<ref>{{cite book|title=Somalia Business Law Handbook: Strategic Information and Laws|date=2013|publisher=International Business Publications|isbn=1438771045|page=102|url=http://www.google.com/books?id=mUIdWpwofCcC&pg=PA102#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=15 June 2017}}</ref>
As stipulated in Article 1 of the [[Transitional Federal Charter of the Somali Republic]], Puntland is a part of the Federal State of Somalia. As such, the region seeks the unity of the [[Somalis]] and adheres to a federal system of government.<ref name="MOPIC">{{cite web|url=http://mopicpl.com/Application/Puntland.pdf|title=Ministry of Planning and International Corporation|publisher=}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Unlike the secessionist region of Somaliland to its west, Puntland is not trying to obtain international recognition as a separate nation.<ref name="RRPuntland">{{cite web|title=Range Resources: Speculative Buy at 25.5p - Target price 56p |url=http://www.rangeresources.com.au/fileadmin/user_upload/research_Reports/gecr_29Nov07_RangeResources_mainnote.pdf |publisher=Range Resources |accessdate=21 February 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120100415/http://www.rangeresources.com.au/fileadmin/user_upload/research_Reports/gecr_29Nov07_RangeResources_mainnote.pdf |archivedate=2012-11-20 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> However, both regions have one thing in common: they base their support upon clan elders and their organizational structure along lines based on clan relationships and [[kinship]].<ref name="RRPuntland"/><ref>[http://wardheernews.com/Articles_09/March/18_somaliland_faisal.pdf Local and Global Norms: Challenges to "Somaliland's" Unilateral Secession] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606161640/http://wardheernews.com/Articles_09/March/18_somaliland_faisal.pdf |date=6 June 2013 }}. (PDF) . Retrieved on 20 May 2012.</ref> Since 1998, Puntland has also been in territorial disputes with Somaliland over the [[Sool, Somalia|Sool]] and [[Sanaag]] regions.
The legal structure of Puntland consists of the judiciary, legislative (House of Representatives) and the executive (the President and his nominated Council of Ministries) branches of government.<ref name="MOPIC"/> Though relatively peaceful, the region briefly experienced political unrest in 2001 when then President of Puntland, Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, one of the founding fathers of the Puntland State and its first president, wanted his term extended. Ahmed and [[Jama Ali Jama]] fought for control of the region, with Ahmed emerging victorious the following year. Ahmed served his second term as president until October 2004, when he was elected [[List of Presidents of Somalia|President of Somalia]]. He was succeeded in office by [[Mohamed Hashi]], who served until January 2005 when he lost a re-election bid in parliament to General [[Mohamud Muse Hersi]] "Adde".
==Politics== {{main article|Government of Puntland}}
===Muse administration=== [[File:Cadde1.jpg|thumb|[[Mohamud Muse Hersi]]]] In March 2005, then President Muse began an ambitious plan to build an airport in Puntland's commercial capital of [[Bosaso]], a project which is now complete and referred to as [[Bender Qassim International Airport]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.puntlandgovt.com/en/currentissues/information/further_information_add.php?id=27 |title=Puntland State Of Somalia |publisher=Puntlandgovt.com |date=18 March 2005 |accessdate=29 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420151618/http://www.puntlandgovt.com/en/currentissues/information/further_information_add.php?id=27 |archivedate=20 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.puntlandgovt.com/en/currentissues/information/current_issues_more.php?id=412 |title=The President Tours the Bossaso Airport Construction Site |publisher=Puntlandgovt.com |date=31 August 2007 |accessdate=29 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071107090353/http://www.puntlandgovt.com/en/currentissues/information/current_issues_more.php?id=412 |archivedate=7 November 2007 }}</ref>
In April 2007, Muse held meetings with Sheikh Saud bin Saqr Al Qasimi, the Crown Prince and Deputy Ruler of [[Ras al-Khaimah]] in the [[United Arab Emirates]] (UAE), where the two leaders signed an agreement on a deal for setting up of a dedicated livestock quarantine facility to facilitate the import of [[livestock]] from Somalia to the UAE.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ameinfo.com/116856.html |title=RAK and Puntland State of Somalia sign agreements to boost bilateral cooperation | Government of Ras Al Khaimah |publisher=AMEinfo.com |date= |accessdate=29 July 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120728101945/http://www.ameinfo.com/116856.html |archive-date=28 July 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In October 2008, Muse also signed a [[United Arab Emirates dirham|Dh]]170 million agreement with [[Dubai]]'s [[Lootah Group]] to support the construction of an airport, seaport and free zone in the coastal city of Bosaso. Muse indicated that "I believe that when we finish all these projects our people will benefit by getting good health services, education and overall prosperity."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hiiraan.com/news2/2008/Nov/puntland_the_land_of_opportunity.aspx |title=Puntland: The land of opportunity |publisher=Hiiraan.com |date=November 2008 |accessdate=29 July 2010}}</ref>
===Farole administration=== [[File:Abdirahman Farole.jpg|thumb|left|[[Abdirahman Farole]]]] In January 2009, [[Abdirahman Farole]] was elected the new President of Puntland. Upon assuming office, the Farole administration implemented a number of reforms, particularly in the security and judicial sectors. To bolster the region's justice system, numerous new prosecutors, judges and other court personnel as well as additional prison guards were hired and trained. In July 2010, the Puntland Council of Ministers unanimously approved a new anti-terrorism law to more efficiently handle terror suspects and their accomplices; a special court is also expected to be established within the region's existing criminal courts system to facilitate the task.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_Cabinet_approves_counterterrorism_law.shtml |title=Somalia: Puntland Cabinet approves counterterrorism law |publisher=Garoweonline.com |date=2010-07-17 |accessdate=2010-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514132216/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_Cabinet_approves_counterterrorism_law.shtml |archivedate=14 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Fiscally, a transparent, [[Government budget|budget]]-based [[public finance]] system was established, which has reportedly helped increase public confidence in government. In addition, a new regional constitution was drafted and later passed on 15 June 2009, which is believed to represent a significant step toward the eventual introduction of a [[Multi-party system|multi-party]] political system to the region for the first time;<ref name="GARW">{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Editorial_29/Somalia_President_Farole_the_Pride_of_Puntland_Editorial.shtml |title=President Farole – the Pride of Puntland |publisher=Garowe Online |date=2010-05-12 |accessdate=2010-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619122328/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Editorial_29/Somalia_President_Farole_the_Pride_of_Puntland_Editorial.shtml |archivedate=19 June 2010 }}</ref> such a system already exists in the adjacent Somaliland region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afrol.com/articles/14904 |title=Somaliland women prepare strategy for election |publisher=Afrol.com |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref>
More modest reforms were also put into motion in the social sector, particularly in the education and healthcare fields. The regional government has hired more healthcare workers and teachers, with major plans under way for school and hospital renovations.<ref name="GARW"/> One of the most significant new reforms enacted by the incumbent Puntland administration is the launching in May 2009 of the [[Puntland Agency For Social Welfare]] (PASWE), the first organization of its kind in Somali history. The agency provides medical, educational and counselling support to vulnerable groups and individuals such as orphans, the disabled and the blind. PASWE is overseen by a Board of Directors, which consists of religious scholars (''[[Ulama|ulema]]''), business people, intellectuals and traditional elders.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_leader_launches_welfare_agency_printer.shtml |title=Somalia: Puntland leader launches welfare agency |publisher=Garoweonline.com |accessdate=2010-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024151636/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_leader_launches_welfare_agency_printer.shtml |archivedate=24 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Democratization process=== {{main article|Puntland presidential election, 2014}} On 15 June 2009, the Puntland government passed a new regional draft constitution, representing a significant step toward the eventual introduction of a [[Multi-party system|multi-party]] political system to the region for the first time.<ref name="GARW"/> [[File:Somdbihd6.png|thumb|right|Women at a political function during the Puntland democratisation process]]
On 15 April 2012, the Puntland government opened a four-day constitutional convention officially inaugurating the new [[constitution of Puntland]]. Overseen by the Puntland Electoral Commission (PEC), the constitution represented the final step in the extant regional democratization process and was scheduled to be followed by the formation of political parties.<ref>{{cite news |title=Somalia: Puntland constitutional convention opens in Garowe |url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_constitutional_convention_opens_in_Garowe_printer.shtml |accessdate=19 April 2012 |newspaper=Garowe Online |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131203174745/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_constitutional_convention_opens_in_Garowe_printer.shtml |archive-date=3 December 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 12 September 2012, the [[Puntland Electoral Commission]] announced that the registration process for political parties in Puntland was now open. This came after the passing of the Political Association Law, the Referendum Act, the District Elections Law and the inauguration of the state constitution.<ref>{{cite news |title=Somalia: ‘Registration of political associations open’: Puntland Election Commission |url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Registration_of_political_associations_open_Puntland_Election_Commission_printer.shtml |accessdate=18 September 2012 |newspaper=Garowe Online |date=12 September 2012 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131203174815/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Registration_of_political_associations_open_Puntland_Election_Commission_printer.shtml |archive-date=3 December 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They will also be challengers in the next elections, scheduled for January 2014.<ref>{{cite news |title=Somalia: Puntland MPs amend electoral law |url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_MPs_amend_electoral_law_printer.shtml |accessdate=19 November 2012 |newspaper=Garowe Online |date=12 November 2012 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131203174747/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_MPs_amend_electoral_law_printer.shtml |archive-date=3 December 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 14 November 2012, President Farole announced the launching of his new political party, [[Horseed (political party)|Horseed]]. The association counts over 200 members and represents the incumbent Puntland government, including Vice President [[Abdisamad Ali Shire]] and the state Ministers. It is the first prospective party to register for an application with the Transitional Puntland Electoral Commission (TPEC). According to Farole, the general public will be eligible for membership in the organization once it is selected as an official political party.<ref>{{cite news |title=Somalia: Puntland President announces political association |url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_President_announces_political_association_printer.shtml |accessdate=19 November 2012 |newspaper=Garowe Online |date=14 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131203174747/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Puntland_President_announces_political_association_printer.shtml |archivedate=3 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Five other political associations were established the following month, including the Union of the People of the Regions or UPR (Ururka Gobolada Umadaha Bahoobey or UGUB),<ref>{{cite news|title=New political party launched in Puntland |url=http://puntlandi.com/new-political-party-launched-in-puntland/ |accessdate=3 December 2013 |newspaper=Puntlandi |date=4 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604041204/http://puntlandi.com/new-political-party-launched-in-puntland/ |archivedate=4 June 2013 }}</ref> the Development and Justice Party or DJP (Xisbiga Horumarinta iyo Cadaalada or Hor-Cad), Midnimo, Talowadaag (Consensus-building), and GAHAYR or Golaha Aqoonta iyo Horumarinta ee Asaaska Yoolka Runta (Council of Education and Development towards Founding the True Goal).<ref>{{cite news|title=Somalia: Two new Puntland political associations declared in Garowe|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Two_new_Puntland_political_associations_declared_in_Garowe_printer.shtml|accessdate=3 December 2013|newspaper=Garowe Online|date=21 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131210225632/http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Two_new_Puntland_political_associations_declared_in_Garowe_printer.shtml|archive-date=10 December 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Ali administration=== [[File:Presidentialres.jpg|thumb|Presidential residence in [[Bosaso]]]] On 8 January 2014, former Prime Minister of Somalia [[Abdiweli Mohamed Ali]] was elected the 5th President of Puntland overcoming Dr. Farole by a single electoral vote.<ref>{{cite news|title=Somalia: Former PM Abdiweli Ali Gas wins in the Puntland Presidential Elections|url=http://www.raxanreeb.com/2014/01/somalia-former-pm-abdiweli-ali-gas-wins-in-the-puntland-presidential-elections/|accessdate=8 January 2014|newspaper=Raxanreeb|date=8 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108122630/http://www.raxanreeb.com/2014/01/somalia-former-pm-abdiweli-ali-gas-wins-in-the-puntland-presidential-elections/|archivedate=8 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Abdihakim Abdullahi Haji Omar]] was concurrently elected Puntland's Vice President.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cabdixakiin Cabdullaahi Camey oo loo doortey Madaxweyne kuxigeenka Puntland|url=http://horseedmedia.net/2014/01/08/cabdixakiin-cabdullaahi-camey-oo-loo-doortey-madaxweyne-kuxigeenka-puntland/|accessdate=8 January 2014|newspaper=Horseed Media|date=8 January 2014}}</ref>
